PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Chiropractic Services
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron,Mrs Child,Mr Hawker,Mr Millar and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong opposition to any proposal to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words ''Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God'', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a Special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer. We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Mr Cowan.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hodgman and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Father Brian Gore
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:

That we wish to express our deep concern for the health and welfare of Father Brian Gore, an Australian citizen, and a missionary priest in the Philippines, who is charged with murder, subversion, possession of explosives and of inciting rebellion, warrants of arrest for which were issued and served on the 18th October 1982.

Your petitioners therefore pray that you do all in your power to urge the Philippines authorities to assist the plight of Father Gore and to help him to continue his missionary work without threat or fear of arrest; furthermore that Father Gore be allowed his right of legal advice and representation and of access at all times to his friends and religious colleagues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compensation for Adverse Drug Reactions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently pharmaceutical companies are not automatically liable for damage or death caused by their products and individuals attempting to obtain just compensation from these companies are disadvantaged by having to take legal action against multinational corporations.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-

1. Appropriate legisation be formulated so that pharmaceutical companies are made automatically liable for damage or death caused by their products which will obviate the need for the adversary system in law.
2. Appropriate legislation be formulated to ensure open inquiry in cases of medical incompetence or negligence leading to death or injury.
3. Appropriate legislation be formulated to allow relatives or ''next friends'' access to medical records in cases of injury or death resulting from medical incompetence or negligence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mandatory Reporting of Adverse Drug Reactions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently pharmaceutical companies are not automatically liable for damage or death caused by their products and that there are no statistics kept to determine whether or not drugs administered prior to death subsequently contributed to that death.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-
1. The recording of prescribed pre-death medication on all death certificates.
2. The collection and publication of relative statistics.
3. Mandatory reporting by doctors to the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (A .D.E.C.) or the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee (A.D.R.A.C.).
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Monitoring Medical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth.

That the current ''epidemic'' of adverse reactions to medical drugs (both prescription and over-the-counter) constitutes a severe health problem. The monitoring of such reactions is inadequate. There is a lack of awareness of the role of such drugs in causing disease. Consumers are confused by the large number of unnecessary brand names for the same drug. There is insufficient onus on drug companies to compensate the victims of adverse drug reactions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-
1. That there should be-
(a) Mandatory reporting of suspected drug reactions to the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee (A.D.R.A.C.).
(b) Recording of pre-death medication on death certificates.
(c) Collection and publication of the resulting statistics.
2. That the labelling of drugs should include-
(a) Generic (or chemical) names in place of brand names.
(b) Warnings of recorded adverse reactions.
3. That Australia should seek uniform international surveillance of medical drugs.
4. That Pharmaceutical companies be made automatically liable for injury or death caused directly or indirectly by their products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Curfew
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show:

That the potential noise hazard to residents of Sandgate, Shorncliffe, Brighton and Nudgee Beach (including 4,000 aged people), will become intolerable when the new Brisbane Airport is operative in 1987, if protective action is not taken.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will, when the redevelopment of the Brisbane Airport becomes operative, ensure that
(i) no jet aircraft use the 32'14' crosswind runway;
(ii) the Department maintain the curfew on the runway from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1 per cent of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other states.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80.00 per day in the other states. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives assembled, should-
Use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, parents and teachers working for and in the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia, respectfully showeth that:
We support the Federal Government's determination to restore the community's confidence in public education.

We support the Federal Government's opposition to base grants to ALL non government schools (a) by reducing funds to those schools already operating above community standards and (b) funding other schools according to need.
We support the Federal Government's policy of negotiations and planning with State/Territory Governments regarding joint programmes for improvements in Government schools in the next decade.
1. We ask that the Federal Government increase recurrent funding for Government schools as promised.
2. We ask that the Federal Government provide promised funding for special programmes to assist primary children with learning difficulties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Members of the Australian Federal Parliament. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Meat Export Inspection Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

1. That Australia's Meat Exports are being placed in an uncompetitive position by the imposition of substantial Export Meat inspection charges whilst Australia 's competitors receive free inspection plus considerable subsidies.

2. These charges are causing substantial loss of business for export abattoir operations and loss of jobs for the employees due to the disparity in inspection costs of export and non-export works arising from a 200 per cent increase in federal government charges at export works.

3. That immediate steps should be taken to end serious inquiry being done by these charges to export abattoir operators, their employees, live-stock producers and all others dependent of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will act to immediately suspend all export inspection charges for a period of three years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Citizenship Act contains provisions for an Oath of Allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors, and an Affirmation of Allegiance, to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors.
That the said Oath of Allegiance and Affirmation of Allegiance are supported by the overwhelming majority of Australians.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:

will ensure that the present Oath of Allegiance and Affirmation of Allegiance are retained, and will strongly oppose any attempts to remove all references to God and the Queen from the Oath of Allegiance and any attempts to remove all references to The Queen from the Affirmation of Allegiance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Road Works
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:

That Bozlin Pty Ltd trading as John Bozic Automotive Services, have provided for many years good and reliable service to customers near Parliament House, and represent the only Automotive Service Station available in the Parliamentary triangle, convenient to visitors and persons working at, or near Parliament House.
That the National Capital Development Commission has indicated its intention to close the access road between Coronation Drive and Kaye Place.

That access has existed in one form or another between Kaye Place and Coronation Drive for most of the last fifty five years, and in the judgment of petitioners that access road is convenient, and represents no traffic hazard.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will ensure that the traffic link between Coronation Drive and Kaye Place is not closed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a ''first strike'' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia are concerned that the Federal Government has callously ignored the severe problems of Australian post-school students in the 1983 Federal Budget. We are disillusioned with the following series of broken promises.
(1) that an ALP Government will progressively increase the maximum TEAS benefit until it equates with the single unemployment benefit and then maintains the nexus;
(2) that an ALP Government will progressively increase the TEAS family income means test until it equates with the average weekly earnings and then maintains the nexus;

(3) that an ALP Government will remove the anomalies in the TEAS regulations and liberalise the definition of 'independence' which allows students to have their needs assessed separately from their parent's circumstances.
We urge the government to honour these promises immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled.
The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cohen and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of concerned people of the Electorate of Indi respectfully show their desire to stop the spread of Paterson's Curse.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House (the Government) act to implement the biological control of Paterson's Curse.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Queensland respectfully show:

Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads; alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths; alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol, alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debit Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth our concern over the continuing taxation of Parents' Club bank accounts by way of the Bank Account Debit Tax.
Your petitioners therefore pray that-

Parent clubs being set up by Government Regulation in the State of Victoria ( Regulation XLII) be recognised by the Australian Government as education auxiliaries, in the same way as are School Councils.
The Treasurer move immediately to exempt Parent Clubs from the tax in the same way as are School Councils.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADELAIDE TO VICTOR HARBOR RAILWAY LINE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) condemns the Government and, in particular, the Minister for Transport for allowing the closure of the Adelaide to Victor Harbor railway line without at least making adequate arrangements for an alternative tourist train to operate on this extremely important tourist route;

(2) notes that both Federal and State Labor Governments have agreed to the cessation of Australian National's operation of this line whereas the Federal Government and State Liberal governments did not agree to such a closure;

(3) calls upon the Federal Government to take immediate action to ensure alternative tourist rail services are provided on this important and historic South Australian railway line which is of great significance to the south coast and Victor Harbor in particular.

(d) that the Brisbane sackings have affected employees of only one private health fund, that one being a fund which refused to partake in negotiations to set up transitional employment arrangements for health fund employees; and
(2) condemns and rejects irresponsible claims to the effect that the Government was not adequately looking after sacked private fund employees.

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) notes with satisfaction the completion of the second free elections in El Salvador in three years, despite attempted terrorist intimidation of voters within El Salvador and an orchestrated leftist campaign to discredit the elections in the world at large; and
(2) congratulates Dr Jose Napoleon Duarte of the Christian Democratic Party on his success in the elections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
TORRES STRAIT FISHERIES BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 28 March 1983, on motion by Mr Hayden:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the debate on this Bill is resumed I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will continue my speech which I commenced yesterday. Fishermen in waters beyond the protected zone and under the jurisdiction of the other country who breach the laws in any fishery not covered by a subsidiary arrangement may be prosecuted in that country's courts. The adoption of this Treaty in December 1978 by the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea, after years of negotiation, has been a dramatic achievement. It is a unique treaty. It attempts to provide a workable solution to a complex situation. The Treaty deals with matters affecting the sovereign interests of both countries. The Treaty contains the framework for the resolution of special legal, moral and humanitarian problems that may arise.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time the Treaty was concluded the governments of both Australia and Papua New Guinea regarded the Treaty as a fair and reasonable solution of such matters as the conflicting claims of the Queensland and Commonwealth governments , the traditional rights of the Torres Strait Islanders and the coastal people of Papua New Guinea and the allocation of the sea and seabed resources of Torres Strait. Public servants on each side of the negotiations laboured hard and long to determine a coherent sequence of historical record and to apply the relevant principles of the international law of the sea to a complex historical and geographical situation which has no parallel elsewhere in the world.

Moreover, the Treaty could not have been concluded unless there had been friendly relations between Australia and Papua New Guinea. The continuation of this mutual good will will be essential to allow the Treaty to function smoothly . It is noteworthy that the Joint Committtee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), in its report on the Torres Strait Treaty recognised that the seabed resources line has the potential to become a major barrier between Australia and Papua New Guinea. The consequences of such a development would be disastrous for the Torres Strait Islands people.

It should be recorded that the accomplishment of the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Peacock) in bringing the Treaty negotiations to a satisfactory conclusion deserves commendation, notwithstanding the obstruction and obdurate opposition of the Premier of Queensland. This Treaty owes much to the initiative of the former Prime Minister of Australia, the Hon. E. G. Whitlam, who on 15 December 1972, wrote to the Premier of Queensland suggesting that discussions should commence between officials of the governments of Papua New Guinea, Queensland and Australia. Mr Bjelke-Petersen replied on 11 January 1973, that he could see no good purpose being served by such discussions. Mr Bjelke-Petersen continued to oppose the development of the Treaty virtually until the time it was signed in December 1978.

Within the preamble of the Treaty the aspirations of the Australian and Papua New Guinea governments for this Treaty to help maintain the bonds of good and friendly neighbours, are fittingly encapsulated in these words:

Recognising the importance of protecting the traditional way of life and livelihood of Australians who are Torres Strait Islanders and of Papua New Guineans who live in the coastal area of Papua New Guinea in and adjacent to the Torres Strait;
Recognising also the importance of protecting the marine environment and ensuring freedom of navigation and overflight for each other's vessels and aircraft in the Torres Strait area;

Desiring also to co-operate with one another in that area in the conservation, management and sharing of fisheries resources and in regulating the exploration and exploitation of seabed mineral resources;
As good neighbours and in a spirit of co-operation, friendship and goodwill. Have agreed as follows . . .
We must never surrender our duty to honour these resolutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Torres Strait Treaty ( Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill which, as has been pointed out previously in the House, was negotiated by the former Government. I pay tribute to the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), who is at the table, for the great efforts that he made in bringing about this Treaty for Australia and its relations with our near neighbour, Papua New Guinea.
—Thank you. You and I had to talk about it a lot though, didn't we?

—Yes. I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his comment because it shows that the Leader of the Opposition is a man of understanding. He negotiated with both the Queensland Government and the Government of Papua New Guinea. He took into account the views of people in the Parliament, including people on the back bench at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said, the purpose of the Bill is to amend the existing Australian legislation covering many areas-fisheries, historic shipwrecks, migration, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, the Quarantine Act, the Wildlife Protection ( Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act, the Customs Act, the Coral Sea Islands Act and the continental shelf legislation-to enable the ratification of the 1978 Torres Strait Treaty. As my colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who is the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, said in the House yesterday, the passage of this legislation is an historic development in the constitutional history of Australia and, I add, the constitutional history of Papua New Guinea, because in Australia we have only one international territorial boundary and that boundary, which is defined in this Treaty, is between Australia and Papua New Guinea.

The legislation that I have referred to defines the elements of the relationship which will govern the conduct of the relations between the two countries in practical matters in the Torres Strait, which is our closest border region with Papua New Guinea. The Treaty is a milestone in the history of Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea, our closest neighbour. I guess it is often forgotten how close it is. At low tide, at least one of those wonderful islands in the Torres Strait-the three closest islands to the Papua New Guinea border-is within walking distance and people come and go by canoe from the southern villages of Papua New Guinea. Regrettably, there are more motor boats than the lovely old, historical canoes. There is a lot of trade, barter and activity between the Torres Strait Islanders, who are, of course, citizens of Australia and resident in the State of Queensland, and the people of Papua New Guinea.

It is worth remembering that the Treaty was negotiated by a sovereign government in Papua New Guinea with Australia, that it was not imposed on Papua New Guinea when Australia was the administering colonial power both of the old Territory and of the old League of Nations Trust Territory and that Australia, to its credit, gave Papua New Guinea independence as the former colonial power and then at arm's length negotiated the Treaty with Papua New Guinea. I think that some tribute needs to be paid to Papua New Guinea in this regard because it was a difficult and long negotiation which it handled and treated in a most serious and decent fashion.

Tribute must also be paid to the Government of Queensland. I was disappointed that the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) criticised the Government of Queensland. I acknowledge his recognition of the work that the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence did during the time that I was Chairman of the Sub-Committee on Territorial Boundaries. I will come to the work of the Parliamentary Joint Committee in a minute, but I pay tribute to the State of Queensland because the islands of the Torres Strait are in the State of Queensland. It can easily be forgotten in Canberra that they are the front line of Australia in every sense of the word. I think it is a remarkable achievement on all fronts, particularly the way in which the Premier of Queensland and the Government of Queensland contributed to the debate. They had a proper point of view. They put that point of view.

I met the Premier of Queensland when I was Chairman of the Parliamentary Sub- Committee. I must admit that I was most impressed with his position. I think that the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence at that time recognised the view of the Government of Queensland. Of course the Torres Strait Islanders are not only citizens of Australia but also residents of the State of Queensland and have both an Australian and a Queensland point of view, and a valid point of view.

I refer to the work of the Parliamentary Committee. I pay tribute to the Leader of the Opposition, the former Foreign Minister, for the work that he did in achieving this most remarkable negotiation and bringing it to a conclusion. I pay tribute to the Papua New Guinea Government and to the Government of Queensland. But mention ought to be made, and I know that some honourable members have mentioned this previously in the debate, of the work of the Parliament. When I say the Parliament on this occasion I mean the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, which comprises members from both sides of the Parliament, from both the House of Representatives and the Senate. I think that in this day and age far too much is made of the confrontation side of politics and that too little recognition is given to those areas where members of this Parliament, both of the Senate and of the House of Representatives, agree across frontiers in the interests of Australia.

I think that the interests of Australia were important in this negotiation with Papua New Guinea of the Torres Strait Treaty. There was bipartisan agreement by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence at that time between members of the former Government and the then Opposition, which is now the Government. I think that the areas of agreement are the unsung stories of this Parliament.

It is worth recalling that the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence set up the Sub-Committee on Territorial Boundaries which looked at the question of the Torres Strait boundaries, heard evidence, made inquiries, visited the Torres Strait on a number of occasions and tabled a report in the Parliament on 9 November 1976. Following that the Sub-Committee was requested by the main Committee, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, to continue to monitor the issue of territorial borders between Australia and Papua New Guinea. That responsibility to monitor current developments on the issue of territorial borders between Australia and Papua New Guinea was formalised as a term of reference. The Parliamentary Committee played, I believe, a very significant role in the resolution of that boundary dispute between Australia and Papua New Guinea in the Torres Strait. That Committee was a way in which the Parliament could be informed of the views of the people living in the Torres Strait and of the Torres Strait Islanders. The Committee took evidence in the Torres Strait. Its members visited not only Thursday Island but also other islands of the Torres Strait. I can remember that members of the Sub-Committee were in a boat which hit a coral reef between Darnley and Murray Islands on one occasion. We wondered whether we were ever going to return to our electorates and to the Parliament of Australia. The Parliament of Australia and its members have a responsibility on such occasions to get the views of the people, in this case the views of the people of the Torres Strait and of the people of Queensland.

It is interesting to note that in 1976 the Parliamentary Committee said that the Government should make every attempt to inform the Australian public of the terms and provisions of the Treaty, and that the Government did. The Committee also said that in the implementation of the Treaty the Government should ensure that the spirit as well as the terms of the Treaty were observed. I think that has been carried out in the negotiations by the former Government and the present Government. The Committee also said that Torres Strait Islanders should be involved in the administration of the Treaty, and that has occurred.

Another important recommendation that the Committee made as a result of its inquiry in the Torres Strait was that control over illegal migration from Papua New Guinea to the Torres Strait be increased substantially and that, if practical, local Australians be employed to achieve this purpose. I am pleased to say that the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs took that matter up, and it is interesting to note that the Torres Strait legislation before us today involves amendments to the Migration Act. One must remember that it is always possible for people to enter this country illegally from the north, from Papua New Guinea. It is easy to go by canoe, by boat or even by aeroplane from the Papua New Guinea island of Daru and land on Thursday Island-no one would know you were there-and then catch the regular service south. That is a matter for concern and vigilance, which I am sure will continue.

The Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee made a number of other recommendations about animal and plant quarantine procedures. It made recommendations about the exploitation of hydrocarbon deposits, if discovered in the area. It made recommendations about the right of all Torres Strait Islanders to practise their traditional subsistence fishing and said that that right should always be preserved. The Committee also stated that every encouragement should be given to Torres Strait Islanders to enter the commercial fishing industry, should they so desire.

The final recommendation of the report was that the interests of the Torres Strait Islanders should always receive consideration by the Australian Government after the Treaty had been ratified and commenced to be implemented. The former Government took into account the views of the Torres Strait Islanders as represented to the Parliamentary Joint Committee and the views received directly as a result of a visit to the area by the former Prime Minister. I say to the present Government and to the present Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), who is in the House now, that I hope that, in the administration of this Treaty and this legislation, the interests of the Torres Strait Islanders will continue to receive consideration by the Australian Government, notwithstanding that the Treaty has been ratified and that the legislation has gone through the House, because there will always be the risk of something going wrong and the opportunity for something to go astray. The Torres Strait Islanders and their interests have to be remembered down here in Canberra.

I have paid tribute to Papua New Guinea, to the Australian Government, to the former Australian Government and to the work of the Parliamentary Joint Committee. The way in which the Parliament was involved in important negotiations between the executive government of the day and a third party, that is, another nation, is a tribute to the parliamentary committee system. I hope that the present Government will continue to see the role of parliamentary committees in that light. I pay tribute to the role of the Leader of the Opposition, a former Foreign Minister and one of Australia's most distinguished Foreign Ministers. This is one of Australia's most important treaties. I also pay tribute to those public servants involved, some of whom are in the gallery today serving the present Government. I pay tribute also to those public servants who have moved into other jobs in the Department of Foreign Affairs.

There was a great effort and understanding of the issues in the Department of Foreign Affairs. From time to time, the people on the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence had to put, perhaps, the view of the Torres Strait Islander to those officials. I pay tribute to those officials because it is only too easy to criticise officials and the bureaucracy, and I do that from time to time, when justified, and I will continue to do so. But tribute needs to be paid to the officials whom I knew, the officials who gave evidence to the Parliamentary Committee. I like to think that the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, being a way in which the Parliament has an interface with the bureaucracy, had some influence over the Foreign Affairs officials negotiating the agreement.

On the question of the future of the Torres Strait Islanders and the people of Torres Strait, I was disappointed in the Government's newly announced tourist air fares. The people of Torres Strait, of Thursday Island and the other islands of Saibai, Boigu and so on, Wednesday Island and Friday Island, will not have the opportunity that other Australians have to take advantage of the Kangaroo Pass air fares. I hope that the Minister for Foreign Affairs will intervene with the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) and with the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) to see that the people of Torres Strait, the people of Queensland, have access and have the opportunity to take advantage of the so-called Kangaroo Pass air fares.

One of the great problems facing the people of the Torres Strait is their isolation. I hope that this omission by the Government is not taken to be fulfilling the recommendation made by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, back in 1976, that the interests of the Torres Strait Islanders should always receive consideration by the Australian Government. In relation to the Government's new so-called cheaper air fares policy, it would seem that not only have the Torres Strait Islanders been forgotten, not only have they been denied the opportunity of going south from the islands-because one has to go by boat or by air; one cannot go by road, by bus, truck or car-but also they are denied the opportunity of cheaper fares for getting south. Similarly, other Australians are denied the opportunity of taking advantage of these so-called cheaper air fares and of visiting the wonderful islands of the Torres Strait and this great border area, and the opportunity of seeing and getting to know and to understand the people of Torres Strait. Thursday Island and the islands of Torres Strait are among the world's most beautiful spots and they have enormous tourism potential.

I pay tribute again to the former Foreign Minister, the Leader of the Opposition. I pay tribute to the officials who negotiated this agreement, to the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea which signed the Treaty, and to the work of the Parliamentary Committee. As I have said, the Opposition, on a bipartisan note, has supported this legislation, which was negotiated by the former Government and which is a remarkable achievement. In conclusion, I state that I wish for the continuance in the future of good relations between Australia and Papua New Guinea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The delimitation of maritime boundaries is one of the major areas of ocean law where disputes between countries occur with frequency and where the development of governing principles of law remains difficult. The signing in December 1978 by Australia and Papua New Guinea of the treaty concerning sovereignty and maritime boundaries in the area between the two countries, including the area known as Torres Strait, and the related matters, thus represents a significant achievement. Not only does the treaty indicate that direct negotiation can successfully resolve complex maritime boundary disputes, but it also contains several novel and significant features that may point the way to solutions elsewhere. Among the novel features are separate seabed and fishery jurisdiction lines, the establishment of a protected zone, and complex arrangements regarding the sharing of the catch of commercial fisheries. Although the treaty delimits a stretch of approximately 1,200 miles, from the Coral Sea, in the east, to the Arafura Sea, in the west, the most significant aspects of the Treaty relate to the Torres Strait area.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking today to the Torres Strait Treaty (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill, I am mindful of the future of the traditional inhabitants of the Torres Strait area, who have resided for generations on the islands in the Torres Strait. I am also mindful that many interests, including those of the Torres Strait Islanders, need to be taken into account and that not only the Commonwealth Government and particularly the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) but also the Minister's counterparts in the Queensland and Papua New Guinea governments will be consulted in the future. I am aware of the lengthy consultations that have already taken place not only at government level but also at a scientific level. The consultations between Australian and Papua New Guinea scientists in July 1981 and February 1983 were extremely useful and provided a basis for future management decisions.

I will talk later about the future management of the Torres Strait fisheries, an issue which has been severely neglected in the past. It is as a result of this neglect that difficulties now exist within the fishing industries of this region of Australia. The Torres Strait area is a unique expanse located between Cape York at the northern extremity of Australia and the southern coast of Papua New Guinea. The area consists of a considerable number of islands, some large and inhabited and others amounting to no more than small rocks and uninhabited caves. They are all Australian, with the exception of one or two small islands close to the Papua New Guinea coast. As well as the special geographical features of the area, one of the major factors that had to be taken into account in devising solutions to the maritime delimitation problem was the need to protect the livelihood and lifestyle of the local inhabitants. The Papua New Guineans of the immediately adjacent area and the Torres Strait Islanders are ethnically distinct. The Islanders are themselves distinct from the Australian Aboriginal people. The local inhabitants still engage in many traditional activities which the Torres Strait Treaty, fortunately, has sought to preserve.

I wish to deal with the areas within the Torres Strait to which I have just referred. Firstly, I refer to the top western group which includes the islands of Saibai, Dauan and Boigu. These are the islands closest to the New Guinea coastline. These islands are swampy mud islands, excepting Dauan, largely surrounded by extensive belts of mangroves. Mangrove fisheries for barramundi, salmon, catfish, mudcrabs and turtles are the major traditional fisheries. I move now to the mid-western group of Badu, Moa, Mabuiag. These large, dry continental islands have significant fisheries on the reef-pelagic fishing, turtles and lobsters. Dugongs are also taken.

The central group, which consists of the York, Coconut, Stephen, Sue, Yam and other islands are coral cays. These form islands of which York is the focus of prawn trawling operations in the straits. These prawn trawling operations are not traditional fishing; they are in fact commercial fishing. Finally, the eastern group, that is, Murray and Darnley islands, are volcanic, hilly islands where gardens are the major traditional food source. Notwithstanding that, reef fish and turtles are an important part of the tradition. I made reference to them because traditional fishing is a very important part of the lifestyle of the Torres Strait Islander. As I have said previously, it is very important that they are protected within this Treaty. The Torres Strait Fisheries Bill will afford such protection.

It is encouraging that consultations are presently taking place between the people of the Torres Strait and adjacent coastal areas and representatives of the commercial fishing industry. This consultation is necessary and it will be necessary for it to continue in the future. In this regard the setting up of the Torres Strait Joint Advisory Council under the provisions of the Treaty is to be commended. It is imperative that the people of the Torres Strait have a significant voice in the deliberations of that Council and that their input to the Council should be acted on by our Government.

I wish now to speak to the amendment proposed by the Opposition for the omission from clause 39 of the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill of the words 'where it considers it appropriate to do so'. The Government opposes that amendment. The text of the Bill that is now before the House was arrived at after extensive negotiations with Queensland. Clause 39 was drafted in its present form on the understanding that the Joint Advisory Council would be consulted only on broad policy issues affecting the traditional inhabitants and on important matters which could not be easily resolved by other consultative processes. It was never -I emphasise that-intended that the three Islander members of the Joint Advisory Council would be consulted on day to day fisheries management matters handled by the Protected Zone Joint Authority. The proposed amendment would oblige the Joint Authority to consult with three Islander members of the Joint Advisory Council about every matter which the Joint Authority was considering that was likely to affect the Australian traditional inhabitants. Given the role of the Joint Advisory Council, this would be clearly impractical.

In opposing that amendment I point out to members of the Opposition that the Joint Authority has power under clause 40(7) to establish advisory groups the membership of which may include Islander and commercial fishing industry representatives. It is envisaged that this will be the principal mechanism through which Islanders will be able to express their views to the Joint Authority on detailed fisheries management issues. Commonwealth and Queensland officials are already consulting with members of a consultative group. This consultative group already contains members of the Australian traditionalists. A similar consultative group exists for the commercial fishing industry. It is planned to continue and to build on these consultative arrangements once the Joint Authority commences operating to ensure that the interests of the Islanders in the commercial fishing industry are properly recognised and catered for. It is therefore necessary to leave clause 39 in its present form. The interests of the Australian traditionalist is well catered for in the provisions of clause 40(7).

The fisheries provisions of the Treaty, which are now provided for in this legislation, oblige the Australian and Papua New Guinea governments firstly to protect the traditional way of life and lifestyle of the traditional inhabitants , including the traditional fishing, which is the principal purpose of the protected zone; secondly, to co-operate and consult with each other in the management and optimum utilisation of protected zone commercial fisheries, provided due protection is given to traditional fisheries; thirdly, to manage particular fisheries jointly if either the Australian or the Papua New Guinea Government considers this necessary; and, fourthly, to implement a complex catch sharing arrangement for protected zone commercial fisheries jointly managed by the two countries. This latter arrangement entitles Australian fishermen to 25 per cent by weight or value of the commercial catch of swimming or sedentary species in the protected zone north of the agreed fisheries or seabed jurisdiction lines respectively and gives Papua New Guinea fishermen a similar entitlement south of the lines. These provisions are set to come into force five years hence.

Fifthly and finally, the fisheries provisions oblige the Australian and Papua New Guinea governments to protect and preserve the marine environment and the indigenous flora and fauna in and around the protected zone. Trawling operations in the Torres Strait are targeted on several species of tiger, endeavour and king prawns, which are trawled at night. The annual catch has been around 800 tonnes. There has been a sharp rise in the number of trawlers operating in recent years.

Many operate for only a few months of the year. This increase has been brought about by reduced catches in the Gulf of Carpentaria and the East Coast. Concern at the number of trawlers has been expressed by the locals, trawlermen themselves, lobster divers and traditional fishermen. It is in this area that management can play a vital role. Previously trawlers sold much of their catch to processing plants on Thursday Island. But recently they have been selling to Cairns-based mother ships. The presence of mother ships has caused Thursday Island processors to close down and rely solely on processing rock lobster.

In 1981, at the fishing industry's request, an area west of Warrior Reefs was closed to trawling by Commonwealth and Queensland authorities because of industry information that the area is a tiger prawn nursery ground. In November 1982 the Queensland Government closed to trawling the territorial waters of Saibai, Dauan, Boigu, Badu, Moa, Mabuiag, Sue, Yam and Poll Islands. It is to be hoped that continual monitoring of the commercial fisheries in the Torres Strait regions will see the future regulation of fishing in these areas, including the closing down of grounds, when it is deemed necessary.

The continued co-operation of the governments, the industry and the Islanders is critical to the proper harvesting of the resources which include prawns, fish , pearl, rock lobster and certainly trochus. Much could be learned by consultation with local leaders such as Oza Bosun, Nelson Billy, the Chairman of Sue Island, Tabipa Mau, the Chairman at Dauan Island and George Mye, who is already a member of the consultative committee. They can play a constructive role in the future management of fisheries in this area. I know, from personal discussions with those whom I have mentioned as well as other locals, that the future of the region can be assured, but only with controlled and sensible management of the region.

I refer now to the proposed amendment by the Government to the Torres Strait Treaty (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1984.The sole purpose of this amendment is to delete Part III of that Bill. Part III amends the Coral Sea Island Acts 1969 to ensure that the boundaries of the Coral Sea Islands area do not overlap the proposed seabed line under the Torres Strait Treaty. Since the Bill was drafted a further agreement between Australia and the Solomon Islands has been negotiated and the boundaries of the Coral Sea Islands area will, as a result, require further modification. It is now proposed by the Government to amend the Coral Sea Islands Act in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No.1) 1984 to adjust the boundaries of the Coral Sea Islands area to ensure that those boundaries do not infringe any international agreement Australia has entered into or might later enter into.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), paid tribute to many people, including himself as a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, for the part that they played in the initiation of negotiations and the final legislation which is before us. I would just like to say one thing: The initiation of these negotiations was undertaken by none other than Gough Whitlam.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, lines 25 to 37, page 3, lines 1 to 44 and page 4, lines 1 to 36, omit Part III.

Part III of the Torres Strait Treaty (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1984 amends the Coral Sea Islands Act. It proposes altering the description of the line around the islands which constitute the Coral Sea Islands territory to take account of the Torres Strait Treaty and the Maritime Boundary Delimitation Treaty with France in respect of New Caledonia. The line merely defines which islands constitute the Coral Sea Islands territory. The territory does not include the waters between the islands.

The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) has now devised a simplified way of drawing that line. Under his proposal it would not be necessary to redraw the line when the maritime boundary delimitation with the Solomon Islands is finalised. I have, therefore, moved this amendment to the Torres Strait Treaty (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill by the deletion of Part III . The simplified proposal of the Minister for Territories and Local Government will be incorporated instead in the next available Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr West)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 19 October 1983, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 39, page 26, lines 15 and 16, omit ', where it considers it appropriate to do so,'.

As stated by the two speakers for the Opposition-the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who is the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, and the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton)-the Opposition supports this legislation. Basically it is legislation which was brought into being by the efforts of the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) when he was Minister for Foreign Affairs. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) indicated that the initial work was done by a former Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, but really the credit for the finalisation of the legislation quite rightly and properly belongs to the present Leader of the Opposition. We have indicated our support for this legislation.

We believe that some fairly obvious difficulties will be encountered in trying to put the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill into operation. It is true, as previous speakers have indicated, that it is a highly complicated piece of legislation. It fundamentally lays down the conditions under which the Australian, Torres Strait Islander and Papua New Guinean fishermen may operate, along with quantities of catches that may be taken and details of how the catches are to be divided between Australia and Papua New Guinea. The complexity of the legislation can be judged from the conditions that are to apply to Australian islands situated on the Papua New Guinea side of the border. In these cases, any fish caught outside the three-mile perimeter of the islands will be shared 75 per cent by Papua New Guinea and 25 per cent by Australia. Fish caught within the three-mile radius will be shared on a 50-50 basis, but all seabed dwelling species will go 100 per cent to Australia. Therefore, a virtually impossible situation could arise with, for example, a trawler catch which is made up of seabed species as well as fish from other water levels.

It is obvious that the intent of this legislation will be achieved only with the utmost co-operation of all the parties involved. In this respect I have to say that the Opposition has strong reservations about clause 39-I take on board the points made by the honourable member for Leichhardt, but I am not persuaded by his arguments-which indicates a reluctance even to involve the Torres Strait Island members of the Torres Strait Joint Advisory Council established under section 19 of the Torres Strait Treaty which causes us a great deal of concern. We believe that the Bill would be better if the Government accepted our amendment.

We believe that it should be mandatory for the Protected Zone Joint Authority to seek the views of the Joint Advisory Council on all occasions where any matter arises which affects the interests of the traditional Australian inhabitants. As the legislation stands, clause 39 empowers the Authority to do this only where it considers it appropriate to do so. We believe that this is not good enough. Whilst the Bill as a whole is an excellent one, it appears to us that the acceptance of our amendment could make this Bill a far better and more practical one.

The Opposition commends the right expressed in the Treaty of traditional inhabitants of both countries to undertake traditional fishing in the protected zone with a minimum of regulation and restriction, but there must be full and mandatory consultation. The effect of our amendment will guarantee the consultation which this Bill must provide if it is to work. I urge the Government to accept the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment. The text of the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill was arrived at after extensive negotiations with Queensland. Clause 39 was drafted in its present form on the understanding that the Joint Advisory Council would be consulted only on broad policy issues affecting the traditional inhabitants and on important matters which could not be easily resolved by other consultative processes. It was never intended that the three Islander members of the Joint Advisory Council be consulted on day to day fisheries management matters handled by the Protected Zone Joint Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment would oblige the Joint Authority to consult the three Islander members of the Joint Advisory Council about every matter which the Joint Authority was considering that was likely to affect the Australian traditional inhabitants. Given the role of the Joint Advisory Council, this would be clearly impractical. The Joint Authority has power under clause 40(7) to establish advisory groups, the membership of which may include Islander and commercial fishing industry representatives. It is envisaged that this will be the principal mechanism through which Islanders will be able to express their views to the Joint Authority on detailed fisheries management issues.

Commonwealth and Queensland officials are already consulting with members of a consultative group formed by the Islanders themselves to discuss management of protected zone fisheries whether for traditional fishing or for commercial fishing. A similar consultative group exists for the commercial fishing industry . It is planned to continue and build on these consultative arrangements once the Joint Authority commences operating, to ensure that the interests of the Islanders and the commercial fishing industry are properly recognised and catered for. It is, therefore, necessary to leave clause 39 in its present form as it would be clearly inappropriate for the Protected Zone Joint Authority to consult the Joint Advisory Council on every matter under consideration by the Authority. For those reasons the Government cannot accept the amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr West)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Judiciary Amendment Bill 1984 is a Bill to amend the Judiciary Act 1903. Honourable members will be aware that the Judiciary Act is one of the important and foundational legislative provisions of this country, dealing as it does with such important matters as the original and appellate jurisdictions of the High Court, the jurisdiction and powers of the High Court generally and the removal of causes and other matters relating to the functions of the High Court. Of course, it is not restricted to that court but it is, shall we say, the charter subject to the Constitution which sets out how the Court is to conduct its business and what are the matters that come before the Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Other matters of great importance are provided for in the Judiciary Act but I will not spend any time on those matters. I simply wish to make clear how important that Act is. We now have an amendment to the Judiciary Act. That amendment is made for a specific purpose. The purpose is to make as sure as possible that legal proceedings-that is criminal proceedings-brought in respect of what is known as the Sheraton Hotel raid are brought in a way and proceeded with in a way which protects the identity of those involved. The persons involved in that raid are well known in the sense that we know as a result of Mr Justice Hope's report into that incident that the persons concerned were members of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. We know the functions of that organisation are primarily the collection of foreign intelligence. Another function specified for that organisation is the maintenance of covert action capability for war time or other very special situations.

It is because of the very special nature of the organisation, the very special nature of the task that members of that organisation have entrusted to them and the high risks that even membership of that organisation entails that Mr Justice Hope recommended that the names of those involved in the Sheraton Hotel raid be not disclosed. I am glad to say that the Government has accepted Mr Justice Hope 's recommendation. This brings me to the reason for the Bill which is now before the House. As I have indicated the purpose of that Bill is to ensure that in the prosecutions which are apparently to take place as a result of that raid- prosecutions for breach of Victorian criminal law-the names of the ASIS employees are not disclosed. I should have thought that that would be something that all honourable members would agree should not happen. That, of course, is the reason why the Bill is before the House. An agreement has been reached with the Victorian Government and complementary legislation is to be passed by that Government. The provisions of the Bill have been explained to the House in the second reading speech but I will spend one or two minutes going over them again.

Effectively, what the Bill does is provide that, in the case of criminal proceedings arising out of the Sheraton Hotel raid, the court before which those proceedings are being heard-on the grounds that the making of an order is desirable in the interests of the national or international security of Australia or in the interests of the physical safety of the accused, or of a witness or of any other person-can, when it is of that view, make a number of orders the effect of which is to prevent the publication of material relating to the trial. Those orders include an order that the proceedings are to take place in a closed hearing; an order that a person, or a specified class of persons, is to be excluded from the whole of the proceedings or from part of the proceedings ; an order prohibiting or restricting the disclosure of information with respect to the whole of the proceedings or part of the proceedings; an order prohibiting or restricting the publication of a report of or relating to the whole or part of the proceedings; an order for the purposes of ensuring that no person without the approval of the court has access, whether before, during or after the hearing of the proceedings, to any indictment, affidavit, exhibit or other document used in the proceedings or to the record of the court relating to the proceedings; or an order combining any two or more of the kinds of orders to which I have referred.

Orders of that kind are most unusual in our society because it is of great importance-it is a general rule-that courts should be open to the public so that the public can see how justice is administered and so that the public can form its own views and make its own criticisms. Of course, here we are dealing with very special matters. No one is above the law. That must be so if our society is to exist as a democracy. Despite what is written by novelists such as Le Carre and Len Deighton-I say in passing that I am an addict to the works of both of those novelists-about secret organisations which may commit crimes against the law of this country and within the borders of this country, such organisations do not exist, nor should they exist, even though I am bound to say that the kinds of organisations of which Le Carre and Deighton write make life more interesting if one is relaxing in the evening. But it is a bedrock assumption that one assumes that no man is beyond the law, that no person is so high or so powerful that the law cannot reach that person down, put him into the dock and deal with him. So it should be.

In the case of this Bill what is assumed is that orders will be made by the court hearing criminal proceedings in Victoria relating to the Sheraton Hotel raid. Of course, once complementary legislation is passed in Victoria, the court then having those powers within Victoria, a breach of an order made by the court would be subject to contempt proceedings by that court. As anybody knows who has had to argue for anybody on the receiving end of contempt proceedings, such proceedings can be very unpleasant indeed. Such a person can go to gaol or can be heavily fined.

How is the order made by the Victorian court to be given effect to within the Commonwealth: that is, outside Victoria? Here we come to the purpose of the present Bill. Under the present Bill the Federal Court is given power to punish a contravention of an order made by the Victorian court as if a contravention or a failure to obey that order had been a contravention or a failure to obey an order made by the Federal Court. Effectively the Federal Court is to take over the role outside Victoria of implementing orders made by the Victorian court. That is good so far as it goes, subject always to the consideration that our courts as a general rule should be open. But there are very special reasons in this case why the criminal proceedings that are contemplated by the Victorian Government should not result in the disclosure of the names of the accused persons-by reason of the very special tasks that those persons carry out.

I do appreciate that there are people in our society who believe that all intelligence organisations should be banned, and indeed some who believe that we should set a moral example to the rest of the world, including Soviet Russia, and that if we set a moral example and ban intelligence organisations and if other Western countries set moral examples and, for example, disarm unilaterally , the Soviet Union, which is highly regarded for its commitment to moral principles, will take heed and act accordingly.

The graveyards of Russia are filled with moral examples. Stalin has put a good many millions of people there and so have his successors in title. So let us not get ourselves into the fairyland of believing that we live in a world which we do not live in. The world we live in, pleasant though it may be for many of us, pleasant though it is for people who sit around the House and engage in the kindly and comradely debates which characterise the way in which this House works, pleasant though it may be for the majority of people in this country, is for many harsh, brutal and brief. If we do not have the ways and means of maintaining our own security and if the West does not have the ways and means of maintaining its security the kind of parliament that we have will become an artifact of the past.

Let us therefore start from the proposition-I am glad this Government does-that those who were concerned in the raid, no matter how stupid, ill-conceived and perfectly bizarre it may have been, should be protected from disclosure as members of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. How does the Government propose to deal with that matter? It has the Bill which is presently before the House, which is a one-off proposal. It differs from the proposal which was originally planned to be introduced by the Victorian Government and by this Parliament in that it applies only to the Sheraton raid. I have heard it said that it applies only to the Sheraton raid because of the amendments proposed by the Liberal Party of Australia in the Victorian Parliament.

I read that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in another place said that this was merely indicative of the fact that the Liberal Party could not get its act together. I thought that was a good collectivist viewpoint. We in the Liberal Party are not collectivists; we do have different views on different matters, particularly on how justice should be administered and particularly on whether there are considerations for a one-off Bill or a Bill which has more general application.

There are, I should have thought, sound reasons for introducing a Bill which has more than a one-off application. Indeed, these reasons were referred to by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), who presented to this House the second reading speech which was, of course, the same as the second reading speech given by the Attorney-General in the other place. He referred to a number of provisions of Acts of Parliament, both here and elsewhere, which have the effect of giving confidentiality to proceedings where, in the public interest, in the national interest or because of other and most compelling reasons, such as the need to safeguard the life of a witness, it was thought that restraints should be placed on the general rule that proceedings before courts should be open.

The Attorney-General referred to the Official Secrets Act of the United Kingdom , to section 85B of the Crimes Act 1914 and to section 50 of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976. Yet we have this somewhat bizarre proposal that this Bill should be restricted to one incident only. We do not believe that that is the proper way to approach this question. Whilst, as I have said, it is essential that as a general rule courts should be open, it is also obviously necessary that there must be exceptions to that rule. Those exceptions are best expressed in terms such as the terms which are expressed here, limited in general principle as they are to cases in which the security of Australia-whether in national or international terms-is in question, or cases in which the physical safety of the accused or of a witness or of any other person is in question. With those sorts of limitations on the ability to exercise the power reposed in the court, the decision must be made as to whether limitations of varying kinds should be placed on the access that can be given to the material before the courts, on the publication of that material or on other matters relating generally to what we might call an open or closed court system. It is bizarre and unnecessary to have a one-off proposal, particularly when one recalls that this proposal will go into the Judiciary Act. We have the quite extraordinary circumstance that that Act will be cluttered up with a separate part dealing with one incident. There is no reason to think that at other times there may not be other reasons for adopting a line such as that which the Government has adopted in this case. What are we going to have then? Are we going to have another Bill? Are we going to have separate Bills to deal with separate issues? Would it not be better, as I have said, to lay down the rules and to leave it to the courts to administer them? For those who do not trust the courts, let me ask : If we do not trust the courts to administer the law, who is going to administer the law? No one.

Whilst I would be the last person to say that courts are always right-indeed I have been convinced of the wrongness of courts when my arguments have not been accepted-I would always be in the forefront of those who say that courts are the bedrock of our constitutional existence and of the democratic principles in which we all believe, although perhaps we would give effect to them in somewhat different ways according to our different political beliefs.

Another problem with this Bill is that it is sunset legislation; it will expire two years after its commencement. I wonder whether those who drafted the Bill have ever had anything to do with criminal proceedings. Let me tell honourable members something about criminal proceedings. People do not like being convicted of crimes. That is the first point. The second point is that people who are convicted of crimes like even less the prospect of spending time breaking rocks in gaol. The third point is that their lawyers seek to make sure that they do not spend time breaking rocks in gaol, and frequently appeal. What could happen here is that criminal proceedings could be brought in the Victorian Supreme Court, or whichever court in Victoria would have jurisdiction in the case of the offences that are alleged against the ASIS operatives, and that trial could take quite a while. If any of the accused were convicted, unreasonable though we may think it to be, they might decide to appeal because they do not want to go to gaol.

My experience has been that most people do not want to go to gaol. That appeal would go to the Victorian court of appeal and in special circumstances it could go to the High Court. The hearing of the proceedings could take a long time. It could take over two years before a final decision is given, by which time this Bill will have expired and the Government will have to come back to the Parliament with a new Bill to deal with precisely the same incident. If there is to be a fresh trial, as sometimes takes place as a result of appeals in criminal cases, I suppose we will have a new set of proceedings and this Part, in any event, would no longer be on foot. So it would be very much wiser, perhaps, if the draftsman had not been so attracted by sunset legislation-that very fashionable concept-and had thought through the consequences of a criminal trial of the kind that we are thinking about, of the kind that this Bill assumes. The Opposition, while it supports the Bill, does not support the limitation to which I have referred. An amendment will be circulated in my name which we will put to the House.

There are one or two other matters that I would like to ask the Minister to give his attention to when he deals with the matter in the Committee stage.
