It is the Government's intention that there should be no disclosure of the names of the ASIS operatives. That intention is sought to be given effect to by this Bill . There are, I believe, members of the Victorian legislature who take the view that there should be no such animal as ASIS and that the names of ASIS operatives should not be kept confidential. I may be wrong in that belief, but I do believe there are members of the Victorian legislature of that view. Is it the intention of the Government, therefore, in pursuit of its objective to safeguard the identities of its own employees that this Bill, when it becomes an Act, should also apply to members of the Victorian legislature? If it is not, of course, it is open to members of that legislature to breach with impunity the intent of this Bill and to reveal to the world at large the identities of the ASIS operatives through the medium of the forum of Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest newspapers from the United Kingdom in the Parliamentary Library have a very startling front page story that a young typist in the Civil Service was gaoled for six months for handing to the Guardian newspaper documents relating to the arrival of cruise missiles in the United Kingdom. The severity of the sentence has created quite a sensation in that country. But this question of security is a problem for all Western democracies. I was impressed by some comments made in the Franks Report of the Committee on Section 2 of the Official Secrets Act 1911 which was presented to the United Kingdom Parliament in September 1972. In particular, in the chapter dealing with secrecy in its wider context, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: A totalitarian government finds it easy to maintain secrecy.
The report continues:

A democratic government, however, though it must compete with these other types of organisation, has a task which is complicated by its obligations to the people. It needs the trust of the governed. It cannot use the plea of secrecy to hide from the people its basic aims. On the contrary it must explain these aims: it must provide the justification for them and give the facts both for and against a selected course of action. Nor must such information be provided only at one level and through one means of communication. A government which pursues secret aims, or which operates in greater secrecy than the effective conduct of its proper functions requires, or which turns information services into propaganda agencies, will lose the trust of the people.

I think that this small extract from the Franks report epitomises the dilemma which this Government faced after the unfortunate and rather extraordinary incident at the Sheraton Hotel in Melbourne on 30 November 1983. The Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his second reading speech spoke about the exercise. He did not mention the fact that there has been a generous settlement to the hotel. By the end of his second reading speech the Minister had made it quite clear that the Government was acting on the advice of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) which has been confirmed by Mr Justice Hope, the Royal Commissioner.

The Judiciary Amendment Bill took me back to a basic legal text which is studied by all students of law in our nation; that is, the Introduction to the Study of the Law of the Constitution by A.V. Dicey. Under the section on 'the rule of law', Dicey makes this point:
. . . every man, whatever be his rank or condition, is subject to the ordinary law of the realm and amenable to the jurisdiction of the ordinary tribunals.

What is proposed today in the Bill before the House is to make the employees of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service not subject to the ordinary law of the realm. Those people will have the advantage of a possible order suppressing publication of their names. Dicey's work stresses also the notion of freedom of the Press, the right of the Press to publish information, to publish without fear or favour. It is, of course, the Press that will be restricted from publishing any of the material that is put before the court, particularly in relation to the defendants' names and addresses, if an order is made. The difficulty with this point, for me, is that many of my constituents who have been brought before petty sessions courts have, to their distress, found their names published in a local paper. I am told that in country areas of Australia local newspapers regularly publish names of, perhaps, first offenders who have been convicted, even if they have been put on a bond, or persons who are involved in coronial inquiries.

In New South Wales there was an Act known as the Female First Offenders Act which prevented the publication of the names of female first offenders. That legislation, in our age of equality, was repealed. But there is a tradition that justice must not only be done but also must be seen to be done.

One can understand that justice can be seen to be done only if the names and, perhaps, addresses of persons charged with and convicted of offences are available to the public and for public scrutiny. The Bill will enable the court, the presiding magistrate or judge to make an order for a closed court for a number of reasons to exclude persons from the hearing, to prohibit the disclosure of information, and so forth. It is set out in some detail in the Bill and also the points were canvassed by the Minister in his second reading speech.

The legislation has a sunset clause-an unfortunate term-which means that it expires after two years. It is a one-off situation. The Opposition opposes this notion. It is the Government's intention to ask the House to reject the amendment proposed by the Opposition. It is the Government's belief that there will be no repetition of the unfortunate incident which occurred in the Sheraton Hotel. There is no earlier precedent. The previous Government was never called upon to bring in any such legislation. We trust that the good sense and the maturity of our security personnel and of the people running security services in Australia will carry the day.

Another reason for rejecting the amendment is that the Victorian Government has co-operated on the basis of the legislation that is before the House now, and not on some sort of amended legislation which the Opposition is bringing forward in this chamber today. The security services in our nation are under review and under very close scrutiny. I trust that the House will reject the amendment proposed by the Opposition.

In my opinion there is a great need for security services in our land. Unfortunately, in recent years we have had many international terrorist acts brought to our doorstep. We all remember with sadness the assassination of the Turkish Ambassador in our country. We remember with horror the Hilton bombing and the bombing of the Israeli Embassy. Not so very long ago a fire burnt out a Lebanese newspaper and printing press in Sydney. Over the years there have been many instances of para-military organisations forming in this country, of groups training for all sorts of armed insurrection, mainly overseas. Some were groups without any real threat to society such as the New Guard, an organisation in Sydney which was opposed to Jack Lang, a former well-known Labor Premier. Fortunately this organisation was composed of and led by people with good sense and nothing untoward happened. But unfortunately other organisations have existed in our country and their activities have resulted in criminal proceedings, prosecutions and convictions.

Our Asian neighbours, the countries in our region which look to Australia for precedents, advice and guidelines, are watching how we handle the embarrassing crisis and problem which arose out of the ASIS affair. These nations, these new countries on our doorstep-some of which I visited last year as a member of a parliamentary delegation-have a real problem in developing their own security services, services which are not working at the behest of any particular political party but in the interests of the people and of the parliament. These nations are watching how this Government handles this situation. I believe that they will certainly be impressed by the fact that the Government is bringing in this legislation for a short period only to protect the personnel who were involved in the raid.

An order of the court to suppress the names of the personnel involved may be made for a number of very desirable reasons. One is, of course, that the order is made in the interests of the national or international security of Australia. Another ground on which an order may be made suppressing the names of the personnel involved is the interests of the physical safety of the accused. That is of great significance to me. If, by publication of the names of people who are charged and convicted of some offence, it means that their lives may be at risk or their physical safety may be threatened, I think that is a very good reason for restricting the publication of such material. There are other reasons set forth in the Bill, but the main reasons are that the national and international security of our nation may be at risk.

The Opposition wishes to have this section of the Judiciary Amendment Bill, when it is passed and included in the Act, retained there for posterity. There have been instances which we can all remember where national security was dealt with on a basis of hysteria. One needs only to look back to the time before 1972 , when the Labor Opposition was pressing for independence in Papua New Guinea, at the quite extraordinary attitude taken by the Government of the day in relation to that matter, and at the accusations made against the Labor Opposition at that time-although they were always cloaked in the respectability of concern for national security-that we were acting in an irresponsible way. Of course, with the viability of Papua New Guinea and the emergence of this very strong, independent nation, it has been shown that the Australian Labor Party was right in relation to giving independence to that land and that there was no threat to national security. But it is an area in which there was hysteria. I believe that it is a reason why this legislation should be able to fade away after two years.

The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) made the point that members of the Victorian Parliament will not be bound by the legislation and may mention the names of the accused in the Victorian Parliament. Be that as it may, that is caught up in the complicated problems which arise from the original Bill of Rights which gave parliamentarians the right to freedom of speech. Victoria is a sovereign State and has a sovereign Parliament. For my part, I cannot see how this Parliament can ever restrain a member of the Victorian Parliament from exercising his or her freedom of speech in parliament. The various solicitors- general in New South Wales and in the Commonwealth have been debating this matter backwards and forwards, but it is an issue in which one trusts that good sense and fair play will apply, particularly as Mr Justice Hope and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) have said that there are some very serious reasons why these names should be suppressed. The Bill proposes that these reasons must be for the protection of the national or international security of Australia or in the interests of the physical safety of the accused. One trusts that members of parliament will take cognisance of these reasons.

The legislation draws attention to the whole problem of freedom of information, the problems of secrecy within the Public Service and, for me, the very important suggestions made in recent publications by Richard Hall, the well- known writer, about the need for Parliament to scrutinise the running of our security services and for these services to be subject to supervision by a standing committee of the Parliament, as happens in the United States of America . However that is somewhat outside the scope of this legislation. I am pleased to support the legislation and call upon the House to reject the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The consequences flowing from what is now called the 'Sheraton Hotel raid' on 30 November last year are many and varied, not the least for those trainees who took part and their supervisors and the then head of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, John Ryan. More pertinently it has raised a number of questions of law and of security for this Parliament to concern itself with. It appears to me that the issue is a fairly simple one and can be succinctly summarised. The issue is that there is no question whatsoever that nobody is above the law. Should the Victorian Attorney-General accept that a prima facie case has been made against those who participated on 30 November, they ought to face a court. It is not for this Parliament, just as it is not for the Victorian Attorney-General, to determine their guilt or otherwise. But it is a matter for the Attorney-General whether or not they should first face court. The question then becomes whether or not their names ought to be made public in the normal course of events. That is the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat: The issue is whether or not, in the interests of national security and foreign relations, those who participated in the ASIS raid ought to have their names broadcast throughout this country and, of course, known to interested persons and agencies in other countries. Therefore, I join with the Parliament in supporting this legislation which will have the effect of allowing the Victorian Attorney-General to apply for an order at a subsequent court hearing that all or part of the proceedings be held in camera. Of course, I hasten to add that it is not a decision of the Attorney-General or the Parliament that the proceedings be held in camera. They may apply for an order.

The legislation before the House will amend the Judiciary Act 1903 to make valid Victorian legislation which will provide that either the Commonwealth Attorney-General or the Victorian Attorney-General may apply for an order that all or part of the proceedings be held in camera so that the names of the arraigned persons not be made public. In essence the Bill makes it an offence enforceable in the Federal Court for a person not to comply with an order made by any court on national security grounds either on the basis that the proceedings be held in closed session or on the basis that the publication of information or evidence concerning those present during the proceedings be prohibited. The Bill, when enacted, will cease to have effect after two years.

As I said earlier, nobody is above the law and the issue is not whether those who participated in the Sheraton Hotel raid ought to appear before a court. It is whether or not those persons' names should be a matter of public record. There are a number of precedents both overseas and in Australia for a parliament enacting legislation which will allow the presiding court to determine whether or not names ought to be made public. In the United Kingdom there is the Official Secrets Act 1920. In Australia we have section 85B of the Crimes Act 1904 which gives judges and magistrates within the Federal jurisdiction power to make orders similar to those in the Bill before the House this morning. Furthermore, we also have within the Federal jurisdiction section 50 of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 which gives that Court the power at any time during or even after the hearing to make orders forbidding the publication of evidence or the names of any party or witness.

So, this Parliament has on prior occasions concerned itself with the question of confidentiality of proceedings in a court. Clearly it is a difficult matter, and a matter which the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), the previous speaker, raised. He gave examples from his electorate of petty offenders, to use the vernacular, having their names published in the local newspaper, thereby suffering on many occasions great social embarrassment and even humiliation. As a solicitor in a country area prior to entering the Parliament, I appeared many times within the Magistrates Court jurisdiction and often found that my clients' names were published in local newspapers. Of course, I suggest that the consequences of that are far more severe in many cases for rural dwellers than for urban dwellers because rural communities are far more closely knit and rural people tend to show more interest in the affairs of their neighbours.

It was always my belief that the public humiliation was regrettable and in many cases far outweighed the penalty for the offence the person committed. Most distressing were the occasions when young people who may have been placed on a bond by the court for a criminal offence had their names published, even though being placed on a good behaviour bond has the effect of wiping the record clean if no further matter is brought before the court. That was always a matter of concern to me.

As a matter of philosophy I support on balance the principle that the Press have open and free access to courts. It is a matter for the Press, not the courts, to decide whether or not it is believed that the publication of names in the normal course of events is far too severe a censure. However, that is not the case here because at stake here are issues of national security and indeed issues which go to the very heart of our foreign relations. For that reason it is proper and correct that this Parliament concern itself with the question of whether to introduce confidentiality proceedings in regard to the ASIS raid.

Certainly Justice Hope in his report on the Sheraton Hotel incident concludes that the names of those participants ought not to be revealed. He based that finding on his assessment of the consequences for foreign relations and national security which would inevitably follow from the publication of their names. He relied in part on a statement from the Foreign Affairs Department about such consequences. However, we do not have the advantage of perusing that statement as it has not been published. Justice Hope again decided that not to publish it would far outweigh the advantages to be gained from its publication.

Furthermore, we may make a judgment as to the behaviour of the participants on that night but we do not make an assessment of their guilt or otherwise. That is properly a matter for the courts. For instance, Justice Hope accepts that a certain amount of realism in an exercise such as was undertaken is desirable, but of course he concludes that excesses in conduct committed during the exercise were attributable to the desire to achieve greater realism. He further finds that that desire to achieve greater realism was not reasonable and exceeded the bounds of desirability.

Justice Hope isolates four separate incidents in which the striving for realism went too far: Firstly, the breaking of the hotel door with a sledgehammer; secondly, the attempt to restrain the hotel manager who wandered on to the exercise; thirdly, the carriage of arms by three of the trainees; fourthly, the display of those arms to the people on the ground floor of the hotel when the trainees were escaping. Indeed, I quote from Justice Hope's report. He finds thus:

The worst feature of the incident was the threatening of the people in the hotel foyer and kitchen with the guns carried by the trainees. This part of the incident was unintended and occurred when the trainees were confronted with an unexpected situation and were without their leader.

I have no hesitation in joining with Justice Hope in finding that the behaviour was unreasonable and offended against acceptable community standards of how we expect our security forces to behave when undertaking exercises within our own country. But guilt is a matter for the courts, and I am somewhat concerned by some of the public statements that have followed from that incident whereby it is assumed already that those participants are guilty at law. They certainly are not.

I have some further concerns following the incident. I refer specifically to the inflated remarks made by Senator Primmer in the other place in regard to the then head of ASIS, Mr John Ryan. His remarks on Mr Ryan were savage and inflammatory and offended against any standard which a member of this Parliament ought to adopt. It was one of the worst examples, and I unhesitatingly condemn the senator for those cowardly and unjustified remarks. I go so far as to suggest that most members of this place would join with me in that criticism.

The members of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service are, of course, concerned with compiling intelligence. The importance of their role can hardly be overstated. We live in an uncertain world. Whether we like it or not, that is a fact, and there is a need at all times to ensure security. These people at many times work under a degree of high risk and make a number of personal sacrifices. They therefore deserve this Government's support and the Parliament' s support wherever possible. That is not to say that at any stage I or members of the Opposition would suggest that they are above the law and ought not to be brought before the courts if a prima facie case of their breaching Australian laws can be made out. That is certainly not the argument. The argument is that because of the nature of their work and because of the consequences which would flow from their names being made public, this legislation introducing confidentiality provisions into the Judiciary Act ought to be permitted to proceed. I am concerned that the names of those participants may be revealed in the Victorian Parliament. I would condemn that. I would advise those who are considering the matter against that course of action in the strongest possible terms. Mr Justice Hope and the Department of Foreign Affairs have concluded that Australia's interests and national security would be injured by that course of action.

The role of ASIS and other security organisations is a matter of debate within the Australian Labor Party at present and is certain to become a heated issue at the July conference. I suggest that members of the Labor Party take into account and remember at all times the acts of terrorism which have occurred in Australia over the past few years and which have involved loss of life and extensive damage to property. I refer, of course, to the tragic events of the Hilton bombing, the assassination of a Turkish diplomat, and the recent bombing of the Israeli diplomatic office. The Government must at all times bear in mind that Australia is not isolated from the ever-increasing problem of terrorism throughout the world, terrorism which seeks to make unstable and to render less effective the working democracies of the Western world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Judiciary Amendment Bill and to oppose the amendments. It always gives me pleasure in a debate to speak after the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) because I always appreciate the care with which he produces his arguments. I was very surprised to hear his confession this morning that he loses some cases.
—We do have some misguided judges.

—I see. We have some interests in common, because apparently we both enjoy Le Carre. But I am sure that the honourable member for North Sydney would agree with me that Le Carre would find it very difficult to produce a scenario as weird and as unusual as that which unfolded in November last year at the Sheraton Hotel. It is because of that episode that this Bill is now before the House. The Bill is designed to amend the Judiciary Act 1903 to provide for the enforcement throughout Australia of orders for confidentiality in relation to certain criminal proceedings made by Victorian courts on grounds relating to the national or international security of Australia. As has been mentioned by other speakers, the Bill has a sunset clause which limits its application to a period of two years. I shall attempt to answer the arguments put up by the amendments as to whether or not the Bill should be a one-off measure or should have general application.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been pointed out by previous speakers, this Bill is the direct result of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service fiasco which occurred on 30 Novembr 1983. Without going into the details of that disgraceful and apparently expensive operation-as those have already been outlined by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran)-it is clear that that operation should never have been allowed. But it is because of that operation, as I said earlier, that the Bill provides a back-up for Victorian legislation, and that legislation is designed to enable in camera hearings in relation to the charges arising from the episode.
The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), in his second reading speech, stated, inter alia:

On the advice of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, confirmed by Mr Justice Hope , the Government considers that there are very strong grounds for believing that the publication of the names of some, if not all, of these persons in the ordinary course of criminal proceedings, would be prejudicial to the national or international security of Australia.

As a person concerned, over a number of years, with civil liberties, I find myself supporting this Bill with, I must confess, a certain degree of reluctance . However, this reluctance has been lessened with the appreciation that the Bill is limited in scope and limited in time. The term 'court' is limited to meaning a court of Victoria and includes a judge, a magistrate or a justice of the peace of such a court. The Bill is also limited in time by the sunset clause to two years. Mr Justice Hope in his report, at paragraph 6.6 on page 70, stated inter alia:

Special problems arise in relation to the disclosure of the name of the persons involved in the Sheraton Hotel incident which are the subject of additional considerations. During the course of my inquiry the Department of Foreign Affairs provided me with a statement about the consequences for foreign relations and national security of disclosure of the names.

He then went on to say that the consequences were summarised in appendix VI. Unfortunately, that appendix VI is not for general publication. Like so many other members, I do not know the reasons which were outlined to support the arguments for suppression. Mr Justice Hope was obviously satisfied that the disclosure of the names would be likely to have the consequences claimed by the Department. It is quite clear that he made an examination of the possible breaches of laws which may be applicable to this instant but has taken the view that any decision on prosecution should rest with the appropriate responsible authorities. Of course, the appropriate responsible authorities happen to be the Victorian legal authorities. As a result, on 29 February 1984 the Victorian Government introduced into the State Parliament the Criminal Proceedings Bill 1984. This Bill proposes to specifically empower the courts of that State to make certain orders for confidentiality in relation to criminal proceedings arising out of the Sheraton Hotel incident.

The Judiciary Amendment Bill complements the legislation, as I will explain in my subsequent comments. It is important to note that section 85B of the Commonwealth Crimes Act, as was pointed out by the honourable member for Gippsland, provides that in proceedings before a Federal court or a court exercising Federal jurisdiction an order may be made prohibiting publication of the whole or a specified part of the proceedings. Offences involving national security personnel in their capacity as such would most usually be expected to contravene Federal legislation. What is unique about the Sheraton Hotel incident is that criminal proceedings under Victorian State law raised national security considerations. Thus, whilst the Victorian Government can legislate to permit State courts to make a confidentiality order on those grounds, this is binding only within the State of Victoria. This is the raison d'etre for the legislation presently before the House.

I have mentioned section 85B of the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914 as having powers similar to those being sought in this Bill. There are other precedents. For example, the United Kingdom Official Secrets Act 1920 has been used by British governments of different political views in some of the more major treason trials in Britain. Of course, there is an argument between those who believe that criminal proceedings involving issues of security should be heard under the protection of comprehensive secrecy provisions and that such provisions should be part of the law, and those who argue that if we have to have confidentiality it should be confined to the particular case. There are also those who argue that confidentiality should be avoided at all costs. The honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) and the honourable member for Gippsland have rightly pointed out the adverse effect, from their own experience, of the publication of names of people appearing in the lower courts.

Whilst I can understand and sympathise with the arguments of those who adopt the latter position-that is, that confidentiality should be avoided at all costs -it is a position which cannot be sustained. We all know that there are occasions when confidentiality is appropriate. This is recognised in both the juvenile and the Family Court jurisdictions in Australia. I consider that the case of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service fiasco, however, comes within the area in which confidentiality must be observed because of the national and, apparently, the international significance behind the disclosure of the names.

It is therefore appropriate to indicate to the House that whilst I have some reservations about the purport of the Bill I do not think that the amendments will meet the purpose that they are intended to serve. The argument has been put by the honourable member for North Sydney that the sunset clause will create some confusion. He has rightly pointed out to the House that this can be brought about because of the lengthy time delays that occur in the processes of law. But this, I argue, is not a case for throwing out the baby with the bath water. The important objective of this Bill is to protect the names of those who could suffer as a result of the divulging of those names. Therefore I support the Bill and oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for their contribution. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), in leading for the Opposition, raised the question of the position of members of the Victorian Parliament if they named Australian Secret Intelligence Service participants in that Parliament. It is a very appropriate question and it cannot be easily answered. One has to rely on the aspect of national security. It would be quite outrageous if a member of parliament did it just for the sake of doing it, thereby jeopardising both security and the lives of the individuals involved. That is how serious the matter is. In other words, it is not just a matter of a member of parliament having the unfettered right to say what he thinks. Nobody would deny that a member of parliament has that right , but he does not have the unfettered right to guarantee that somebody else loses his life. I do not think that that can be accepted. Nevertheless, Parliament being what it is, what has happened is a very exceptional case.

SPEECH.PARA: In fairness to the honourable member for North Sydney, who raised the issue, I am reminded that recently this matter was raised in the South Australian Parliament. Apparently, a joint opinion was obtained from the Federal Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Solicitor-General. The matter that the honourable gentleman has raised is perhaps a weakness in the Bill. I am advised that the acting Crown Solicitor stated that the present Bill would appear not to affect the privilege of State parliaments but cautioned that because of the complexity and uncertainty of the constitutional issues it is not possible to be categorical on this point. There is the view that once the individuals are named it is a bit late to try to test it; it would be too late for the safety of the people involved and the security of the nation. The opinion given last year states:

Certainly, if Federal law is to have such an application, the power supporting it would need to be commensurate with its effect. One example of how Federal law might have an overriding effect in the context of matters prejudicial to the defence and safety of the country in times of war;
and, I would read into that, in times of peace where national security and the safety of personnel are involved-

in our view a law which forbade a person, whether in Parliament or not, to make public the position of a convoy at sea and thereby to expose those manning it to the risk of death by enemy action, would be a valid law.

So we get a balance in that a defence power may be extended to cover all exigencies. In summary, the opinion states that section 49 of the Constitution requires an express declaration for legislation to affect the privilege of the Commonwealth Parliament. No such declaration is in this Bill. Even so, this does not negate the possible effect on State parliamentary privilege. However, given the conclusion of the case which was the subject of the opinion, I feel that although the parliamentarian might not be affected, the media could be.

That might be where we can leave that matter. I am advised that during the second reading debate the honourable member for North Sydney said that the two- year sunset period was too short for a possible retrial and appeal. I am advised that this period reflects the provision of the Victorian legislation. The judgment is primarily a matter for the Victorian Parliament. The proceedings are , after all, Victorian proceedings. Again the honourable gentleman argued that the Judiciary Act is of general application and that the amendments are out of place in the Bill. I am advised that the Act is a general one. The view of the Attorney-General is that that in itself is no reason for not making special provision because this is such an exceptional case. I thank the honourable gentleman for his contribution. I think we now need to go into Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 2, line 5-8, omit from the definition of 'proceedings' all words after 'proceedings' (second occurring).

In moving that amendment I thank the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) for revealing to me that there are many things in common between all of us. In his case it is that we both have an addiction to Le Carre's works. As I have said before, it illustrates that there are more things in common in this Parliament than is sometimes thought.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add myself to that.

—I include the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones). I should also like to thank the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) for what he said in relation to the question raised by me, in particular whether or not these provisions which are presently before us, when enacted, would affect the privileges of the Victorian Parliament. I agree that it is a very difficult question. I agree with the advice which the Deputy Crown Solicitor appears to have given. Not having looked closely at it, but remarking on it as I prepared for this speech, it appeared to me that it would not affect the privileges of the Victorian Parliament because it was not expressed to do so. However, it is an exceedingly difficult constitutional question. Let us hope that it never arises. The Deputy Prime Minister rightly pointed out that it would certainly affect the media. I do not know what arrangements the Victorian Parliament has to broadcast what is said in that Parliament but I suppose that once it goes out over the air it is a little too late to prosecute anybody. Let us hope that that never arises.

SPEECH.PARA: I said in my speech on the second reading much of what I would wish to say on the amendment which is now before the House. We are dealing with a particular instance. Other cases could arise. It seems procedurally odd and rather bizzare to introduce a piece of legislation for one instance on the assumption that that instance merits it, rather than introduce a piece of legislation which deals in principle with the question. After all, it is only if the principles which are embodied in the Judiciary Amendment Bill are thought to apply that orders can be made by a court. Equally, there may be other cases when, for precisely the same reasons-that is, reasons falling within these principles-orders should be made. To introduce a Bill simply to deal with one instance, albeit that the amendment was made at the behest apparently of the Liberal Party of Australia in Victoria, seems to us to be wrong.

We therefore think that the best way of dealing with the question is the way in which I understood the Government originally intended to deal with the question, which was to apply the provisions generally. For the purposes of doing that one would simply amend the provision of the Bill which defines 'proceedings'. One would amend that by leaving out all the words after 'proceedings' where that word secondly occurs. So that the definition of 'proceedings' would simply be: ' Proceedings' means criminal proceedings. Then the Bill, when enacted, would apply to criminal proceedings whether or not they were Sheraton Hotel criminal proceedings or any other kind of proceedings. It would be up to the court to decide whether a case was made out for any form of order under the section. The very fact that an instance has occurred, which the Government rightly accepts as meriting the kind of provision before the House, gives weight to the argument that one should make provision for a general rule; that general rule to be applied by courts on the basis of the particular facts before them. I therefore ask for the amendment in my name to be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is unable to accept the amendment whilst appreciating the spirit in which it is moved. There might be other instances that arise. If the amendment were carried, it would enable those other instances to be encompassed within the ambit of the Judiciary Amendment Bill. The definition of 'proceedings' relates to specific proceedings in a certain place in Victoria on a certain date. Of course, the infringement, if there is any infringement, appears to be of Victorian law. Therefore, we might want to say in the general concept of debate: Why not have it for incidents that might arise in the future? If they did they would be in other States. Those States might still decide to prosecute. I do not think we could affect the situation because it would be under State law.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had the benefit of Victorian co-operation. In other words, the law has to be upheld. But in the concept of national security and the safety of individuals there has to be a prohibition against publication. The Victorians have said that they would accept that. They have passed the appropriate piece of legislation. As the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) knows, members of his own Party in the Victorian Assembly would not accept this amendment. In fact they made it very clear that, unless the definition of the word 'proceedings' was so defined and classified to relate to a specific instance, they would not approve of the Bill. I know that that creates certainly no weight in the Federal Parliament but it creates a lot of weight in terms of what sort of complementary legislation we would expect to get through Victoria. In other words, if we were to lose the Bill in this sense we would be virtually unable to say that we could adhere to the agreement that we made with the Victorian Government on this matter.

Public opinion in Victoria would expect that Government to be doing something about this matter. We, in the national sphere, have the obligation of protecting people helping us in the areas of intelligence and national security. The two should not be readily entwined, but it nevertheless happened in the one case. No doubt if these people were involved in speeding offences or matters of that nature we could not in any way protect their disclosure. But when those people are in our employ we have an obligation. That is where the balance is difficult to assess. I think this Bill does it. It does it with the co-operation of the Victorian Government. It does it with the co-operation of the Victorian Parliament. It does it in the express terms in which the Victorian Parliament has indicated it would approve, and in those terms only.

By added weight, for what it might be worth, I am told that the Australian Democrats in the Senate would not support the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition in this place. I think we are very mindful of the fact that, if there are other instances-we hope that there are not; we urge that there should not be-we would again be placed in a difficult position of having to try to negotiate similar legislation with the State governments. This legislation has a sunset clause in it. We think that is adequate. It is an extraordinary set of circumstances which are unique. Whilst I can appreciate the sentiments expressed by the honourable member for North Sydney in moving this amendment the Government is unable to accept it for the reasons that I have outlined.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; reported adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, three associated measures are to be put before the House this afternoon: the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Bill . I suggest it might suit the convenience of honourable members to debate these Bills cognately, while separate questions will, in the ordinary course of business, naturally have to be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, I shall allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this package of Bills, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Bill, is to provide for the imposition of an additional levy on Bass Strait crude oil and for the collection of the levy, together with the establishment of a trust fund for the purpose of making payments to the refiners of crude oil. The package of Bills is designed to compensate some of the freight costs or the northern oil refiners of crude oil from Bass Strait by re-allocating some of the freight allowance of 36c per barrel attaching to that product from the southern or Victorian refiners to the northern refiners. This is to be done by imposing a levy on Bass Strait oil equal to 20c per barrel. The revenue will be placed in a trust fund and redistributed amongst all the refiners on a basis which takes into account the cost of transporting the crude oil from Western Port to the various refineries.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this formula the southern refiners will receive a lower amount of the freight allowance than previously while the northern refiners will receive additional assistance. There is not expected to be any change to Commonwealth revenue apart from the extra administrative costs.

Whilst the members on this side of the House will not be opposing the passage of these Bills, we are concerned about a number of aspects to which I would like to draw the attention of the House. As a brief background to my comments I would explain that the nearest refinery to the Bass Strait fields, Western Port in Victoria, does not have the capacity to refine all the crude oil from those fields. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Unemployment-Ferntree Gully and District Welfare Association for the Intellectually Handicapped-Proposed Overseas Trading Corporation-Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-Hawke Labor Government: Youth Policy-Sydney Airport-Australian Industry: Restructuring

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in the grievance debate on this day I rise to grieve on behalf of Australia's unemployed. I do so as an employer of unskilled, unemployed young people. Events this week have tended to focus attention on the plight of Australia's unemployed. The action of the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), whether rightly or wrongly motivated, has helped people to be more aware than ever of the unemployed in this otherwise fair city. I noted that the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) in a notice of motion yesterday, drew the attention of the House to the fact that unemployment is a major issue confronting the Australian community, that, so he claimed, the Government has successfully pursued policies designed to deal with that issue and that unemployment is a major social tragedy for many Australians. Most significantly of all this week, the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), said:

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment breaks people morally, it breaks them physically, it breaks them intellectually, it breaks up families and it brings about massive poverty.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you will find in this House bipartisan agreement for the unfortunate truth that unemployment does indeed poison people, it erodes their sense of citizenship and it is a soul destroying disease.

I rise because I am concerned that we have failed to date to have open debate on this issue in this House. Apart from inferences and comments made in matters of public importance by the Opposition, the matter has not been fairly aired. One could almost accuse the Government of having avoided debate on this issue if one considers that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), when last he had an opportunity to deal with youth employment in introducing the Commonwealth rebate for apprentice full-time training scheme, did so through a 'Dear Dorothy Dix' from the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) and so avoided the healthy debate that could have resulted from a ministerial statement. Further, a call from the opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations and youth employment , the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) for an inquiry into teenage employment, the relativities between youth and adult wages, and the reluctance of employers to employ young people has met as yet with no response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you not mount an inquiry when you were in government?

—Every time we enter this House and make one or two constructive comments, we face the sort of tirade I am getting from the honourable member opposite. I have not as yet made a comment in criticism of the Government. In fact, standing here this afternoon I am not criticising the Government's short term record. I acknowledge that in the Australian Financial Review this morning, comment is made about the fact that the number of young people receiving unemployment benefit has fallen for the first time. But if we are to stand in this House and witness from this Government an exercise in self-congratulation over this dip in unemployment figures, that would be even less sensitive to the unemployed than has been the action of the honourable member for Hume. The Fraser Government could have claimed similar credit for similar dips in the period 1978 to 1981 without the benefit of drought-breaking rains, a world recovery and an inherited wage pause.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to make an urgent assessment of the present situation and to look, so far as I am able, with bipartisan eyes at the causes of and the solutions to Australia's blight of unemployment. I do not want to allow short term relief to camouflage my assessment of the underlying problem. Sadly, as a Parliament we have not as yet made that assessment, nor had the opportunity to do so. This Parliament introduced and has witnessed a decade of sundry and assorted unemployment schemes, whether they were the regional employment development scheme or the community employment programs, whether they were introduced by the Fraser Government under the wage pause program or introduced and funded by the $ 300 million made available by this Government under the CEP. What we cannot escape as a parliament is that none of these schemes works in reducing the number of unemployed. The facts are that all of these schemes give unemployed people some work experience but they do not provide full time jobs. Even the work experience is limited when we consider that the $300m scheme we are presently engaged in will, in fact, give work experience to something like 40, 000 people. That is fewer than one in 10 of the present unemployed. We must look elsewhere for a solution to the unemployed problem and for real lasting jobs.

This is not a criticism of the Government. The present figures give some hope but nothing has been done in this House to address the root cause of the problem . No Government scheme is likely to produce productive long term jobs and solve the underlying problem of unemployment. The irony is, as every Australian knows, and certainly as every rural Australian knows, that there are jobs waiting to be done, many of them unskilled, and that nine out of 10 Australians are currently in work.

The question then is: Why do employers hesitate to employ? It would be simplistic to do as people have done before and say: 'There are 600,000 small businesses in Australia and 600,000 people out of work. If every small business took on one more person there would be no more unemployment'. That is simplistic but it points to the root cause of the problem. For the truth is that employers are fearful to take on additional staff. They are fearful of those imposts that have been levied on them by State and Federal governments such as payroll taxes and workers compensation. They are fearful of those imposts that are Australian employment phenomena-long service leave and leave loadings. These on-costs may well be 50 per cent of the employer's costs. In buoyant times these demands were made and met, but a recent survey has shown that employees currently rate job security and work environment ahead of their wage levels. The responsiblity now on the Government, the responsibility even more acutely on people in work, is to look at current wage levels and at the demands they are making with current on- job costs.

I would suggest that after a decade of government action it is over to the employees to decide what room they can make in their work force for the unemployed. It is the employees who dictate the unions' willingness to make room for unemployed people and it is the employees who control initial productivity. I further suggest that the solution to much of Australia's current unemployment is not through legislation but consideration. There is no escaping the unbreakable relationship that exists between real unit costs and unemployment rates. The two graphs follow each other up and they have done so under successive governments. We cannot escape that as real unit costs for employment rise so unemployment rises. The challenge the House faces, the challenge this Parliament faces, is the challenge of grasping the nettle, biting the bullet and recognising that indexation costs jobs. The wage pause introduced by the Fraser Government slowed down the rate at which people were put out of work. We are just seeing the benefit of that in this month's figures. Wage indexation will guarantee that as incomes rise so does unemployment. Uncomfortable as it is we cannot escape it. I conclude by quoting from an editorial in the Australian on 16 August last year:
It is pointless to push for wage rises when an industry cannot pay them. And it is selfish to push for them when the result is a loss of jobs for workmates in the industry.
The challenge that the Australian employee faces is the challenge of making room for other Australians in the work force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Among the most difficult areas for Federal members of parliament to cover in relation to constituents' problems are those which contain some elements of government involvement but which are essentially the responsibilities of State governments. Constituents seeking the help of Federal parliamentarians become angry when their Federal members appear to them to be unwilling to pursue their cases, when in fact the parliamentarian has done all within his or her power to assist but is finally frustrated by the intransigence or inertia of State bodies. I would like to relate to the House just such a problem, as I believe that a case of injustice has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: My constituent's name is Maureen Rees. She is an intellectually disabled pensioner who is supported, together with a number of other intellectually disabled people, by the Ferntree Gully and District Welfare Association for the Intellectually Handicapped. For the information of honourable members I will give a broad outline of the case. In 1967 the City of Knox resolved to sell quarry land and donate the proceeds to a building fund for the intellectually handicapped of the district, to be held on trust to attract a $4 to $1 government building grant. On 6 September 1971, the land was transferred to three trustees of the Ferntree Gully and District Welfare Association for the Intellectually Handicapped, namely, Keith Robert Lithgow, Leslie Robert Kerr and Geoffrey Phillip Hayes. The trustees in turn leased the land for 99 years to Basil de Jong, Gazina de Jong and Paul Joseph Engeler, on the condition that they operate a licensed restaurant.

The lease was prepared on the instructions of the Town Clerk, Neville Haynes, but there is doubt as to whether the date of the lease was 1 October 1971 or 1 October 1972. Trevor and Frank Rees, acting on behalf of their sister, Maureen, assert that evidence shows the date of the lease to be 1 August 1971. Subsequently, the trustees resigned-incidentally they resigned on 1 September 1971-and, as an aside, it is rather puzzling, to say the least, that the land was not transferred at that time to the Association which was in fact incorporated on the same day.

In June 1972-the actual date is again uncertain-the three trustees and a company called PIB Investment Pty Ltd, the lessees, mortgaged the land to Alliance Acceptance Co. Ltd for $80,000, the money to be used in construction of the 'Swagman' restaurant. On 27 July 1972, the Association became the proprietors of the land by transfer from the trustees, at which time the Swagman restaurant was half completed. At this stage it is important to note that under the Hospitals and Charities Act it is necessary for a benevolent society to obtain authorisation to sell or lease land in trust. This authorisation was obtained, but again, as an aside, it should be noted that the Rees brothers claim that the date of the lease of 1 August 1972 was false and, in fact, the land was leased to the de Jongs and Engeler at a much earlier date.

A replacement lease was completed on 27 September 1972, which stipulated that the Ferntree Gully and District Welfare Association become the legal owners of the restaurant, leasing both the land and premises for 99 years for a premium of $5,000, with a rent of $50 to $75 per week for the next 15 years, after which time the rent could be adjusted by mutual agreement. Subsequently, on 5 December 1977, the site and premises were sold by the Association to a company named Basilthon Nominees Pty Ltd, of which Basil de Jong and Gazina de Jong were directors, for $213,000. In February 1979, just 14 months later, Basilthon Nominees went into liquidation; the site and premises at that time having been valued at $1,750,000. It is worthy of mention here that the site was estimated to be worth about $18,000 in 1972.

As mentioned previously, Frank and Trevor Rees, who are also constituents of mine, have been inquiring into the facts of the case, not only for their sister but for all mentally handicapped people in relation to their rights in respect of property held in trust on their behalf. From 1976 to date the brothers have pursued their inquiries with various State bodies and State parliamentarians but with little success. In consequence, in April 1982, they asked for my help and I accordingly made inquiries of the then Attorney-General, Treasurer and Minister for Social Security. Unfortunately, I do not have time in this debate to go over the details of the various lines of inquiry which I pursued with the various Federal Ministers. Suffice to say that it was made very clear to me that the property transactions did not fall within the responsibility of the Federal Government and inquiries should therefore be made through appropriate State Government channels.

It is perhaps unfortunate that my constituents, although it is understandable after years of frustration, see the replies of the Commonwealth Ministers as unsatisfactory. I have, however, examined the respective Federal and State responsibilities very carefully and I am perfectly satisfied that the charges of fradulent dealings in relation to a property transaction involving an association registered under a State Act can fall only within the realm of State government responsibilities. Accordingly, and in conjunction with my inquiries of Commonwealth Ministers, I wrote to the State Minister of Health on 1 June 1983. Regretfully, although I have sent several reminder letters to the Minister , beyond an acknowledgment and advice that the matter has been referred to the Health Commission I have not received a reply to one of the central issues of my inquiry, which is contained in the following quote from my letter:
The case involves persons dealing with the Welfare Association who had previously been convicted of stealing and fraud and doubts relating to the authenticity of:
(i) dates of land transfers;
(ii) authorisations of such transfers; and

(iii) prices negotiated. According to a former Minister of Health, Mr W. V. Houghton, the sale of the 'Swagman' property to Basilthon Nominees Pty. Ltd. was authorised by the Health Commission in the terms of Section 68 (3) (b) of the Hospitals and Charities Act 1958, following a report by the Valuer-General that the price represented, in his opinion, a full and proper consideration as a basis for negotiations for the sale of property at the time in question-the ' property' being the land and improvements.

However, the Director-General for Local Government, Mr. George Pentland, advises that no valuation in respect of the abovementioned property was made by the office of the Valuer-General. In view of that discrepancy, I write, in the interest of the Commonwealth pensioner involved, to ask for copies of the letter from the said association seeking authority to sell this trust property, pursuant to Section 68 (3) (b) of the Act, and the Health Commission's reply granting such authorisation.

In the time available, I have not been able to go through the maze of channels which have been pursued by the Rees brothers in their attempts to uncover the facts behind the rather strange business dealings involving the sale of the land and premises of the Swagman restaurant. It is possible that I will be advised that the Health Commission is unable to provide the answers to the questions I have asked. Let me make it quite clear that in my opinion it will be most regrettable if I am not provided with the facts of this case. It will indicate a substantial weakening of the powers of Federal parliamentarians to act on behalf of constituents where the matter concerned falls outside the realm of Commonwealth responsibilities. Such a weakening of our representative function will also, in my view, represent a weakening of our democratic system.

Let me conclude by setting out the matters of contention which I consider must be resolved before this case is settled to my satisfaction. Firstly, in view of apparent conflicting evidence in respect of the dates of the property transfer relating to the land and premises comprising the Swagman restuarant, the dates need to be ascertained and authenticated. Secondly, bearing in mind that in 1972 the undeveloped land was valued at $18,000, that in December 1977 the land and premises were sold for $213,000 and that in 1979 the land and premises were apparently valued at $1,750,000, how can this rapid escalation in values be reconciled with the actual business dealings undertaken by the various owners of the property during that period? Thirdly, in particular, what explanation is there for an 800 per cent increase in the value of the property in less than two years? Fourthly, and finally, what was the basis of the legal advice to the administrator of the Ferntree Gully and District Welfare Association for the Intellectually Handicapped, Mr Duncan Cook, that enabled him to refuse to provide either the Rees brothers or myself with a copy of the resolution of the Association authorising the sale of the property? What had the administrator got to hide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House to the Government's determination to establish a State owned overseas trading corporation regardless of widespread community opposition. The Government makes great play of its commitment to what is described as consensus. It is, however, becoming increasingly apparent that consensus is just a meaningless slogan. Nowhere is that more apparent than in the case of the Overseas Trading Corporation, which I will refer to as the OTC. The Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) has for the last year trumpeted his belief that Australia must have an OTC. He has done so despite implacable opposition from the business community and the opposition of the Australian exporters and manufacturers who, the Minister claims, would benefit from such a proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: It is ironical indeed that the Minister should be promoting a proposal in the interests of business when business is totally opposed to that proposal. In recent weeks, Australia's two largest business organisations, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and the Confederation of Australian Industry, have made their opposition to the OTC abundantly clear. In December, the CAI conducted a survey of 41 companies engaged in manufacturing, mining, trading and the processing of primary products to establish their views on the OTC. The respondents' exports totalled around $6 billion. It was therefore a very thorough and very reliable survey.

The result of the survey was that only nine of the 41 companies indicated any kind of support for an OTC and, of these, several expressed doubts about its ability to operate profitably or to represent their products adequately. CAI members argued that such a company would be superfluous. They have made a point which would be quite obvious to any government or any Minister not bent on ideological cause. Private companies would take up all the viable trading opportunities, thereby leaving the government trading company with unprofitable and commercially unviable business. The only alternative for the OTC would be to take profitable business away from the private sector. There is no doubt that that is exactly the course that the OTC would follow.

These views have been strongly supported by the Australian Chamber of Commerce. The Federal Director of the Chamber, Mr Alexander Downer, wrote to the Minister for Trade on 16 December last, drawing the Minister's attention to the unanimous opposition of trading members of the Australian Chamber of Commerce to an OTC. The Chamber argued that an OTC would take business away from existing private sector exporters, thereby undermining their profitability. The Chamber further believes existing exporters are already able to facilitate small business penetration into export markets. It again believes and it has emphasised that established exporters are already able, without difficulty, to trade in the Middle East and centrally planned economies. Yet, despite this advice by the Chamber to the Minister for Trade, the Government is still pursuing a proposal. Apparently, the Government knows better then professional traders who operate daily in the market-place just what exporters need. That is just arrogant, ideological nonsense.

The Government has now appointed a consultant, the Australian Bank Ltd, to look at the proposal. The bank was asked first to establish whether there was a case for an OTC and, if it felt that there was, to draw up a detailed plan of how the OTC would work. The way the terms of reference were drafted ensured that the Australian Bank would argue for an OTC. If it did not it would lose the very valuable business of drawing up the blueprint of the corporation. It has a vested interest in advising the Government that an OTC was desirable. As a compromise, the Australian Bank has proposed that 60 per cent of the OTC be owned by the private sector.

I make two points about that. First, if an OTC were to be viable the private sector would be prepared to own it outright; there would be no need to commit taxpayers' funds to a commercial venture. Secondly, taxpayers' money should not be used to fund commercial activities. On the contrary, taxpayers would, I do not doubt, prefer a reduction in taxation. But, equally significant, there is no indication that business leaders support the Australian Bank's 40 : 60 proposal at all. Indeed, there are suggestions that both the Australian Chamber of Commerce and the Confederation of Australian Industry will oppose the Australian Bank proposal.

The Government is arguing that Australian exports have been poorly marketed and that is why its share of world trade has fallen from 1.7 per cent to 1.3 per cent over the last 12 years. It is not poor marketing which has pushed Australia out of world markets; it is simply that Australian exports are becoming increasingly uncompetitive, and that is the key to it-the competitiveness of Australia's exports. The Government's priority, therefore, should be to restore competitiveness by ensuring wage levels reflect industry's capacity to pay, by ensuring that real interest rates are brought down by responsible fiscal policies and by giving business breathing space by abandoning anti-business measures such as those outlined in the trade practices discussion paper.

These are the priorities. If the Government were to translate its rhetoric on consensus into real consideration of business concerns, Australia might be able to recapture lost markets. If the Government, on an ideological crusade, proceeds with its proposals to establish an overseas trading corporation it will meet with the distrust and opposition of business and the wider community. The solution to the problem of Australia's falling export market does not lie in the establishment of nationalised industries, which no one has asked for and nobody wants. Instead, it rests with the Government in providing a sounder, more competitive economic export market. The challenge therefore is on the Government to assist in the wider economic strategy of our exporters. It does not rest in such nationalised, socialistic plans to dominate free enterprise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance relates to the review process available to people who have received an adverse decision by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The current review process was established by the previous Government in 1982 when the then Minister announced the formation of the Immigration Review Panel. According to the Minister's Press announcement at the time, the new arrangements constituted a major advance in the review of decisions on migration and citizenship cases. An integral part of this new approach was that applicants would be given the reasons why their applications were unsuccessful. They would also be told how to lodge an appeal and advised on how to present their cases in the most favourable way. This, I can say with surety, is not happening, and, as a result, people are being required to present their cases for appeal in ignorance of the reasons why their applications have been rejected.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been aware of the inadequacy of the information provided by the Department for some time. However, it was brought into focus when a constituent of mine, Mr Jackson, sought my help following the rejection of his appeal. Mr Jackson had sponsored his brother-in-law, Mr Hunt, and family, who wished to migrate to Australia from England in 1982. Following a brief letter of rejection from the Australian High Commission in London in June 1983, Mr Hunt, the sponsoree, wrote to the High Commission requesting details of how many points he scored and how these points were made up. A week later Mr Hunt received the following reply from the High Commission:
I appreciate your disappointment resulting from the rejection of your application. Unfortunately, unemployment is a serious problem and this has led to a reduction in the migration programme.

As was explained in our letter of 1 June the decision can only be reviewed through your relative in Australia. If an appeal is lodged we will be asked to forward full details of your points assessment to Australia for consideration by the Review Panel.

Mr Hunt's request for details was obviously not met by this letter from the High Commission. Mr Jackson, the Australian sponsor, in late June received a letter from the Department of Immigration which also stated that the application had been unsuccessful. Again, no reasons were given although Mr Jackson was advised that he may have a right of appeal under the review rights. Mr Jackson twice attempted by phone to obtain further details as to why the application was rejected before he lodged his appeal. He was apparently told just to fill in the form as best he could as all the details would be provided to the Review Panel directly by the Department. Not only is this advice contrary to the original intent of the Minister when providing this review right, but also it makes it impossible for the person appealing to lodge a relevant appeal. The critical section of the request for review form asks the applicant:
1. Are there any facts or circumstances about the case which are in dispute between you and the Department?
2. Are there any aspects of the case which in your opinion the Department has failed to consider or to which it has given too little consideration?

A person cannot answer those questions with relevance if he has not been given details for the rejection. The Department itself recognises this as a problem in its 1983 annual report. However, it sees no immediate resolution because of the drain on resources such as staff, time and money. I contend that such a position is untenable as I believe it is a denial of the rights of the applicant.

When I first saw Mr Jackson's appeal form-and that was after a decision had been made by the Minister-I criticised him for the way it had been completed. In reply to question No. 1, factors in dispute, he had detailed some of the human tragedies the sponsored couple had faced in their lives. These factors, of course, were not in dispute.

In reply to question No. 2, aspects not considered by the Department, he wrote that too little consideration had been given to the fact that Mr Hunt had an offer of employment and that he had been sponsored. This was irrelevant as Mr Hunt had received the maximum points possible for the offer of employment and maximum points for being sponsored by a non-Australian citizen. But, as Mr Jackson quickly pointed out, he was not to know his answers were irrelevant because despite his requests he had been unable to obtain these details before he lodged his appeal. I myself had only known them because the Review secretariat had provided me with them at my request.

As a consequence, Mr Jackson's appeal did not provide any new information which may have altered the Department's original decision. Now that he knows these details Mr Jackson believes that there are certain factors the Department has not considered and he has also obtained new material which could influence the decision. I hope that in Mr Jackson's case the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) will give him the opportunity of presenting a new appeal. However, the principal purpose of my speaking in the House today is not simply to raise facts about a particular case. Rather it is to highlight the principle involved: That is, that the Department of Immigration is not providing people with enough information to decide whether they have grounds for appeal in the first place and certainly not enough detail to lodge a relevant appeal in the second.

I also believe that whilst the Department does not provide such information the Review Panel is in many cases wasting its time reviewing decisions. I am suggesting that a reallocation of the Department's resources may in fact reduce the work load. Under the current arrangements, when an appeal is lodged it goes straight to a section of the Department to provide a statement of applicable policy and standards and to ascertain the Department's reasons for the rejection of the specific application. This requires the Department to gather together information, possibly from the overseas post and various sections of the Department within Australia, on which to write a report. This process is taking so long, according to a member of the Review Panel, that the Panel has on some occasions had no cases before it because they were all awaiting departmental report.

If the Department's staff, time and money were spent in the first instance on providing individuals with details on policy and the reasons why the Department rejects applications it would, firstly, obviate the need to have a special section of the Department set up to acquire the same details long after the decision is made; secondly, it would allow applicants to determine whether they have any ground for an appeal; and, thirdly, it would provide those seeking an appeal information to enable them to lodge a relevant appeal. This in turn would make the Review Panel's role far more effective. I therefore call on the Minister for Immigration to consider the matters I have raised in this House today and to take measures which will overcome what I perceive to be inadequacies in the current review system.

In the few minutes I have remaining I also express my concerns over the rights given under the current review system to people who have come to Australia on visitor's visas to stay here permanently. Such people sign an agreement when entering the country as visitors undertaking to abide by the conditions of their visas, that is, that they are in Australia purely for holiday purposes and they will return home prior to the expiration of their visas. Yet under review rights three and four if such people apply for a change of status after their arrival and are rejected they are entitled to appeal against the Department's ruling free of charge. This right is being abused. It is well known that if people want to extend their holiday visas for a further six to 12 months the most effective way is to wait until their visas have almost expired and then apply to the Department for a change of status and, if rejected, appeal. This whole process, due to delays in the system, can take up to 12 months. Not only does this process clog up the Department with even more files but it costs the taxpayers a huge amount of money in that they are financing the costs of the Review Panel in examining such cases. Also, such people, after six months in Australia, get the benefit of medicare coverage.

Why we as Australians subject ourselves to the costs and time involved in appeals by people who have reneged on declarations they have signed when entering the country as visitors is beyond me. A minimum change in my opinion would be that such people should at least pay for the costs of any appeal. In fact, I question their right of appeal in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford) for some of the sentiments that he expressed in his speech. On 5 March 1983, 23 Liberal and National Party members lost their seats from this House in the Parliament. The Australian Labor Party swept to power with a majority of 25 members and on a two-party preferred vote a 3.6 per cent swing. A swing of 3.3 per cent on a two-party preferred vote is all that is necessary to unseat the present Government. In a nutshell, at that time the population judged that the Fraser Government had not come across with the goods. Whether Liberal and National Party supporters agree or disagree with the collective judgment of the people is now immaterial. Our democratic system produced an ALP Federal Government. To me, that we have a democracy rates as equal in importance to my Party being in power.

SPEECH.PARA: I am the only person now in this Parliament who actually lost a seat in 1983 and who can now stand in this place and speak of that loss. Dismissing at this time a couple of disappointing aspects of the ALP campaign in my then seat of Fadden, I have no difficulty in understanding why a national swing of 3.6 per cent took place and why we lost 23 seats. I harbour no resentment about the people's decision. However, despite the present high personal standing of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), I voice a firmly held view that we are now witnessing in Australia the greatest con act by any government and any Prime Minister in this nation's history. I do not state this as one who is politically peeved but if people will only look beyond the veneer of utter falsity of the Government and the Prime Minister it is easy to see.

The Prime Minister has projected an image of being 'Honest Bob', who would rather be dead than be found out being dishonest. There is now sufficient evidence to prove that Robert James Lee Hawke is not the angel he would have people believe. His first untruth as leader of the ALP was on the very day he became leader of that party, 3 February 1983. Let us remember how on that night on 3 February, during an interview with Richard Carleton on Nationwide he did his cool-to describe it mildly-when Carleton had the temerity to ask him, in relation to the overthrow of my fellow Queenslander, Bill Hayden: 'Are you at all embarrassed by the blood on your hands tonight?' Honest Bob exploded. He accused Carleton of being quite 'perverted' and of 'impertinence'. Honest Bob vehemently denied during the 1983 election campaign that he was in any way implicated and his righteousness, what is more, was convincing to the electorate at large.
