The Paul Kelly book, The Hawke Ascendancy, has revealed how deeply involved the now Prime Minister was in Bill Hayden's overthrow. Only one month ago the Prime Minister actually complimented Kelly at the launching of the book on the accuracy of the contents of the book. He even alluded to some passages being a little bit embarrassing to him and to Bill Hayden.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order. The honourable member will refer to the office of the member.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker; I mean to the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden). So much for honesty on that occasion. How any man could look into that box and demonstrate against Richard Carleton, who obviously had put his finger on a very tender spot, is beyond me. How any man could have pretended for the rest of that interview that it was all lies when it was the truth is also beyond me. The electorate should not need reminding of how the Federal Government has walked away from so many of those promises made during the February 1983 election campaign: There will be tax cuts; no pensioners shall be hurt; petrol prices will come down by 3c a litre; there will be no additional tax on superannuation payments and no capital gains tax; we will leave the health levy in place until 1 February 1984-I notice the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) sitting at the table nodding his head; he remembers it too-we will leave in place the interest rebate for those paying off their homes; and so on and so on and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will remember the words of the Prime Minister on 11 February 1983: 'Now, one thing you will find throughout this campaign is that I am not going to make promises that I cannot keep'. Following his election those promises and so many others that I have alluded to were all swept aside with the excuse that John Howard and Malcolm Fraser had deceived Australia and that there was a deficit or an overspending to the tune of $9.6 billion. That was their excuse. In this place we hear that repeated and repeated, time after time. Whenever the Labor Government is in trouble it refers to that deficit. The untruth of that figure of $9.6 billion and in its continued use was highlighted last August when the Government Budget came down showing a deficit of only $5.9 billion. The Government then added another $2.5 billion to finance its own programs. So within five months that $9.6 billion had become only $5.9 billion. The people of Australia have been conned on the walking away from all those promises. The Canberra Times of 7 March, in its editorial titled 'P.M.'s Image Damaged', stated:

The point is worth repeating: Mr Hawke and Mr Keating have now conceded that the figures they used to justify abandonment of the ALP's election program were spurious. The import of that admission has yet to sink into the electorate, the ALP branches, and the industrial wing of the Labor movement.

I notice the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) leaving the chamber. Many people in the Labor Party share many of his views. How disappointed they have been with the Prime Minister for the way in which he has walked away from so many of the commitments which motivated left wing people in this country to work their hearts out to get a Labor government. That is not my problem; that is their problem.

In conclusion, I repeat what I said earlier. We are witnessing in this country an effective campaign by one of the greatest con merchants this nation has seen. I wish him well in his appearances at sporting events. I wish him well on his happy-go-lucky attitude to the job. But when it comes to deceiving the people of this nation and combining that deceit with an appearance that butter would not melt in his mouth, that it is honest Bob, I take exception. If he wants to be a Prime Minister who says to the people, 'Well, I indulge in trickery; judge me for what I am', that is honest; but his parade in this place day after day pretending that he is something that he is not needs to be exposed. I just hope that Liberal and National Party people start playing an active part in talking to fellow Australians about this because the facts are there to bolster the argument and to support the argument and to rip away this sickening veneer which currently exists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join today's debate to grieve for the young people of Australia-those people neglected during the seven years of Liberal rule-and to applaud the new Government's actions in the area of youth policy, to commend those steps which have been taken and those which are still in the planning stages, which have for the first time in many years provided proof that here at last we have a government which is genuinely concerned with the problems of young people in contemporary society.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming to office at the time that it did the Government was faced with the twin problems of record youth unemployment and low retention and participation rates in our schools and tertiary institutions. These two problems are, of course, at least in part, related. Low participation rates after the end of compulsory schooling must contribute towards high youth unemployment. It is true that low retention rates in Australian secondary schools and low participation rates in post-secondary education are features of the Australian system of which none of us, particularly the former Government, can be proud. Any comparision with countries such as Japan, the United States of America or Canada reveals that we perform very poorly and that, while on average their young people are pursuing further education after the compulsory age of leaving, far too many of our young people have their talents wasted and have joined the ranks of the unemployed.

The Government is, of course, taking steps to remedy this appalling situation- not, as some mean-minded critics would suggest, with the objective of hiding youth unemployment in the schools and post-secondary institutions but because our performance is so bad when compared with the overseas experience, because the present statistics reveal an appalling waste of human talent which, if developed, would enrich the lives of individuals and contribute so much to the wealth of the nation. I was therefore very pleased to see the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), very early in their terms, expressing an interest and a determination to act in this area.

Last November a team from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development spent some time in Australia reviewing youth policy, taking a fresh look at existing programs and their deficiencies, looking at young people's problems and offering overseas experience of similar problems and possible approaches to solutions. As the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs said at that time:

The Government sees a need to take stock of existing programs and of their relevance to the problems of young people to improve co-ordination, remove inconsistencies and develop a more coherent set of policies and programs.
This review was a very important initiative of the new Government and I, with other members I am sure, await its final report with a great deal of interest.

The Government's participation and equity program which was announced in the education guidelines of 1983 was welcomed by all of those people with a genuine interest in improving educational opportunity in this country. This program is a most important expression of the needs policy and it is aimed at encouraging greater participation among disadvantaged groups and in disadvantaged areas. It will target resources, particularly human resources, on those areas which have historically been disadvantaged, particularly through the long periods of Liberal Federal government.

It will come as no surprise to honourable members to learn that the area of western Sydney, part of which I represent, will require special assistance under the participation and equity program. Honourable members might be interested to learn, however, of the extent of the problem and therefore the extent of the need. Nationally, around 35 per cent of students enjoy a full secondary education. The figure for Government schools is around 28 per cent. There are 44 Government secondary schools in western Sydney. Thirty-seven of them retain less than the national average and 33 less than the Government school average. More than half of those schools retain fewer than one in five of their Year 7 entrants to the end of Year 12. Three of them retain fewer than one in 10.

Clearly, the western Sydney region is an area requiring additional resources to meet special problems. The assistance must be substantial. It must be targeted quite specifically on those areas of special need and it must apply over a long period. Otherwise no substantial results will occur. The responses to the problems need to be many, varied and innovative. They may involve alternative courses; they may involve new curricula; they may require, indeed, new ways of organising schools.

I was delighted last year when the then Minister for Education in New South Wales, now the Deputy Premier, the Hon. Ron Mulock, announced that a pilot senior high school would operate in western Sydney from the beginning of 1985-a school modelled on the Canberra pattern, a separate institution for students pursuing the last two years of secondary education. They certainly have been a great success in Canberra. I must confess that I was, however, rather less than delighted to learn recently that the introduction of the western Sydney senior high school had been postponed, postponed largely because of opposition from the New South Wales Teachers' Federation. I must say that I find the Federation's objections to this innovation a little difficult to understand. I do that from the position of a person who has been a fully paid up and frequently very active member of that organisation for more than 20 years. At this stage I can only express the hope that further and meaningful and genuine discussions between all of those people interested in providing workable solutions to the many and varied problems of the young people in western Sydney will continue so that this project can be launched with goodwill, co-operation and understanding on all sides and, above all, with a genuine determination to make it succeed, to make it work in the interests of the young people in that area and to lift retention rates in western Sydney from their present very, very low level.

I remain convinced, however, that the real key to improving participation rates in Australian education-apart from innovative organisation, new courses and more determination at that level-rests with the provision of improved income support for those who choose to continue their studies. While it is true that some young people-indeed many-discontinue their education at age 15 because perhaps there is little in schools to attract them to stay on and they see no reason to extend their sentences for a further two years, I believe that there are many who would otherwise stay on and who fail to do so for purely economic reasons. In other words, they see little sense in staying on at school when they can leave, attempt to get a job or look at the option of the unemployment benefit if they fail to obtain employment.

I was therefore pleased to receive recently, with other honourable members, a copy of the discussion paper entitled 'Income Support for Young People'. This paper was prepared following the inaugural meeting of the Youth Ministers in November last year and I understand that the working party reported to a further meeting of those Ministers recently. This paper identifies very well a number of very important issues in this area, including the complexity of the current system, which involves at least 37 different possible methods of payment to young people. It addresses the inadequacy of levels of allowances, particularly for those young people living away from home or those who have no parental support. It identifies inequities created by income tests, disincentives operating in the system and the question of dependency. It looks at overall constraints on possible reforms to the system, particularly those constraints arising from severe budgetary pressures placed on the present Government and, of course, inherited from the previous Government. The paper explores many of the problems and exposes many of the anomalies in the system, which has been allowed to grow like Topsy and which has been characterised by the ad hockery of successive Liberal administrations. The task of rationalisation, restoring equity and providing incentives where they are most needed will not be an easy one. This discussion paper is an important first step and I look forward very much to the Government's response to it.

I draw particular attention to the plight of those mature age students who are seeking to obtain a school certificate or Year 10 certification. At present these students qualify for no form of educational assistance, yet without the school certificate they are unable to proceed to full secondary education. I trust that their claims will be addressed in any review of the arrangements for student assistance. I close by commending the initiative of the Youth Ministers in having this discussion paper prepared. I express confidence that it will produce real and lasting benefits for the many young people in this country who deserve a better deal and who have for far too long been denied it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the subject of Sydney Airport and the hundreds and thousands of people who are being affected by the refusal of this Government to make a decision about that airport and about the site of the second airport. It was the policy of the Australian Labor Party in opposition not to proceed with the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Surprisingly one might think, given its record for keeping promises, this promise was kept-or perhaps not so surprisingly when one looks at the electorates which it thought might be adversely affected in electoral terms by a decision to go ahead with the third runway.

SPEECH.PARA: What has it done? It has left us without any proposal for a third runway because that has been stopped and it has left us in search of a site for a second airport. It is that aspect that I wish to look at and ask three question: Firstly, when are we going to have a decision; secondly, where is the new site going to be; and, thirdly, what of Sydney Airport? Nobody could deny that this is an urgent question, least of all the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley), who has been at pains to express his concern about the need for a speedy resolution of the question of the site of Sydney's second airport.

Piecing together the Government's policy in this area is rather like being blindfolded and trying to put together a jigsaw puzzle of which some of the pieces are missing, but I will seek to piece it together as best I can from published statements and reports of what the Minister has said. In the Canberra Times of 30 March 1983 this is what he is reported to have said, and he has never denied it, concerning the relocation, the new site:
The project has top priority and I hope to reach a final decision sooner rather than later . . . certainly within the life of the current Parliament.
On the same day, 30 March, he was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying this:
Sydney will not get a second airport on this side of the Blue Mountains unless a site is chosen quickly.
One can only say he is absolutely right there. He is also reported as saying this:
I will not be the Minister for Aviation when the second airport is completed, but I will be the minister when its location is decided.

Will he? Is that his intention? Is that the Government's intention? Going forward through some of the statements which are reported of him in the newspapers, on 5 May 1983 he is reported to have said that he hoped to bring the matter to a fairly rapid conclusion. He was reported to have said further that a deal of work had been done by the Major Airport Needs of Sydney Study. Certainly there had been a deal of work done on the whole question of the major airport needs of Sydney. Moving forward and trying to piece together the jigsaw puzzle, on 13 May a statement of a meeting between the Minister and local government representatives stated:
Mr Beazley told the councillors that he had no preconceived ideas about the eventual site but that he was determined to make a final decision as soon as possible.

What does that tell us of Mr Beazley? It tells us, one would think, that he is a man-a Minister-on top of his portfolio, vigorous, keen to see decisions made and determined to see that decisions will be made. This is not a man, one might think, who will be stopped, who will be held back by bureaucratic inertia or the politics of Tammany Hall. Or is that not so? Is in fact the Government playing the politics of Tammany Hall and is the Minister a party to those political games? What do we see as we go through the Press cuttings? On 27 July 1983 he is reported to have said of Kingsford-Smith Airport:
It is not our intention to abandon this site . . .
He is also reported as pointing this out, which is undeniably the fact:
The annual wages bill for employees on the airport alone is around $300 million and it employs close to 14,000 people . . .

That is so. Of course the loss of that airport would be an economic catastrophe for people living around that area. But let us move forward again through the Press cuttings, through the statements made by the Minister. On 25 August, in a news release, he said:

I am very concerned about the worry and uncertainty which many people are experiencing as a result of proposals regarding the development or airport facilities in the Sydney area and the Government will be moving to take this decision as quickly as possible.

I emphasise the words 'as quickly as possible' because how else could the Government approach this decision other than as a decision which needed to be urgently made? But is it being urgently made? We come next to a joint statement made by Mr Beazley--

TALK.START.PARA: -Order!
—By the Minister for Aviation and the Minister for Environment and Planning of the New South Wales Government, Mr Bedford. That statement was made on 27 September 1983 and in it we see this:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Beazley said Sydney Airport was the hub of the Australian airline network and the resolution of Sydney's future airport needs in an environmentally acceptable manner was one of our primary objectives.

It certainly is the hub of Australia's international network and of Australia's domestic network, taking as it does more than eight and a half million passengers through it each year and suffering as it does, of course, great problems of congestion. What did Mr Bedford say in this same statement of 27 September 1983? Mr Bedford said:
. . . the time was rapidly approaching when the opportunity to preserve a second airport site would be lost.

That is undeniably the truth, and time is passing. In this joint statement it was also said of the MANS Study-the sixth study made on Sydney airport needs- which finished in 1979 and which is a voluminous examination of those needs:
. . . the MANS Study is still relevant and therefore will only require updating .

One would think, therefore, that it would be a fairly quick thing to make a decision upon this matter, important as it is and pressingly urgent as it is. But what do we see? The clincher in this statement of 27 September 1983, for reasons which are indicated, limping as they are:
. . . it will not be possible to announce the actual site until about mid 1985.

Let us move forward to 27 March 1984, exactly six months after the joint statement by the Federal Minister and the New South Wales Minister. The Minister for Aviation is reported in the Canberra Times as saying to the National Aviation Press Club:
He did not believe that the present Kingsford-Smith Airport would disappear totally.

What does that mean? It means that it is largely to disappear. Let me now come back to the questions that I posed at the outset. The first was: When is the decision going to be made? The decision is going to be made after the next election and the Government does not give a damn about the consequences in terms of inconvenience, in terms of money lost, in terms of whether or not it will even be possible after the next election to find an airport. It is going to defer the decision for purely political reasons: The politics of Tammany Hall and the principles of Tammany Hall. The second question is: Where is the site going to be? We do not know. But the Government must know, the Department of Aviation must know. It is perfectly impossible that after all this time they would not know where the site is going to be, if they really wanted to tell us. Thirdly, what of Sydney Airport? We now know that Sydney Airport is to be run down. To what extent one does not know, but if it is not going to disappear, totally, to quote what Mr Beazley has said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would ask the honourable member--

—What the Minister said means that there is going to be very little of it left. That means a great loss of jobs, a huge diversion of resources, and for what purpose? Apparently the purpose can only be to meet the commitments of the Government to its political views, and its political views about getting back into power regardless of the consequences to the people who live around Sydney Airport and in the sites which are affected by the proposals for the new airport.

—Order! Before I call the honourable member for Burke, I must ask honourable members to abide by the Standing Orders and to refer to honourable members either by their electorates or by their portfolios.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks about the restructuring of Australian industry-a topic which I think is of enormous importance to this country-and on the Government's attitude towards this important medium to long term objective. Let me say firstly that I consider it a disgrace that the Federal Opposition has hardly ever mentioned industry policy or the restructuring of industry. Yesterday we had the spectacle of the first question on industry policy from the Opposition being asked by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). That was the Opposition's first reference to the matter and it was not in fact a substantive question on restructuring.

SPEECH.PARA: This reflects the fact that the Opposition has nothing to say on industry policy. During its period in government its whole approach to industry matters was total chaos. In the final year of the Fraser Government 100,000 jobs were lost in manufacturing industry-a wholesale and massive destruction of our manufacturing industry unprecedented in Australian history. The Labor Government , in its first year, has been trying to cope with the crisis situation which it inherited from the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. But this is not sufficient in itself. What is necessary and what we are developing is a policy for the restructuring of industry, a positive policy which we hope will result in the development and strengthening of Australian manufacturing industry to make it competitive and efficient, and at the same time able to provide a lasting industrial base for this country.

The term 'restructuring' may be open to different interpretations. However, let me emphasise this point: No member of this Government would consider ' restructuring' to mean sudden, massive and isolated reductions in protection to large sections of our manufacturing industry. That has never been the intention of this Government because, without doubt, such a course of action would lead to significantly reduced employment in manufacturing and, at least in the medium term, would result in greater total unemployment. Swift and uncomplemented reductions in trade barriers represent a politically naive and economically callous approach to industry policy. The term 'restructuring' does not refer to the vertual destruction of our manufacturing base; rather, it is an important long term, positive goal to achieve viable, efficient and productive industries.

Unlike many on the other side, including the former Treasurer, and certain Federal Government bureaucracies with their heads in the clouds of conservative economic theory-such as the Industries Assistance Commission-the Government realises that immediate and significant reductions in protection will, in isolation, be counter-productive to its objective of eventual full employment. Central to this is the recognition that manufacturing industry is a relatively labour intensive sector and that a redistribution of income away from manufacturing industry which would improve with isolated reductions in trade barriers will destroy more jobs than it creates, even in the long term. The redirected investment away from manufacturing would, in the present economic climate, flow mainly to financial speculation and possibly to the mining sector, thus creating fewer jobs and a more concentrated level of wealth.

For this reason the Labor Government is committed to the promotion of strong manufacturing and service industries. Long term restructuring must be designed to achieve this and therefore must involve much more than changes in protection levels. Protection is but one aspect of the concept of restructuring. The fact that lowering trade barriers in isolation can be a negative and destructive policy, however, should not lead us to think that in the longer term such a course of action, when complemented with appropriate backup policies, cannot be positive and constructive.

I believe the time has come to stop looking at protection in the narrow, philosophically biased way the Opposition has done in the past. We must start to look at the issue of protection policy in terms of how best it can be conducted for the purposes of the Government's restructuring goal. The first step towards this is to consider protection policy as only one aspect of the Government's overall long term industry policy. It is only then that reducing protection can be constructive and positive. Clearly, the short-sighted protection policies of the previous Government have shown that to consider protection as an independent , self-fulfilling aspect of economic policy will completely negate its effectiveness. Firms have rarely been willing to expand investment and employment in return for assistance,be it by way of protection or direct financial assistance. The end result of the previous Government's attitude towards protection has not been more efficient and responsive industries but higher unemployment and underutilised capacity.

A long term policy of restructuring based on two-way agreement between employers and the Government is the only guarantee we have that reducing protection will not just destroy jobs. The basis of such agreements and undertakings must be a comprehensive and systematic plan. There is no other way we can be assured that new industries will be in place to employ workers if and when they become redundant. The prime task of government forward planning must be to ensure that potential growth areas are identified and swiftly acted upon. The necessary government bodies, such as the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the Australian Manufacturing Industry Council and other industry councils, are already in place to implement and where necessary enforce a broad planning strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

—I refer the Minister for Defence to his answer on the Invincible fiasco last year and to the various conflicting comments he made. Does the Minister still maintain, as he did in this House on 1 March 1984, that there was no policy in place to cover dry docking of vessels such as the Invincible, as distinct from the long-standing practice on visits of nuclear armed or nuclear powered ships?

—The statement which I released on this matter and which was agreed to by the governments of the United Kingdom and the United States of America constitutes the agreed statement which has been made on this matter by the three governments in respect of dry docking of ships which are nuclear powered or which may have been carrying nuclear weapons. The statement is an agreed statement, and it stands as set out.

—Can the Foreign Minister say what period has elapsed since he first stated that the Government would establish a peace research institute? How can he justify this delay? Will he give an undertaking that there will now be prompt action in carrying out the firm commitment given by the Government to establish such an institute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of great good fortune that I do, by coincidence, happen to have some figures here which will be helpful in response to this question. I acknowledge that several months have elapsed since I originally announced that a peace research institute would be established and that the Australian Government would be funding its foundation and operation. It was to be established at the Australian National University under arrangements which were then mutually agreed upon. Unfortunately the arrangements went foul of some institutional and structural problems. As a consequence the arrangements had to be re-negotiated. They have been. The centre is to go ahead and will be established at the Australian National University. I will convey the latest details and confirmation that the project is to go ahead to the Vice-Chancellor, Professor Peter Karmel, in the course of today or tomorrow.

ANSWER.PARA: For the record I add that I am extremely pleased at the generous response of the Minister for Finance in agreeing that the new arrangements would be funded. He enjoys a very high respect in the Government as being an attentive protector of the public purse against all assaults. Indeed he has an enviable and unrivalled record in our hearts and minds. That is somewhat different from winning them, I suppose.

The figures which he has agreed to are $50,000 for 1983-84; $217,000 for 1984- 85; $263,000 for 1985-86; $269,000 for 1986-87; and $350,000 for the remainder of the seven-year guarantee period which the Australian National University sought. I repeat that I am indeed grateful to the Minister for Finance for the help in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a follow-up question of the Minister for Defence. In the light of his previous answer is he aware that there was an exchange of notes between Australia and the United States of America regarding the furnishing of supplies and services to naval vessels which did not distinguish between services to be provided to nuclear and non-nuclear vessels? The notes were tabled, slightly amended, in this House in 1957 and were again drawn to the notice of honourable members in 1963. Is he aware that article 3 of this agreement requires each government to supply services such as overhauling, repairs, alterations, installation of equipment, together with incidental supplies, to visiting naval vessels of the other government? Would the Minister agree that the provisions of this agreement constitute the basis of a policy under which the Royal Navy's request would be made for the dry docking of Invincible to be performed in Australia? Why does the Minister deny that any policy was in force? Will the Minister confirm to this House that there will be no repetition henceforth of the Invincible fiasco?
—Firstly, the answer to the right honourable gentleman's specific question is no. Secondly, I have set out the agreed position of the three governments concerned and that stands.

—I address a question to the Treasurer. In view of the pessimistic statements made yesterday by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition about the state of the Australian economy would the Treasurer be in a position-by dint, I suppose, of the same good fortune to which the Foreign Affairs Minister referred --
—Order! The honourable member should proceed with his question.
—Would the Treasurer be in a position to advise the House of any additional information which further confirms the success of the Government's economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just so happens that figures for the December quarter national accounts were released this morning. I assure the House, including the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and particularly my colleagues the members of the Government, that these figures are cause for much pleasure on the part of the Government in particular and, I should hope, the Parliament in general. Mr Speaker, you may recall that when the September national accounts came out the growth in gross domestic product in that quarter was 4.4 per cent, the highest rate recorded since the quarterly figures had been published. I am now in a position to advise the House that that figure has been revised upwards to 5 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The accounts show that growth for the first six months of this year was running at 6.9 per cent; that was 5 per cent for September and 1.9 per cent for December . If we were to repeat, as I think is possible, the 1.9 per cent in the two ensuing quarters in March and June we would easily exceed the 10 per cent rate of growth through the year that I forecast a week ago. Indeed the prospect is that that figure will be exceeded.

Of course, one of the claims that have been made against the Government in respect of the pick-up in activity this year is that all the growth was coming off the farm and government sectors and that really everything was just going to fall in a heap when the growth in the farm sector and what have you finished. In the December quarter national accounts the contribution from government expenditure was in fact negative for the quarter, as was the contribution from the farm sector. Yet growth in the non-farm sector was 2.2 per cent. I am not in the business of annualising figures but lest any colleague in the Parliament confuse the 2.2 per cent with a low figure I state that based on that one quarter, if we were to do the old Phil Lynch trick, it would annualise at somewhere between 8 per cent and 9 per cent. In fact growth of 2.2 per cent in non-farm gross domestic product in one quarter is very strong indeed.

In the national accounts we have seen the first positive contribution from private capital expenditure for the first time in six quarters. With consumption revealed as running very strongly in the accounts we now have a significant contribution coming from the private sector. Therefore, the claim that this is all because of the farms and all that stimulus coming off the Commonwealth and State Budgets is simply untrue. There is now a strong and significant contribution coming through from the private sector. As well today retail sales figures have been published which show an increase. Motor vehicle sales are up.

While I am on this subject let me say in respect of the national accounts that inflation for the calendar year 1983, and I think the Parliament should listen to this, as measured by the broad implicit price deflator-that is not just the consumer price index, as my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong is always pointing out-was 6.1 per cent. There were no Medicare fiddles. The broadest deflator was 6.1 per cent. That is a lot different from the 11.5 per cent legacy of the former Government. It is a lot different from the 11.5 per cent increase in the consumer price index and the 12 per cent to 13 per cent on the implicit price deflator of a year ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have halved it.

—It has been halved. The inflation rate, on the broadest of deflators , has been cut by half to 6.1 per cent. Let me also indicate to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that company profits for the last 12 months have rebounded very sharply, rising by 39 per cent over the year-the highest since 1973-with the profit share to gross domestic product being higher than in any year under the Fraser Government. So much for the continuing business support for the--
—I hope the Treasurer is rounding off his answer.

—I am right on the answer, Mr Speaker. What the national accounts make clear-and it now becomes a matter of history rather than a matter of speculation or forecasting-is that Australia has a very strong pick-up in demand . We have a strong profit performance. We have consumer spending and confidence up. We have a strong contribution from the private sector. With those conditions in place, as both the Prime Minister and I have said in the last few weeks, that lays the preconditions for a continuing pick-up in private investment in the economy. It is a stunning turnaround in the economy and it more than lays the foundation for continued economic growth in Australia, for a true non- inflationary recovery. At this point in time let me say, without gilding the lily in the slightest, that the Government can be very proud of this result.

—I refer the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to the call in October last year by the Minister for Industry and Commerce for a halt in the escalation of labour on-costs. I ask: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a recent study by the Business Council of Australia which shows that the hourly on-costs of employing labour increased by 14.4 per cent over the calendar year 1983 and that these on-costs now add 53 per cent to the direct costs of employing people? Does the Minister accept the logic of avoiding increases in real direct costs under current economic circumstances and that that logic extends also to indirect costs? In recognising that job security and retirement incomes now rate ahead of wages as employee priorities, what does the Government intend to do to ensure that the claim for improved superannuation is not granted in addition to wage increases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the survey which was published by the Business Council of Australia and which showed some rather startling figures in respect of labour on-costs which, of course, are not all paid as a result of payments to employees but are paid because of things such as payroll tax which are not attributable to either the unions or the workers on the job but to government decisions. However , I say to the honourable member that he should be cautious in utilising this kind of survey because we do not have any official figures on on-costs. Various surveys have been conducted over the past few years by various employer organisations, all of which have come up with quite different figures.

ANSWER.PARA: The Business Council of Australia survey, which was published recently, was the same survey, covering the same companies and using the same questionnaire as the Australian Industries Development Association survey the previous year. Yet the December 1982 survey-the same survey conducted a year later but for the same period-showed an increae of 8.6 per cent as at December 1982, which does not make any sense. Over the course of the year December 1982 to December 1983 the Business Council's survey showed that there had been a 3.3 per cent increase in wage costs and a 14.4 per cent increase in labour on-costs. I found this very difficult to understand.

On looking more closely at the survey I found that there were some quite inexplicable elements in it. For instance we are told that public holiday costs went up 25 per cent. Since there were no more public holidays in 1983 than there were in 1982 I find that difficult to understand. We are told that leave loading costs went up 16.7 per cent and that leave costs went up 23 per cent. That I understand may have something to do with the fact that more employees in some industries were asked to take more leave in 1983, for instance, to use up their long service leave because of the dire state of the economy. They were using up an entitlement which was not accruing any faster in 1983 than in previous years.

In regard to the other elements of the survey such as employee amenities and safety provisions, the survey shows an increase of over 20 per cent. On further investigation it turns out that this was because depreciation costs on employee amenities were allocated over fewer workers as there were fewer employees in those companies which were surveyed. Therefore, the cost per employee was higher . I think we need to fully understand exactly what is being put to us when we are told that labour on-costs increased in this way. Clearly some parts of the survey are not at all explicable. Other parts are clearly to do with the fact that the recession has created greater costs per employee.

If the honourable member compares labour on-costs in Australia with those overseas as published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in 1979, he will see that our figures, even accepting the Business Council's figures, are not higher than those generally applying in other countries. Nevertheless having said all that, can I say to the honourable member that the Government would, of course, be concerned if there were a surge of labour on-costs and if this were found to be a way of getting around the wage indexation guidelines in some concerted way. Therefore we are concerned about that.

We are aware that there is a move for increased superannuation entitlements or for superannuation entitlements to be extended. At the present time that is occurring particularly in the building industry. That, of course, is not unique. It has developed under various wage systems in the past, including the previous wage indexation system when superannuation schemes were negotiated continuously throughout that period. We are concerned that those superannuation schemes which are developed are genuine superannuation schemes. We have been concerned to do that in the building industry. We have also asked the Australian Council of Trade Unions to give us an assurance that there will not be some rash of claims for superannuation schemes to take the place of wage claims which might otherwise have existed but for the wage indexation guildelines. The ACTU has given us an assurance that there will not be a rash of superannuation claims. Of course there may be other superannuation claims. However, there will not be a widespread rash of such claims but an orderly process at much the same pace that has been going on for over a decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Will the Minister inform the House of the progress made by the Government in implementing its community employment program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to inform the honourable member that the community employment program, which is the largest labour market program ever put into place in this country, is being successfully implemented and will, in the course of this year, assist 40,000 people to obtain employment. As at 9 March, honourable members may be interested to know, 4,419 projects had been approved, involving 29,328 jobs. A further 966 projects have been recommended and are waiting approval. Involved in them are another 4,333 jobs. So altogether, approved or awaiting approval, are 33,661 jobs. In terms of the number of jobs actually on the ground, some 1,350 projects have been commenced, with approximately 10,000 people working at the present time. That number will increase very rapidly as the projects which have been approved are put into place. As I have said, we will have approximately 40,000 people at work by the end of this financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to say that the targets of the program are being very substantially achieved. Some 94 per cent of the jobs are going to those who have been unemployed continuously for more than three months. About 35 per cent of the jobs approved are expected to be filled by women, which does fall short of the 50 per cent target which the Government set itself. However, if one excludes the jobs on local roads component, which has been excluded from that target, it comes up to 40 per cent. We expect that percentage to increase further.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that members of the Opposition are not at all interested in the unemployed. I can understand their not being interested in this answer and being more interested in the shenanigans of the honourable member for Hume. As I was saying in regard to the target for women, approximately 40 per cent of the jobs outside the jobs on local roads component are being taken up by women. We expect that percentage to increase as more community group projects are approved in the course of this year. The House may also be interested to know that 7.4 per cent of the total jobs approved have been taken up by Aborigines; 3.5 per cent by disabled persons; and 2.7 per cent by migrants with language difficulties. In summary, I think the program is being successfully implemented. It is an enormous source of satisfaction to me and to the Government that this program will this year provide about 40,000 jobs for people who, in the main, because of their disadvantaged position in the labour market would have had little chance of getting a job, even in the context of the very strongly growing economy which the Treasurer has outlined to us today.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is a significant difference between the prices at which at least Australian uranium has actually been sold over the last couple of years and the spot price.
