TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the appropriate course is either to take the question on notice or, alternatively, to try to get a response for the honourable member from my colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy in the course of the day and it can be interpolated in the program later on. But it would not be appropriate for me to try to second guess what the Minister for Resources and Energy was saying as I was not involved in the discussion.

—I ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs whether he can comment on reports that Chinese officials will soon approach the Australian Government with a proposal to allow 10,000 Chinese guest workers--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member has asked the Minister for a comment.
—I ask the honourable member to repeat his question. A point of order has been raised as to whether the question is in order. I would like to hear it again.

—Is the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware of reports that Chinese officials will soon approach the Australian Government with a proposal to allow 10,000 Chinese guest workers into the country? Is the Minister concerned at the increasing number of mischievous, racist propaganda statements being peddled within Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say quite categorically that there will be no guest workers allowed into Australia either from the People's Republic of China or from any other nation. Under the current Government policy it is simply not possible for such reports to be accurate. Our immigration programs are conducted under a number of categories-family reunion, refugees, skilled labour, employer nomination and business migration being the main ones. The House will see that no category would provide for such a scheme of guest workers. Under the employer nomination scheme, not more than 3,000 people will be granted entry to Australia in this financial year. The criteria for those people to be admitted are that the job is not capable of being filled from within the Australian labour market, that the prospective employer has adequately tested and advertised within the Australian labour market and has made attempts to train a prospective employee. Further, such jobs as are filled from overseas by employer nominations are generally filled in that way because other jobs of resident Australian workers may be dependent upon such jobs being filled from overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite frankly-and now I come to what I think is the bitter heart of the matter- I question the motive behind the increasing numbers of reports about the so- called excessive immigration program and the so-called Asianisation of that program. Learned pundits in some sections of the newspaper medium urge me to accept 400,000 or 500,000 migrants a year to put a bonfire under the economy so to speak, as they allege is possible. On the other hand, a spate of articles urges us to conduct a moratorium on all immigration, because they question why migrants should take the jobs of Australian workers. Then we get a digression into this false argument regarding favoured Asian immigration. I have already successfully put that argument to rest once and for all in the media in this country. Despite what Professor Blainey or any other learned, respected academic or pundit might say, there is no favouritism or discrimination in our immigration programs; nor will there be. What is more, I do not really think there was discrimination in the programs of the former Government. I hope we can get a bipartisan approach on this matter to quash these increasingly irrational and irrelevant charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the honourable member for Denison say about that?
—I hope the honourable member for Denison in future will take a long, hard look at his public comments.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. We have had three ministerial statements today, one from the Treasurer, one from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and now another report from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. This is not the time that they should be doing such a thing. They can make a ministerial statement at any time.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member knows the rulings in the past about the length of answers.

—I repeat: There is no favouritism or discrimination in any category of the migration program, be it in the family reunion, the refugees or the business migration category. In the business migration category, not more than 2,000 people will come to Australia this year. In the family reunion category the figure is something like 40,000. When people attack our family reunion program and say that we are deliberately Asianising it because the Asian component has gone up from 25 per cent to 40 per cent, they are talking about the component going up by 6,000 Asians. When it is reduced to those figures, we see how mean, petty and trivial are these charges.

ANSWER.PARA: I simply conclude on this note: All of those people in this country, including anyone on the Opposition benches who may be contemplating taking this false argument any further, should ask themselves: How rational and logical is it to argue that we should be taking care of our regional trading partners, to expect that we can increase trade with all of the Asian countries, from Japan right through to Indonesia, and, at the same time, argue that because a few more thousand Asians may be coming in-not under any favouritism but because they can simply take advantage of a global program-we should, in effect, be condemning them because they want to come in those small numbers to this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism to the recent interpretation of the Broadcasting and Television Act by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in relation to the advertising of tobacco products. What action does the Government intend to take to remove the uncertainty now existing within the television industry and the sport and arts communities because of the potential financial loss of sponsorship for sport and the arts? Does the Minister accept the right of anybody or any group to accept or to reject sponsors according to their own policy?

—My views on this subject are very well known, so I will not canvass them. The Minister for Communications should really be answering this question as the legislation affects his portfolio. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has interpreted that legislation as it is written. Whatever future action is taken by the Government in this area is the direct responsibility of the Minister for Communications.

—Will the Minister for Finance and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Industrial Matters inform the Parliament what progress is being made towards the introduction of the Public Service reform package announced by the Government in the White Paper released last December?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I record the fact of her continuing very close interest in the development of the Government's proposals in this regard. Following the publication of the policy paper late last year I have been involved in a very extensive round of consultations with the unions representing public servants and with the authors of the recent reports on the Public Service and public administration generally, including Mr Reid and Dr Coombs, and the honourable member for Bradfield as well as, of course, the honourable member for Canberra. As a result of those discussions, the Government has now finalised its position and will be moving to the introduction of legislation to effect the changes as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of those consultations a small number of relatively minor changes were made to the proposals which really go to the question of strengthening the merit principle within the Public Service in a way which was in accordance with both our policy and the desires of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the unions affiliated with it. So in relation to the question of transfers and the selection of public servants regard will be had to criteria spelling out how selections and transfers should be made and so on. No major changes have been made to the proposals--
An incident having occurred in the Gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite honourable members to retain their seats until the Gallery is cleared. Had the Minister for Finance concluded his answer?

—No, but I am very close to finishing, Mr Speaker. I indicate that as a result of those consultations it is now clear that there is very wide support, not only within the Public Service but also from people outside the Public Service, for the proposals with which we are proceeding. It is recognised that as a result of those changes which are of a historic nature the Public Service will be more flexible and efficient. This will lead to better government generally. I will provide the honourable member with a more detailed statement of the precise details of the additional changes which have been made since the consultation.
—Mr Speaker, under the Standing Orders can I ask the Minister to table the document from which he was reading?
—Was the Minister quoting from a public document?
—No, I was not.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Primary Industry recall giving a recent interview to the Stock and Land newspaper in which he admitted that he was unhappy with his Government's massive 200 per cent increase in meat export inspection charges? Was the Minister correctly reported? He is reported to have said:

QUESTION.PARA: It's not my personal stance . . . I couldn't win on that issue . . .

Can the Minister explain why he was unable to convince his Cabinet colleagues of the hardship that such a massive increase will cause to an industry already suffering from the combined effects of a devastating drought and depressed world markets? What action will he take to rectify the situation as indicated by him?

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable gentleman well knows, I used the phrase: 'I couldn't win on that issue . . '. That expression is understood by people. As I have said constantly in this House and outside, the reason I could not win on this issue was that it had been the policy of the previous Government since 1979. It was entrenched by the previous Government when Peter Nixon, as Minister for Primary Industry, was on the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, the so- called razor gang, and the policy was re-emphasised then.

—Order! I think I should clarify a matter. When attention is drawn to a matter with regard to standing order 321 two questions should be asked of the Minister. The first question is: Is it a document relating to public affairs? I used the words 'public document'. The second question is: 'Is it confidential?'. I think that in the circumstances I should readdress the question in the proper form. I ask the Minister for Finance: Was it a document relating to public affairs?
—I was not reading from any document. I had a document in front of me . No doubt the Opposition would be happy to see it in the form of a Press statement at some stage.
—There is no need to debate the matter. I had to correct the form of the question I asked. I call the honourable member for Diamond Valley.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. I am sure that the Minister is aware that today the Parliament has been visited by the 'People for Public Housing.' What does the Government intend to do to alleviate housing-related poverty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an understatement to say that there is far too much housing- related poverty in this community. It is a fact that if the amount of money appropriated for housing in the 1975-76 Hayden Budget had been continued during the seven years of the Liberal-Country Party coalition, another $3,750m would have been spent on public housing in those intervening years.

ANSWER.PARA: It is no wonder that there is all this housing-related poverty in our community . The problem is particularly prevalent in Victoria. I will go through some of the statistics about the numbers of public dwellings per thousand of population. In my State of South Australia there are 36 per thousand. In New South Wales there are 17 per thousand. In Victoria, where most of these people come from, there are nine per thousand. That is because the Bolte, Hamer and Thompson governments in particular sold off the public housing stock of that State. It is no wonder that we have demonstrations such as the unfortunate one we experienced today when we have that sort of record from these discredited people who are now trying to interject.

Most of the problem in this housing-related poverty area is due to the fact that so many people have to rely on the private rental market, and 60 per cent of those in the private rental market are spending more than half their income on rent. Many of those people have only a social security benefit as income. It is no wonder that there is such anger in the community in relation to this subject at present.

In order to make this even clearer, I inform the House that at the moment in this country there are only 250,000 public dwellings and, on any assessment, about 350,000 family units needing public housing. This Government has embarked on the task of overcoming this terrible problem. Firstly, we are reducing the demand for that public housing by what we have done in the private home ownership sector through the first home owners scheme. Secondly, we have increased our appropriation for public housing enormously. We increased it by 50 per cent in the last Budget from $333m to $500m. We also increased the appropriation for the States so that the States and the Territories could match the amount that we are appropriating for public housing.

All in all, in the current financial year there has been a 24 per cent increase in the appropriation for public housing to $1.3 billion. That contrasts with the fact that in real terms the reduction over the seven years of the Fraser Government was 40 per cent. Certainly we have now turned the tide back somewhat, but there is a long way to go and that is why we are renegotiating the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement at present. I acknowledge that demonstrations of the sort we had today are probably not the best way of bringing this problem to the attention of the community, but I also pay tribute to those groups which are seeking to make the problem known in the community. They include not only this group but also Shelter, the Australian Council of Churches, the Australian Council of Social Service, the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace and many other institutions which are seeking to make this problem known.

At least those institutions are sincere, which is more than can be said for the honourable member for Hume. That grubby action of his has already been condemned by a great number of people on both sides of this House. I declare that it is time the Leader of the Opposition took some action and got rid of him from the front bench of the Opposition. It is a pity that the Leader of the Opposition is not here today to hear this claim made.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you breach national security you can stay on the front bench. That is all right!
—I can understand your problems with national security. That doesn't matter!

—I notice that the Leader of the National Party is interjecting. We cannot expect such standards from him to get rid of the honourable member for Hume, but I believe the Leader of the Opposition should take up the onus now and get rid of this insincerity from his front bench and make sure that something genuine is done about housing-related poverty in this community.

—My question, which is addressed to the Treasurer, is about the national account figures in respect of which he waxed so lyrical a few minutes ago. Do those national income figures reveal a 5.6 per cent increase in wages in the December quarter, the highest figure since the September quarter 1974 and more than the previous five quarters put together? Did this result in a fall in the growth of gross operating surpluses of non-farm trading enterprises from 9.9 per cent in September to 3.1 per cent in December? Did the reduction in the implicit price deflator over 1983 to 6.1 per cent, revealed in the national income figures and lauded by the honourable gentleman, depend on the benefits of the wages pause which was prematurely ended by the Hawke Government? Does the worrying rise in the non-farm implicit price deflator from the September figure of 0.5 per cent to a December figure of 2.1 per cent reflect the consequences of the Government's premature return to full wage indexation?
—Of course, there will have been some wage movement in the December quarter accounts.
—Some! It is the highest since 1974.

—Just hang on. The main reason for that 5.6 per cent figure is strong employment growth. That is the reason it is in there, not simply because of the 4.3 per cent moving through. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition can shake his head until it falls off; that is the fact. He may want to deny that there is strong employment growth in this country, but the fact is that there is-and it is in the accounts. Therefore, once one accepts that premise all the other elements of the honourable member's question fall apart.
—I understand that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition seeks my indulgence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Speaker. I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —When the House comes to order I will invite the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to go on with his explanation.

—Where is 'new idealism'-the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins)? In addressing the National Press Club yesterday the Minister for Finance asserted that the $3,000m owing in disputed taxation was a result of the alleged neglect of the administration of taxation during the time I was Treasurer.
—That is right.
—Hang on, don't get too excited about it.
—Order! I remind the House that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is entitled to make his explanation and that honourable members should not interrupt that explanation by interjection.

—For the information of the Minister for Finance I should inform him and anybody else who is interested in the matter that that $3,000m represents payment of tax in dispute between the Commissioner of Taxation and individual taxpayers. A sizeable proportion of it is taxation due under tax avoidance schemes which were either outlawed or challenged during the time that the previous Government was in office. For the Minister or anybody else in the Government to assert that in some way we are to blame for that figure being outstanding is to distort the truth completely.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. My point of order is that the Minister should have included the $70,000--
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Canberra has indicated that she seeks my indulgence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker. I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member claims to have been misrepresented?
—That is right.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I speak in my capacity as a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts and as chairperson of the sectional committee on medical fraud and overservicing. On Tuesday in the Senate committee rooms a media conference was held and a statement released on a report by the Rupert Public Interest Movement entitled 'Medifraud-A professionally induced cancer'. The Public Accounts Committee was misrepresented in the media release and the report. The Rupert document alleged that the Public Accounts Committee, in its medical fraud inquiry, neglected to address in its progress report the issue of the quality of senior management in the Department of Health. It further alleged that the Committee was inactive during 1983 and that it failed to protect key witnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a document, which I do not propose to read, Mr Speaker, refuting these points of detail. I seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. The honourable member knows the guidelines for incorporating documents in Hansard, and that is not within them. She may, however, table it.
—That being so, Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish, then, to make brief comments on the allegations.

—No. The honourable member must realise that she is allowed to explain where she has been personally misrepresented. As she has been chairperson of that sub-committee, I have allowed her to proceed, because I think that it is in the interests of the Parliament that that misrepresentation be corrected. But the honourable member cannot debate the matter, and to go through a rebuttal of the arguments in any extraneous paper is clearly debate and not correcting a personal misrepresentation.
—What I shall do then, Mr Speaker, if leave is granted, is to table a document. Would that be appropriate? May I have leave to explain where I was misrepresented?
—No. The honourable member is misusing the process of making a personal explanation in regard to misrepresentation. I think that there are other occasions on which she could correct this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable member may proceed with a personal explanation.

—In the Age newspaper of yesterday there appeared an article in relation to the amendments moved by the Opposition to the Government's resolution on Aboriginal affairs. That article started off: 'Don't call blacks first owners, says Opposition'. I think that that misinterprets the Opposition's views. I quote from the Australian Associated Press report of the Press conference that I held in relation to that matter, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular the Opposition felt the term 'conquest' used in the original wording relating to white settlement could be seen as Parliament supporting arguments in favour of Aboriginal sovereignty and a separate Aboriginal nation.
I think that the Age statement goes a lot further than the statement that I made .
The second misrepresentation appeared in the Canberra Times of yesterday. The specific paragraph to which I refer is a statement by the Canberra Times, as follows:
The Opposition spokesman on Aboriginal affairs, Mr Porter (Lib, SA), said that Australia's mineral industry was more important to the national interest than giving Aborigines control.
I admit that that statement is not in inverted commas, but I should like to explain that that is not what I said. What I said was:

Our resolution proposes that we ensure a just and reasonable framework which enables mining to take place on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land on terms, particularly with regard to access and compensation, which pay proper regard to both their social and cultural interests and to the national interest in the development of Australia's mineral resources . . .

In this way we seek to ensure in relation to mining on Aboriginal land, the terms and conditions of approval should take into account the unique Aboriginal interests in land, especially land on which traditional owners continue to reside.

DEBATE.TITLE: REORGANISED PORTFOLIO RESPONSIBILITIES IN ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable members will be aware that in the period since the Hawke Government took office on 5 March 1983, considerable changes have occurred in the Aboriginal Affairs Ministry which are designed to put authority and responsibility firmly into Aboriginal hands. As I have indicated previously to the Parliament, since this Government came into office Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leaders have been directly and decisively involved in the development of policy and its implementation. To further this involvement consultation with Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders has been reinforced at all levels and through their specialist organisations. Throughout this period of quite significant development, the Government has been considering more fundamental changes to the distribution of portfolio responsibilities to support further development of independent Aboriginal leadership and to improve the effectiveness of the portfolio's delivery of services to the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of these developments and discussions throughout the portfolio, the Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr John Taylor, put to me a number of proposals for change in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. One of his suggestions was that the activities of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio would be enhanced by the appointment of a suitable Aboriginal to the position of Secretary to the Department. He was mindful that as we come to 1988, our bicentennial year, with many and strengthening indications of Aboriginal support and understanding for this landmark, we also faced important decisions about national land rights and sacred sites in particular, and also many other issues where a balanced approach could be aided by the right appointment. I am pleased to be able to inform the House that the Governor-General has today approved the Goverment's recommendation that Mr Charles Perkins be appointed Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

This is an historic appointment at a significant stage in Aborignal development . Mr Perkins, who has given distinguished service to the Aboriginal movement, is the first Aboriginal to be appointed head of a Commonwealth Government department. Mr Perkins is well known to members of this Parliament and throughout the country. He has continued to fight for equality and justice for Aboriginal Australians; he has made achievements over the years which all Australians, I am sure, would applaud. Aboriginal people have cause to be proud of those achievements.

Mr Perkins was born on an Aboriginal reserve on the Todd River. One of 11 children, Mr Perkins's mother was of Arunta descent and his father was Kalkadoon descent. Educated in Alice Springs, Adelaide and Sydney, he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts Degree from Sydney University in 1964, having previously worked in a variety of occupations. Quite early in his life he became associated with the Aboriginal movement and in 1969 joined the Commonwealth Public Service in the former Office of Aboriginal Affairs. Mr Perkins has had a succession of administrative appointments in Aboriginal Affairs, rising to the position of Deputy Secretary in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in September 1979. He was the first Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission on its creation in July 1980, an initiative of the previous Government. Mr Perkins has been involved in the creation and achievements of the Aboriginal Development Commission, which has incorporated in its Act recognition of the past dispossession and dispersal of Aboriginal people. This was the first time such recognition was incorporated in an Act of the Commonwealth Parliament.

I know that honourable members will join with me in wishing Mr Perkins well in his new appointment. For my part, as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I look forward to working with him to continue to enhance the situation of Aboriginal Australians.

Mr Perkins will assist me in the implementation of a major restructuring of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. As a consequence of Mr Perkins's resignation as Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission, I have appointed Mrs Shirley McPherson of Western Australia as Acting Chairman of the Commission, and Mr Mick Miller of Queensland as Acting Deputy Chairman. Both appointments are to be on a part time basis.

The Government has decided to establish a new Aboriginal Housing Authority to provide a focus under Aboriginal leadership for all housing functions in the portfolio. Such a fundamental reorganisation is long overdue. It is intended that this new authority will incorporate the existing grant-in-aid housing function which the Aboriginal Development Commission acquired from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in June 1982. It will also assume the functions of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, a company which has provided accommodation for Aboriginals throughout the nation.

The new Aboriginal Housing Authority will be asked to find solutions to the housing needs of various Aboriginal groups across Australia, be they on outstations, town dwellers or those who have opted for a less settled form of lifestyle. It will promote the development of appropriate Aboriginal housing technology and the employment and training of Aboriginals in the building and maintenance trade. Certain related functions associated with the provision of infrastructures for housing will be transferred to the new Aboriginal Housing Authority from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The Chairman of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, Miss Lois O'Donoghue, CBE, AM, has agreed to accept the position of full time chairperson of Aboriginal Hostels Limited to assist in the implementation of these arrangements and the development of new authority.

These changes will enable the Aboriginal Development Commission to concentrate on the social and economic development of Aboriginal people through its functions associated with the acquisition of land, housing loans and enterprises . It will continue to implement the Government's commitment to overcoming the many disadvantages which Aboriginals face through their past dispossession and dispersal. It will be through mechanisms such as the Aboriginal Development Commission that the Government will seek to achieve equality and self- determination for Aboriginal Australians. I will be taking this opportunity to examine the ways the delivery of services in this most important area might be rationalised. The Government will be considering the report of Dr H. C. Coombs on the National Aboriginal Conference and this may lead to some additional restructuring of the portfolio aimed at further positively enhancing the role of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in policy formulation, budgeting and program delivery. Discussions are being held with the relevant unions and staff associations on the new development, and work will begin immediately to ensure that there is an orderly implementation after consultation with Aboriginal organisations.

In informing the House of these arrangements I wish to thank the former Secretary of the Department, Mr John Taylor. Through his involvement in these initiatives and by stepping aside on his own initiative Mr Taylor has, I believe , been a part of what will be seen in years to come as a very significant advance in the concept of self-determination for Aboriginal people. Mr Taylor has actively pursued the development of the new arrangements with a view to enhancing Aboriginal leadership and involvement in all aspects of the Government 's Aboriginal Affairs programs. The needs of the Aboriginal community have placed considerable pressure on the officers within the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. The Secretary has had to ensure that the Government's policies were pursued in a prompt manner and I wish to express my personal appreciation to Mr Taylor and his officers for their efforts in this regard.

A great deal has been achieved in the last decade since the Whitlam Government put in place the arrangements on which we are now building. That a great deal more needs to be done is readily acknowledged on both sides of this House. This Government stands for reconciliation. That reconciliation will not be achieved until there is a recognition by both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal of the worth of each other in a multicultural society where each has an important role to play and a contribution to make. Mr Perkins assumes the position of secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs at a crucial time in our history. I call on the Parliament and this nation to recognise the efforts of this Government in taking initiatives which will help bring this nation together and overcome the very many difficulties which Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders face in Australia today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The statement to the House by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) deals with two matters: Firstly, the announcement of the appointment of Mr Charles Perkins as head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and, secondly, certain aspects of the restructuring of organisations within the responsibility of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. It is a very general statement and its generality gives rise to a number of important questions which the Minister has failed to address. The Minister is now becoming well known for his hasty and ill-considered statements. In his efforts to make changes in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio overnight, he consistently fails to adequately consider the implications of his proposals. As I have said before both in this House and outside, the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio is a sensitive one and the Minister time and again fails properly to address his mind to the consequences and ramifications of his impetuous statements. This often results in the raising of expectations amongst the Aboriginal community, which expectations he does not live up to.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement raises many questions in relation to both the appointment of Mr Perkins and the restructuring of certain organisations within the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. I refer firstly to the Minister's announcement that Mr Perkins is to be appointed head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. This appointment by the Government raises the general question of Aboriginal employment in the Public Service. The Opposition is concerned that there is a significant under-representation of Aboriginal people in our Public Service. Action needs to be taken to redress this situation. We are also deeply aware of the need for special programs-specifically, special education and training programs-to ensure that Aborigines are able to qualify for Public Service positions and obtain them on merit. The Opposition believes that it is extremely important, for the Aboriginal people themselves, for the rest of the Public Service and for the general public, that those appointed are competent to fulfil their role. It is therefore essential that the education and training programs to which I refer are implemented.

It has been widely suggested for some time that Mr Perkins would be appointed to the position of Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Therefore, this announcement comes as no surprise. A specific concern of the Opposition in relation to the appointment is the matter of timing. The Minister's statement does not indicate exactly when Mr Perkins is to take up his new position as Secretary to the Department. I raise this matter with the Minister because members of this House will be aware that the Standing Committee on Expenditure is currently undertaking an inquiry into the financial operations of the Aboriginal Development Commission. The ADC inquiry is one of a number which the Expenditure Committee is currently undertaking. Other areas being reviewed by that Committee include assistance to the arts, accommodation and home care for the aged, Telecom Australia's zoning charging policy and so on. In relation to the inquiry into the ADC, I understand that a submission has been sought from the ADC itself. I believe that Mr Perkins would have a valuable role in assisting the Committee with the submission from the ADC.

I raise the question of the timing of Mr Perkins's move from the chairmanship of the ADC to the position of Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs because I believe that, if he takes up his new appointment before the Committee undertakes its hearings, difficulties could emerge regarding a conflict of interest and questions of accountability. Such a conflict is not difficult to envisage, especially if the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is called to give evidence in relation to the ADC submission. Despite the fact that I raised this issue publicly last Sunday, the Minister has not indicated in his statement when Mr Perkins will take up his new appointment. The Opposition is of the view that the Government and the Minister ought at least to pay the parliamentary Committee the courtesy of delaying Mr Perkins's move pending the completion of the inquiry. I understand that the Committee does not envisage a lengthy inquiry and that therefore only a small delay in Mr Perkins taking up his new post would be required.

I turn now to the reorganisation of some Aboriginal authorities. The Minister has announced that there will be a new Aboriginal housing authority incorporating the existing grant-in-aid housing function from the ADC together with the functions of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. I have been made aware of serious concern in the Aboriginal community that this is only the first move towards a major restructuring of the portfolio responsibilities. The Minister made reference to that in his statement and I believe he should clarify his intentions to this Parliament. I have said for some time that I believe it would be appropriate to bring the Aboriginal accommodation functions under one organisation. I note with some pleasure that the Minister has now acted on that suggestion. I have been concerned that, with the increasing growth of the ADC and the number of functions being absorbed by the ADC, the variety of functions must make it difficult for the ADC to be an efficient organisation covering, for example, housing, enterprise-orientated operations, and more recently, the Aboriginal Sports Foundation and the Aboriginal Arts and Crafts Co. It was in light of this growth of ADC functions last year that I believed it would be more sensible to separate out Aboriginal housing and combine it with Aboriginal Hostels Ltd.

Certainly-as the Minister stated and I agree-housing is one of the most pressing problems confronting the Aboriginal community. The House will recall that recently, both the Minister and I made statements in relation to the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs entitled 'Strategies to Help Overcome the Problems of Aboriginal Town Campers'. In our response both the Minister and I highlighted the grave situation facing fringe dwellers and town campers around Australia. In addition, there is no doubt that there are similar problems for Aborigines on many reserves and indeed in traditional areas. It is an area demanding high priority.
I referred to the Minister's response to the fringe dwellers report on 1 March. In that speech the Minister said:
The task of providing accommodation will be shared by my Department--
that is, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs--

the Aboriginal Development Commission, Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, and the Department of Social Security through its homeless persons assistance program, as well as the States. All of these agencies will be responsible, with the National Aboriginal Conference, for consultation about housing.

So at the beginning of this month, the Minister was convinced apparently that the task of providing Aboriginal accommodation was to be shared by the Department, the Aboriginal Development Commission, Aboriginal Hostels and the Department of Social Security, in consultation with the NAC. Now, 28 days later, the Minister has had a sudden and radical change of mind and these functions are to be subsumed by the Aboriginal Housing Authority. This highlights the total lack of planning and policy direction under this Minister. His erratic shooting from the hip style of approach to his portfolio highlights his atrocious administration of his portfolio. Instead of trying to impose uniform land rights on the States when they are in the process of legislating for land rights themselves, he ought to be concentrating on the efficient delivery of services and assistance to overcome the disadvantages facing the Aboriginal community.

But it is not just in the Minister's March statement that his lack of adequate planning of the administration of his portfolio is revealed. The Aboriginal Hostels annual report for 1982-83 at page 5 states that the Government agreed last November to review the Aboriginal Hostels charter because it believed the original charter needed to be brought up to date in order that Aboriginal Hostels could 'work more efficiently and with the authority and autonomy it deserves'. I ask the Minister: In the five months since that statement was made, what work has been done in reviewing the charter of Aboriginal Hostels within the framework of its then responsibility which is now irrelevant, given the reorganisation announced today.

There are a number of issues which the Minister should have explained in relation to this reorganisation which he has failed to address. Firstly, the Government often professes its policy of consultation with Aboriginal organisations. I wonder whether consultation was entered into before this reorganisation was finalised. Certainly I am aware of concern amongst Aboriginal communities and others about where this Government is taking Aboriginal affairs, and I wonder whether the NAC, supposedly the Government's chief adviser, was consulted about this matter or merely told last Sunday that it was going to occur.

Secondly, the Minister has not explained which Aboriginal housing functions will be transferred to the new Aboriginal Housing Authority. He has said that certain related functions associated with the provision of infrastructure for housing will be transferred from the DAA. We are not told which are the functions to which he refers. The third issue I raise is that the ADC is to maintain its housing loan funding. Again, the Minister has not explained why he has separated this from the other housing functions. I can only assume that he believes that these functions, given to the Aboriginal Housing Authority will be welfare orientated, whereas housing loans, perhaps in the Minister's mind, are a separate issue. This matter ought to be clarified by the Minister.

The fourth area where the Minister is desperately short on detail is in relation to the administrative changes in the area of personnel. Presumably, the aim of the reorganisation is to have a lean and efficient Aboriginal housing authority and, similarly, a lean and efficient ADC in order that the greatest possible proportion of funds provided for the Aboriginal people actually reach those to whom they are directed and are not absorbed in administration. One would assume that within the ADC and the DAA there is a store of expertise in relation to Aboriginal housing. The Minister has not indicated whether these personnel will be transferred. For example, I trust that the new organisation will not merely duplicate the existing organisations. Just how much Aboriginal Affairs money has been spent in the last six months in organising the Aboriginal housing function which will now be totally wasted because of the Minister's lack of planning, his lack of policy direction and his lack of foresight.

The fifth issue which the Minister has not addressed is the renegotiation being undertaken under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The ADC was supposedly playing a major role in consultations involved in that renegotiation. I ask the Minister: Will it continue to have that role or will it be assumed by the new Housing Authority? These are all questions that I believe deserve answers in this place.

The Minister has made some other organisational changes which are not included in this statement. He has transferred the Aboriginal Sports Foundation to the ADC and he is in the process of having the Aboriginal Arts and Crafts Co. transferred to the ADC. Neither of these transfers has been handled well and there is concern about this Minister's ability to make such changes in a business-like manner. The morale of the Minister's Department is low because of the Minister's erratic behaviour. It is clear that the Minister needs to apply himself to the proper administration of his portfolio, instead of racing around the country picking fights with his State colleagues and making ill-considered statements.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bass (Nr Newman) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's inept handling in allowing the dangerous run-down of the army in this country thus threatening the security of the Australian people and its territories.
I call upon those members who approved of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to a question I asked the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) on 2 March in this place, inter alia he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the figures given by the honourable member are correct-and I do not dispute them-they are exactly the figures which existed at the time when he went out of office as a Minister of the Crown.

By making that statement and a number of other comments in articles and newspapers, the Minister has either set out to mislead the nation or, because he does not know what is going on in a crucial area of his portfolio, has continually demonstrated a massive ignorance and incompetence.

What is the actual situation? The Australian Army's ability to deal with low and mid-level threats depends on the Regular Division. This is the basic force structure which would be needed to meet an immediate threat or which would be capable of rapid expansion as a threat became apparent.

That function has become even more significant in this last year because of a deteriorating situation in our own region, with the considerable build-up of the Soviet Union in Vietnam and the Indian Ocean, the continuing problem of the conflict in Cambodia and the worrying tensions in West Irian and Papua New Guinea. In this last year the efficiency and capacity of the Division to meet a threat has become more urgent in the light of the Government's expressed policy of standing on our own feet without expecting others to help us. Thus, Australia 's strategic situation has changed. That is partly as a result of external factors and partly as a result of conscious decisions by the Hawke Government.

The Minister's response has not been to increase defence strength in response to the changed situation but to run down Australia's defences while at the same time claiming that the situation is satisfactory. On a number of counts the capability of the Army's Regular Division has been seriously blunted by the Hawke Government's policy and the inadequacies of the Minister for Defence. Cuts in a range of critical areas have been made in the last year. They include unit strengths, recruiting and reinforcement rates, resources for training and the Army Reserve.

I will deal firstly with unit strengths. All units in the division are restricted below their war establishment to special peacetime levels. A number of units have now been reduced below these peacetime authorisations. These reductions occurred in the last year. These units constitute the corps of the Regular Division. They should represent the cutting edge of a credible defence deterrent for Australia. To fall below the already dangerously low peacetime authorised establishment means that as fighting units they are not capable of either conducting effective training or carrying out their role in war.

To illustrate the point I will take the case of the 8-12 Medium Artillery Regiment. This unit provides all the artillery support for the 1st Brigade at Holsworthy. In operations its support would be indispensible. This unit is to be equipped with the newly purchased M198 153 millimetre howitzer from the United States of America. The efficient introduction of this new gun will be delayed because there will not be enough gunners trained to man the equipment as the gun comes on stream.

Again, take the case of the infantry battalions. The division is organised to have nine battalions. Of these, three are non-existent, two are organised on light scales in the Operational Deployment Force in Townsville and the remaining four are on greatly reduced peacetime establishments. The Government has allowed two of these four battalions to fall below already severely restricted strengths . This means that about one-half of what remains of the infantry units of the Division have lapsed below levels which might constitute a credible infantry fighting unit. These units might be able to conduct platoon or company training- just; but to train or fight as battalions would simply not be on.

However, the position is actually much worse. If the balloon goes up plans have already been laid to decimate the battalions in Enoggera to reinforce the Townsville battalions. This is a clear admission that the Operational Deployment Force at Townsville, earmarked to meet immediate low level threats, is not sufficiently manned to meet an emergency. It also means that in the Division we can expect to have only two very under-manned and badly equipped battalions presently training in an airborne and mechanised role.

I turn secondly to Army recruiting. Recruiting in 1983-84 has been reduced. Comparing January to June 1984 with the same period in 1983 shows that it is expected that the flow of recruits to the Army will be down by at least 15 per cent. This means that reinforcements to under-strength units in the Division will take place only at a trickle. The result of this Government action is that the dangerous situation which the Minister has allowed to develop in the Division cannot be corrected quickly. In fact, if retirement rates increase or re-engagement levels fall-which is not unlikely given the economic climate and the Government's meddling with conditions of service-the situation could well become worse. This stinginess is in sharp contrast to the Government's generosity in promoting a 10 per cent growth in the Public Service over the last two years.

Thirdly, as far as training is concerned, major restrictions have been placed on the activities of the Division. In the case of the 1st Brigade at Holsworthy- one of the key fighting formations in the Division-I instance examples of the prohibitive nature of these restrictions. The Brigade is allowed to exercise only every second year. Battalions are allowed to exercise only once a year. The Cavalry Regiment is allowed to train with tanks only every second year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is the on year?

—It gets much worse. Gunners on the Unit's fighting vehicles are restricted to only two rounds of 76-millimetre ammunition per year. It takes three rounds to range the gun. The Mechanised Infantry Battalion is allowed to train for only two weeks a year with the Tank Regiment at Puckapunyal.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not sufficient allocation of small arms ammunition for soldiers to complete the requirement for annual weapon training. Thus, incredible as it may be, infantry soldiers will not be able to become proficient in the use of their basic weapons. There is an acute shortage of small arms blanks and training pyrotechnics for exercises. Even the armed forces' freeze dried ration packs are on a very restricted availability. The availability of Royal Australian Air Force helicopters to the Army is almost non-existent. In infantry battalions 106 -millimetre anti-tank gun ammunition availability is sufficient only to introduce troops to the weapon, not to train them. I could go on and on.

There is a disastrous situation in relation to the Army Reserve. At present the Division would meet a low-level threat only with difficulty. Deficiencies I have described but also other grave weaknesses as in air defence, mobility, parachute capability, training and reserve stocks to name but a few, would make that task very hazardous. To sustain operations for any length of time, given the weaknesses in logistic support, would be difficult. This, of course, has been more than amply comfirmed in disclosures to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in recent days. But the Army's ability to meet a modest, mid -level threat is almost impossible. Given the wholesale reduction in the ability of the Division to go to war on its present Regular Army basis the availability of a trained Army Reserve to reinforce and augment the Division may be the only way a mid-level threat could now be met. The Army Reserve is rapidly reaching a stage where it will not be able to make that essential contribution.

Over the last year the Army Reserve has suffered a number of assaults from the Hawke Government which may have left it mortally wounded. The Government has hit reservists' fundamental conditions of service by taxing their pay. It has cut back their rations, petrol, transport and ammunition; it has savaged the number of training hours and it has even slashed voluntary, without pay, training activities. The Government has cut training hours for the Reserve so that many commanders in the Army, both Reserve and Regular, believe that it will be an impossible task to carry out efficient training. The restrictions mean that training will be confined to the most basic and elementary levels.

The fundamental need to integrate Reserve units with Regular units, particularly to fill the gaps in Regular units and formations, is now beyond reach. The fact is that the Army has significantly deteriorated as a fighting force over the last year and its situation is worsening even now. The Division is not in a position to meet Australia's defence requirements as they have been defined by the Hawke Government. The Government is very lucky that the Army is manned by dedicated, very competent men and women. It is their loyalty and qualities of leadership which have kept the lid on the mess in which the Army now finds itself.

What is that mess? I will give some examples. The 3rd Infantry Battalion is training to achieve a reduced battalion airborne capability of 360 men. This is a very important capacity for the Army to develop. At the moment there are not enough main parachutes, reserve parachutes or even protective headgear to meet that very limited aim. The cavalry regiment, responsible for reconnaissance for the Army, has only enough resources to train officers in technique. It has neither the equipment nor the men to carry out its role. It has no surveillance equipment, only very limited assault troops and is not allowed to train with tanks except on a very limited basis.

The 5th/7th Infantry Battalion is training as a mechanised infantry battalion. This unit should be the core of a mechanised force with hitting power and mobility. But only two companies have been equipped with vehicles. There are enough armoured personnel carriers in Army stocks to equip the remaining company but there is not enough money to buy the spares to maintain the vehicles. Thus they remain in stock unissued, unused. The fact that the Battalion is allowed to train with tanks for only two weeks per year is a scandal. Two weeks training together is an impossible limitation to impose.

I will cite the 1st Brigade's 101 Workshop's position. This is a workshop unit which provides critical repair and maintenance facilities for the Brigade's vehicles, weapons and other essential equipment. In this unit the kitchens have been condemned because of their condition; the building is infected with cockroaches; the troops' bathrooms, latrines and quarters are disgraceful. Working areas are no better. Trade unions would have long since refused to allow their members to work in such conditions.

Attempts to rehouse the soldiers in unused migrant accommodation at East Hills have so far not been successful. At East Hills good, modern accommodation exists which has not been used since October last year. For a very modest sum of about $600,000 the area could be made ready to accept immediately soldiers who are presently so badly housed. Housing conditions at Holsworthy Army area are still below standard. It is estimated that out of 2,000 married quarters at Holsworthy , 1,200 are substandard. Attempts are being made to refurbish some tiny, substandard fibro houses, but the money is being wasted. It costs about 75 per cent of what it would cost to build new houses, that is, at least $30,000 per house. After all this money has been spent the houses will still be tiny and will become major maintenance problems in three or four years. Carpets are being laid in the houses but only to seal the gaps between the floorboards.

In the Second Military District covering New South Wales it is estimated that there is a $30m debt at least for repair and maintenance work required to be carried out. The 1983-84 repair and maintenance funds provided to the Army and the Department of Housing and Construction were about $11.3m. Compare this with last year's figure of approximately $11.5m. When inflation is taken into account this represents a serious reduction in funds for 1983-84. Of this amount only about $4m is available towards reducing the $30m backlog of maintenance work.

As if this dismal picture were not enough, units have great difficulty in obtaining replacements of certain sizes of combat boots and jungle greens for soldiers who need replacements for worn-out equipment. Not only is there a shortage of parachutes and armoured vehicles but it would appear that the Army is to go barefoot as well. All of these problems have to be added to the assault that the Government has made on Service pay and retirement benefits. I speak, of course, about such sad examples as the 30 per cent tax levy on retirement benefits and the Medicare penalty on married members who have working wives.

The Minister for Defence is an incompetent Minister. From the very outset of this Government he has put his foot in it. He allowed the RAAF to be used in spy flights over Tasmania but abandoned the Navy Fleet Air Arm. He has ripped into the Services by reducing their retirement benefits, taking away the Citizen Military Forces' tax concessions and generally reduced pay levels by insisting that Medicare levies be paid from salaries. He has damaged Australia's relationships with its allies by his stupid and heavy-handed handling of the docking of allied warships in what has now become known as the Invincible affair .

Today we have exposed the dangerous state to which he has reduced the Army Division, the critical force structure upon which the Army builds its whole capabilities and strengths. He is guilty not only of running down the strength of the Army but also of attempting to cover up what he has done. The Minister, in his public speeches, has been preaching a commitment to maintaining an effective Army whilst, in reality, he has been taking away its boots and bullets . He has attempted to mislead the House; he has attempted to mislead the nation. He has been found out. He should be sacked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Is not the Minister going to answer these accusations, these criticisms? It is a disgrace that the Minister is not getting up to meet the valid criticisms.
—That is not a point of order.

—I am very sorry that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman), who had a long association with the Australian Defence Force, descended to the levels to which he descended today in making totally unwarranted personal attacks on the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) for the state of the Australian Defence Force. SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record. In the Budget that was brought down in August last year there was an increase of the order of 4 per cent in the appropriation for the Australian Defence Force. That is a very respectable increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the boots and bullets.

—I will deal with that. Honourable members opposite, who are now justly on the Opposition benches, on several occasions raised expectancies in the Defence Force for levels of funding which they never provided.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. We need an assurance that the Minister will speak in this debate.
—There is no point of order.
—He is in the chamber. The public of Australia should know that he is refusing to answer these accusations.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Order! When the occupant of the chair is standing, the House will be silent, and I mean both sides of the House. The interjections which have been coming across the House are not good natured banter. I would expect that, since the honourable member for Bass was heard in silence, the House will accord the same degree of courtesy to the honourable member for Brisbane.

—I will quote from comments made by the people who advise the present Government, and formerly advised the previous Government, as to what is their view of the Australian Defence Force as it stands today. Recently, the Chief of the Defence Force Staff, Air Chief Marshal Sir Neville McNamara, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australians have every reason to be proud of the reputation enjoyed by the Defence Force. It is manned by highly skilled men and women dedicated to attaining the highest levels of professional skill. Our capabilities are progressively improving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. That is a totally untrue statement. In the last 12 months the Army Reserve has been totally withdrawn.
—There is no point of order.
—I find it absolutely shocking that the honourable member would attack the Chief of the General Staff, who cannot defend himself, in this House, for a statement which he has made.
—He is the Chief of the Defence Force Staff. Get your priorities right.

—He is not yet the Chief of the Defence Force Staff, not until 13 April . The former Minister has obviously lost touch with these things very quickly. We have talked about a rundown in the reserves. TALK.START.PARA: —We made those decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is not even responding. It is his responsibility.
—He is squibbing his responsibilities.

—It is very easy to say things like that, particularly if members of the Opposition do not want to hear the facts. They will have their turn. A range of matters have been introduced to us as facts by the honourable member for Bass . First of all, he talked about our deteriorating environment. Then he spoke about standing on our own feet.
