Are we then to be blamed, after having been in office for a year, for the fact that the houses at the Royal Australian Air Force Base, Darwin, have not been significantly repaired in any way since the time of Cyclone Tracy? Cyclone Tracy was a long way back in the past. It is very easy to use a broad brush approach and list all of the deficiencies that exist. We do not deny that some of those deficiencies exist. The Minister took over the management of the Defence Force from the right honourable member for New England and the deficiencies existed at that time. It will take a significant amount of time to improve that situation. Everywhere the parliamentary committee went it was told by serving defence personnel of projects that had been promised by the previous Government but had been progressively cut out of the Budget.

The honourable member said that Army recruiting had been reduced. Let us also take into account the fact that the Defence Force is responding to an economic situation, where many officers and senior people in the Defence Force, because of the difficult employment situation outside the Force-surely the Opposition does not blame this Government for that, because that is another of the situations that we inherited from the previous Government-and who would otherwise not have stayed in the Force, are re-enlisting. Is the Opposition advocating that we should decline to recruit those people, that we should put them out in the market place in these very difficult economic circumstances? At a time when the massive cost of this equipment program is starting to be shown in the Budget, the Opposition is saying, in effect, one of two things.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have increased the Public Service by 10 per cent. What about the Army? Why not spend that money on the Army instead of the wretched Public Service?

—The Labor Government will stand on its record. Honourable members should look at the increase of $500m in the defence budget of this year, a larger increase both in real and absolute terms than the previous Government made. They should look at the way in which new equipment programs, such as the ordering of the frigates, are being slotted in. It is not hard to go around the country and see areas in which we could improve. These improvements are taking place, but there is a long lead time. The structure of the Australian armed force is very much determined by equipment ordered in the 1960s. The equipment that we order now will be around at the turn of the century.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bass referred to Defence Force pay and reserve force pay. The question of reserve force pay has been referred to the Coldham Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay with a view to bringing the pay up to adequate standards. Members of the Army Reserve have been deliberately underpaid over the years. We have been doing things on the cheap. During the last week the Minister for Defence announced a new arbitral system, a tribunal to set Defence Force pay. Honourable members opposite talk about morale. The Labor Government came to office in 1972. In the following year we gave the armed forces an across the board increase in pay. They waited until 1981 for the Coldham Committee to give a further upgrading. The present Opposition was not prepared to find the money in the Budget that year and kept them waiting a further year until 1982, which was when those increases flowed through the system. Yet honourable members opposite talk to us about Defence Force morale. The record of the Opposition on defence when in government is absolutely disgraceful.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the boots? You have fellows walking around without any dashed boots.
—That is totally untrue.
—It is absolutely true.
— Order! I warn the honourable member for Bass.

—The speech by the honourable member for Bass about the Australian Defence Force was a shocking indictment of the Fraser Government. The Labor Government now in office is setting out to redress these problems in very difficult circumstances. I am very proud indeed of the quality of those members of the Defence Force whom the Committee recently met in northern Australia. I am very pleased with the programs which the Government is setting in train to solve the problems we inherited from the Fraser Government. It is total humbug to suggest that this Government or any other government in the world could redress in one year of government the neglect of the Australian Defence Force over the seven years of the Fraser Government.
—Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question which must be asked is: Where is the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes)? Where has he been for the last 12 months and what is he doing for the defence of this country? Has he been gagged, we must ask, for incompetence? Has he been or is he about to be relieved of his job ? Why is he not answering the detailed charges that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) has levelled at his administration of the Department of Defence ? It is unheard of in this House that a Minister does not speak up for his Department under such circumstances. It is no wonder that the members of his Department, both civil and military, have lost confidence in him.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross), who was sold a dump in no uncertain terms by the Minister and who made very heavy weather of an almost impossible job. Why does the Minister not get up and speak for himself? The honourable member for Brisbane knows very well that all the things that the honourable member for Bass has been talking about, and which I will be talking about, were told to him when he visited Townsville. It is no use for him to say that he has been around the country and that everything is sweet and rosy, because he knows very well that it is not. Let us hear some refuting of the charges that have been made.

The Government is placing the security of this country in jeopardy because the Army is becoming non-effective, as has been outlined by the honourable member for Bass. Let me give some more examples of what is happening in the Australian Army. I illustrate this with a sad tale which was told to me a few weeks ago by a senior non-commissioned officer in a field force unit in north Queensland, one of the units which would be in the forefront of any engagement into which Australia might be forced. Ammunition is so short in his unit that he and other members of his platoon club together, with their own money, and go down to the local store to buy it. In 1984 soldiers are buying their own ammunition to try to become proficient with their basic weapon, which is a rifle. I say to the Minister for Defence: Let us have an answer to that one. Soldiers are buying their own ammunition because the Department cannot provide it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—That is true. The Government says that we are living in an uncertain world, which is true. There is a Russian build-up in submarines and aircraft in Vietnam. Yet what are soldiers in Australia doing? Buying their own ammunition to try to train themselves. In other units there has been a shortage of some sizes of boots. So not only are infantry soldiers buying their own ammunition but also infantry soldiers, because there are no vehicles and because there are no helicopters, are walking everywhere with no damn boots, for God's sake! There is a shortage of claymore mines, a very basic infantry weapon. There are soldiers in the Army who have never seen a claymore mine. A training unit in north Queensland keeps a few on the shelf. When soldiers come from other units soldiers there trot them out and say: 'This is a claymore mine'. They are handled like gold because they cannot get them. All the night-viewing devices which used to be prevalent in infantry battalions have now been withdrawn. Helicopter training hours are almost non-existent, as is track mileage. The list goes on and on. All this has happened in the last 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: How can the Government claim that the field force is effective? Is it any wonder that scores of people doubt our capacity to fight in a modern war. The will is not lacking. As the honourable member for Bass quite rightly pointed out , the only thing that keeps the Army going is the dedication and professionalism of the people in it. If one went around the Army and generally talked to any senior officers, junior officers, any NCOs, or any soldiers, in fact, they would tell one what I am telling honourable members. Honourable members should read what the Chief of Defence Force Staff and others had to say in Perth at a defence seminar recently. Read what the 'Returned Services League Defence Paper 1984' says. Read what the Australian newspaper says week after week. Read what any retired serviceman says from time to time in the media.

Let me go on to speak about a few more deficiencies. Our major field formation is the division. It is a skeleton in structure. We have one division, I might add, for a huge country which has 15 million people-probably the lowest ratio of arms of any developed country in the world. The cutting edge of the Australian Army is a skeleton. The forefront of the division is the operational deployment force based on 3 Brigade in Townsville. The only reason it operates is the dedication of its men and women who are loyal to the country, and I might add to the Government, to a man. But they are despairing, as they should be. In the ODF , the first unit that would be deployed in any action, they are on restricted manpower establishments. They have little or no air mobility. There are four helicopters, which in normal circumstances would lift a platoon, but because the platoons are so reduced four helicopters would probably lift two platoons without any trouble. There is almost no ground transport. There are 40 trucks in the whole brigade with 40 drivers for around-the-clock operations. So for two- thirds of the time the trucks are grounded. Weapons, machineguns and rifles, are almost without exception over 20 years old and sometimes in dangerous condition.

There is no anti-tank capacity whatsoever in the brigade, no radar, no air defence and no parachute capacity. There is a parachute capacity in Sydney, which is good for the unit which is training as a para-unit. But if it is required, it would not be the ADF that does the job but a battalion from Sydney. There is no amphibious training and no reconnaissance element in the whole of the ADF. It is short of ammunition, mines, flares, transport and men. It is short of everything that counts.

Let us talk about the deployment of the ADF. Let me quote what the Minister, who is not to speak in this debate, said in his submission to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on 20 March. It is signed on the front page 'G. Scholes, Minister for Defence'. This is his submission:
Our reserves of ammunition, weapons and spare parts would not support any sustained combat involvement of our forces beyond low level operations.

Of course, that is absolutely true. I put this to the Minister: I do not think that in the present climate of what he has done to the Army we could support one brigade in operation for any length of time. It has been put to me by more than one person that we would be flat out deploying and supporting one battalion in the field for any length of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did they say in 1982?
—Order! The Minister will not interject.
—If you are going to interject, get up and debate it. Go on, get up and debate it. You are gutless.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for McPherson to resume his seat. I will not again ask the honourable member for Bass to cease interjecting.

—One has to ask: How will the ADF get to wherever it is supposed to be going? How will it move when it gets there, provided it has boots? What weaponry would be available and how would we support it? One could go on and on. The 6th Brigade in Brisbane has a battalion strength of 400. If everybody came back from leave and courses and no one was sick that brigade might get 300 bayonets in the field-that is, if it was not supporting the ADF in the field where 200 men would be committed. It is a joke. The Army Reserve may have 15,000 effective personnel . One training group in Brisbane has just had 3,000 man days cut off its training element. The artillery battery in my unit lost 12 men the other day. They each handed in their gear and said: 'If you are not going to let us train, I am off'. The story goes on and on. I conclude by saying-
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accuse the Liberal and National parties. For over 31 years they had the trust of the Australian people to provide a defence force for this country. They abandoned that responsibility. They have left this country in the most defenceless state it has been in since World War II. I will speak to this House today about the criminal neglect and irresponsibility of those honourable members on the other side of the House who had the trust of the Australian people to provide an adequate defence force for this country. It causes me great distress to find the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) sheltering under the loyalty of servicemen of this country, accusing them of not performing their tasks and accusing senior officers of not giving competent, honest and adequate advice to governments over the years. That he should do that is an indictment. The matter for discussion proposed by the honourable member for Bass reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's inept handling in allowing the dangerous run-down of the army in this country thus threatening the security of the Australian people and its territories.

Sir, I say to you that that is an indictment of the criminal neglect and inadequate performance of the Liberal-National party during the 31 years it was in office. Why did it not establish an adequate defence capability for this country during that time? Why did it not instil in the Australian community an awareness of the need to provide adequate defence for this country? Why did it distort the defence budget of this nation by reducing actual expenditure during the seven years the Fraser Government was in power? Why did it not establish an adequate procurement program for our defence forces during that time?

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order; why is the Minister not taking part in the debate?
—That is not a point of order.

—When the previous Government was asked by the present Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) when he was in opposition to provide an adequate defence force, to re-arm the defence forces of this country, why did it criminally abandon its statutory responsibility in that area? Let us look at the strength of the Australian Army today. In a country of over 15.5 million people we have one infantry division; one armoured regiment; two cavalry regiments; four artillery regiments; one field engineer regiment; one construction regiment; one field survey regiment; five signal regiments; one special air services regiment; one aviation regiment; one transport regiment; one transport air support regiment--
—What does all that mean?

—This is the record of 31 years of criminal neglect of the defence forces of this country. Wherever we debate this issue throughout the length and breadth of this country the record of the Liberal-National party will be hung up to show the people of Australia how it has betrayed the interests of this country. It is also reported that, as a result of that 31 years experience, 36 M198 150-millimetre howitzers are now on order. That is the record for the Australian Army in 31 years of Liberal-National party rule.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the attitude of defence spokesmen at that time. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), when Minister for Defence in 1983, wrote in the Pacific Defence Reporter an article on the subject: 'Time on our Side'. In responding to a report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence he made the following remarks:
Global nuclear war remains improbable, Australia would not be a principal threat in such a conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The right honourable member for New England. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The large armies in our region are largely irrelevant to Australia's defence problems, because they are currently unsupported by the substantial maritime and air resources needed to launch and sustain a major military action against Australia as an island nation.
These fundamental considerations provide us with considerable assurance for our own future security.
Australia is able, with its present planned military capabilities, to make low or intermediate level attacks against it costly and hazardous.
That article was written in February 1983 by the right honourable member for New England. He goes on to say:
Furthermore we are well equipped to expand these capabilities in the face of an emerging threat.
Again I quote from the right honourable member for New England. A little over a year ago he said:

The long lead-time in years necessary for personnel recruiting and training and manufacturing and acquisition of military hardware determine our defence capacity is at least five and almost certainly 10 years hence. It is the Government's view that this period is within the time frame necessary to identify possible threat ahead and so permit timely expansion, should it be believed necessary.

That was the prognosis of the spokesman on defence in the previous Liberal- National party Government in 1983. I say this: There is a need to re-arm the defence forces in this country. There is a need to re-equip the defence forces of this country. There is a need to breathe a breath of fresh air into the Army, Navy and Air Force of this country. Last year the Hawke Labor Government, an authentic Australian government, increased defence expenditure by 4 per cent in real terms at a time of obvious economic difficulty. Contrast that with the Liberal-National party Government expenditure in its last year of office of increasing defence expenditure in real terms by 1.7 per cent. During the seven disastrous years of that criminal neglect by the Liberal-National party Government, defence expenditure increases averaged 2.5 per cent. The fact is that the present Government is prepared to spend more on defence in real terms than the Fraser Government ever did.

Let me make a few remarks about northern defence. Recently I visited Larrakeyah Naval Base. There I saw a naval base that had no air defence whatever, and naval craft that had very little defensive capability, let alone offensive capability. I saw the seamen's quarters, which were run down and rat infested, with no privacy for the seamen. I saw, also, that Cockatoo Island Dockyard in Sydney, a major re-equipment facility for the Navy, was run down and dirty, with papers blowing everywhere. The place was a disgrace. I asked persons involved what the Liberal-National party Government did during those 30 years. I asked the question of the Captain at Larrakeyah Naval Base. I asked the question of the Captain at Cockatoo Island Dockyard. On each occasion the answer was: 'Nothing'.

So I ask: What about regional surveillance and northern defence? We have the 3rd Brigade based at Townsville, a fine, loyal body of men. Yet only recently the Chief of Joint Operations and Plans at the Department of Defence, in a statement dated 24 February 1984-only recently-had this to say about the 3rd Brigade:
The Operational Deployment Force at Townsville is kept at war strength and ready for operations. The remainder form the expansion base.

The statements made by the Opposition in this debate indicate clearly that the members of the 3rd Brigade have abandoned their posts. I object to those statements. I find it insulting that Opposition members should cast aspersions on members of the 3rd Brigade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Why does the honourable member keep quoting someone else? Why does he not--
—There is no point of order.

—The people of Australia have always turned to the Australian Labor Party in times of need to re-arm this country. Our allies turned to this country in the Second World War. The people of Australia turned to the ALP on 5 March 1983. We have accepted the task of re-arming Australia and providing an adequate defence force. It is a task that we will have great honour in achieving, in expanding our defence forces during the next 20 years of Labor government in Australia. It is a task that we will achieve by providing, for the first time in our nation's history, an adequate defence force.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the National Party from moving:

That this House censures the Minister for Defence for his failure to address the serious deficiencies in the Australian Defence Force revealed by the members for Bass and McPherson in the matter of public importance today, and for his refusal to guarantee the provision of sufficient resources to rectify the Australian Defence Force deficiencies in the 1984-85 Budget.

I have moved the motion because there have been very serious deficiencies revealed by the two spokesmen for the Opposition in this debate. They are deficiencies which require a response from the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) , on a matter which goes to the core of morale and capability at a time when the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has forced on Australia a greater measure of self-sufficiency than has ever been required before. Unless I move for the suspension of Standing Orders to allow this censure motion to be considered, this House this afternoon will see the Minister for Defence failing to respond on matters of critical importance to the whole Australian nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable members will be aware that in December last year Parliament passed the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act 1983. That Act allowed the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to consider any request from the New South Wales Special Commission of Inquiry, constituted by Mr Justice Cross, for information relating to the commission or intended commission of a serious criminal offence which had been obtained by the lawful interception of telecommunications. Mr Justice Cross was appointed to conduct three separate inquiries under the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act 1983. Two of those inquiries have been completed. The third inquiry, relating to the circumstances surrounding the early release of certain prisoners, was in progress when Mr Justice Cross resigned his commission because of ill health.

On 27 March the New South Wales Governor appointed Mr Justice Slattery to conduct that uncompleted inquiry. Pursuant to the terms of the 1983 amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act, the Attorney-General has communicated to Mr Justice Cross certain information obtained by the Australian Federal Police by lawful interception of telecommunications. The Telecommunications ( Interception) Amendment Bill 1984 is necessary to permit that information to be furnished to Mr Justice Slattery for the purposes of his special commission of inquiry. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to continue with the debate.
—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I will allow that course to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill is a very important Bill even though it is a very brief one and even though the purpose of the Bill is, in essence, to substitute for Mr Justice Cross, Mr Justice Slattery for the purposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Because this is an important Bill I wish to take a little more time in speaking to it than has the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen). The original Bill, original in the sense of the one that this substitutes for, was the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1983 which became Act No. 116 of 1983. The purpose of that Bill was to allow information to be forwarded to the Cross Special Commission of Inquiry. The information that could be forwarded to the Cross inquiry was information, for present purposes, which had been intercepted pursuant to the provisions of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act which under certain circumstances allows interception of telephone calls.

We have recently heard a lot in this House about the interception of telephone calls. We should understand how the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act 1983 works because we are really substituting Mr Justice Slattery for Mr Justice Cross. The Act first of all defines what an inquiry is and refers to the inquiry which has been conducted under the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act 1983 of New South Wales. I will come back to that at a later time. The Act then sets out what a relevant offence is for the purposes of communication being made and defines that as an offence against a law of the Commonwealth, a law of the State or a law of the Territory that is punishable by imprisonment for life or for a maximum period of not less than three years; that is, if it is three years or more, it is a relevant offence.

The Act then provides that the person conducting what has been properly called the Cross inquiry may, by notice in writing to the Commonwealth Attorney-General , request the Attorney-General to ascertain whether there was information lawfully obtained by intercepting communications passing over our telecommunications system that is relevant for the purposes of the inquiry and appears to relate to the commission or intended commission of a relevant offence ; that is to say, an offence punishable by a maximum period of imprisonment of three years or more.

On receipt of such a request the Attorney-General may then and will no doubt examine the request and if satisfied make a request in writing to the Commissioner of Police to ascertain whether there is material available and if any such material is in the possession of the Australian Federal Police he may communicate that. The Commissioner is then to communicate that to the Attorney- General. Therefore, the Attorney-General requests the Federal Police to advise whether there is relevant information and he is then advised by the police whether this information exists. The Attorney-General then has the task of being satisfied that the information should be passed on to the New South Wales inquiry. If he is satisfied that it should be passed on to that inquiry he may pass it on and that information may be used for the purposes of that inquiry.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act 1983 specified Mr Justice Cross as the person who was conducting an inquiry under the New South Wales Act. Of course why we have this Bill before us is that Mr Justice Cross, for reasons of ill health, has retired. We now have the appointment of Mr Justice Slattery in his place. In passing I mention that I have known Mr Justice Slattery for many years and have a high regard for him and his capabilities.

I think we need to look at what it is that His Honour Mr Justice Slattery has to do under the New South Wales Act. Under the New South Wales Act he has to conduct an inquiry into circumstances surrounding the early release of certain prisoners. This would seem a very necessary thing to do because we all know of the early prisoner release scandal in New South Wales. It has been said of the New South Wales prisons that they were the only walk in, walk out prisons in the country. Because of the very great criticisms made of the early release scheme- calls which almost invariably have come from the New South Wales Opposition and not from anyone on the Government side-we now have the Cross inquiry which has been taken over by Mr Justice Slattery. All of us here wish Mr Justice Slattery well in the conduct of that inquiry since there is, from all we have heard, a great deal to inquire into. New South Wales probably has the dubious reputation of being known as the most corrupt State in the country. Certainly there are no likely contenders for that title.

One of the problems that I think we need to look at is how the inquiry in New South Wales is conducted. I say this because Mr Justice Slattery, or anybody else who is appointed as a special commissioner under the New South Wales Act, is bound by that Act. There is one particularly troubling provision of that Act. It is one that I have never understood the reason for if the New South Wales Government was interested in fair play. It is provided by section 36(1) of the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act that:
A Special Commission shall not be vitiated by reason of any informality or want of form or be liable to be challenged, appealed against, quashed or called in question by any court.

By any court? Does that mean that the commissioner, whoever he is and however eminent he may be, is beyond judicial control? Is that not a perfectly astonishing provision to appear in an Act which clothes the commissioner with very wide powers to interrogate, to require documents and to require answers? Section 36(2) states:
No proceedings, whether for an order in the nature of prohibition, certiorari or mandamus or for a declaration or injunction or for any other relief, shall lie in respect of any Special Commission.

Effectively what that means is that the commission of inquiry established under the Act is beyond the control of the courts. So that the non-lawyers in the House know what I am talking about when I talk about prohibition, certiorari, or mandamus, let me briefly explain. Prohibition is an order that a superior court may give to any inferior court or to any tribunal exercising powers of a judicial or quasi-judicial nature to prohibit that tribunal from exceeding its powers. Certiorari is an order pursuant to which a superior court can quash, that is, invalidate, proceedings, before an inferior court or before a tribunal exercising judicial or quasi-judicial powers. Mandamus is an order which can be issued by a superior court to compel an inferior court or a tribunal exercising judicial or quasi-judicial powers to perform its functions according to law. A declaration is a form of relief which is available to citizens of this country so that they can go to a court and get it to declare that what has been done by such a body as a commission of inquiry is beyond power. I suppose everybody knows what an injunction is. It is an order which is issued by a superior court preventing, amongst other things, the misuse of power by an inferior court or a tribunal of the kind we have here.

Tribunals of inquiry are ordinarily established by terms of reference. Those terms of reference set out what they may or may not do. Under the law of this land, unless altered by statute as it has been in New South Wales, if a tribunal exceeds its powers a person who is affected by any decision of that tribunal can go to the court and say: 'This tribunal is exceeding its powers. It is seeking to force me to do things which it is not entitled to do. It is seeking to call for papers from me which it is not entitled to call for, and I want you to stop it'. If the court is convinced that that is so, the court will order the tribunal to stop doing what it does not have power to do. However, that provision is not to apply. Nor is there to be any kind of right of appeal so that one cannot control what is happening while it is happening and one cannot appeal against any finding which may be made against one.

We all know that an inquiry was made into some statements made by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair). I am not going to traverse what took place in that inquiry but I will repeat now what I said then and that is, that judges go wrong every day of the week. It is the nature of the system. That is why we have appeal courts. Appeal courts are there to try to put things right . They do not always succeed in putting things right as anybody who has experience in the law or in the world knows. Courts are always going to be fallible. But with a system of appeal courts at least we have an opportunity of review.

Under the New South Wales provisions in the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act 1983 there is no capability of reviewing a decision made by the Special Commissioner. There is no capability of controlling what that Special Commissioner is doing. That, it seems to me, is a grave departure from the kinds of laws which we should have in this country. It must be a basic rule that those who are conducting inquiries of a semi-judicial kind or even inquiries of a judicial kind-here we are really concerned with inquiries of a semi-judicial kind-should be subject to control of the courts.

The person who is going to conduct the third limb of the inquiries under the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act, Mr Justice Slattery, is, as I say, a person for whom I have the highest regard and whom I have known for many years. However , whether it is Mr Justice Slattery or any other judge, or a Queen's Counsel appointed under the New South Wales Act-I see a Queen's Counsel can be appointed under the Act-they can all go wrong. They can all make mistakes; they can all say things which prove, in the final analysis, to be incorrect. We all know that inquiries of this kind attract the widest publicity. When things are said which, in the final analysis, prove to be incorrect, there is no recalling them. What goes out from such an inquiry almost invariably attracts far more attention than does any refutation no matter how well based, no matter how reasonable.

Whilst the Opposition supports the Bill, we think it necessary to draw to the attention of the House and the Government, which has said on many occasions that it has a commitment to civil rights-although I must say some of its actions are far away from giving real life to any such commitment-that we hope that in the legislation which will come before this Parliament, we will not see anything which prohibits bodies of the kind that have been established in New South Wales from control by the courts. That being said, the Opposition supports the Bill but adds the warning that the New South Wales legislation is not the sort of legislation we want to see here. It is not the sort of legislation that is calculated to make sure that people called before it get a fair hearing in the sense that they have a right at the end of the day to have matters reviewed. God knows, maybe some of us will be called before an inquiry one of these days. If our reputations were going to be affected, we most certainly would want an opportunity to correct anything that may be said about us, and to argue that the corrections should be made and entered on the record and to do that before a court, or to control the proceedings of a body which might be exceeding its terms of reference and exceeding them in a way that harms us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1984, which has been introduced quickly, which had its passage through the Senate recently and which is being facilitated at this time, is an important piece of legislation which my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney ( Mr Spender) has indicated has the support of the Opposition. But I would not want it to be thought that the support of the Opposition for the introduction and the immediate passage of this legislation was necessarily support for the New South Wales Special Commissions of Inquiry Act and the form in which that Commission is now functioning. Notwithstanding those reservations, I would not want it to be thought that these comments could be construed in any way as a criticism of the appointment of Mr Justice Slattery as the new Commissioner in New South Wales to undertake inquiries under the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act. I know of Mr Justice Slattery by repute, and I regard him to be a judge of very considerable reputation. But I think it is important that honourable members be aware of the limitations of the legislation under which he is required to work.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney has placed some weight today on particular clauses and drawn, I think quite properly, to public notice the very considerable concern that should exist about the fact that inquiries that we are facilitating are a special form of commission and not a royal commission with the normal protections that the public might expect would be available had a royal commissioner been appointed in New South Wales to carry out investigations into the early release scheme and into other matters that have recently been considered by that body.

This is not the first time that in New South Wales legislation of an unusual character has been introduced for which people wonder why the usual formula for conducting investigations has not been availed of by the Government. There was, first, the Evidence Amendment Act in New South Wales which was of considerable concern to those who were interested in civil liberties, those who were interested in facilitating proper inquiry and ensuring that proper evidence in matters could be put before the courts. Yet legislation was brought into the Parliament to prevent information in the hands of government being made available to the courts in New South Wales. New South Wales was the only place, as I understand it, where legislation of that character was introduced.

Then, of course, there were certain allegations made in respect of which, because of their force, there was a view that there ought to be an inquiry to establish truth and to establish whether allegations that had been made were correct. The normal way in which those matters would have been dealt with would have been by way of royal commission. Yet what we saw in 1983 was the introduction of legislation to establish a special commission of inquiry which, in terms of the legislation, qualified the rights which would normally be available to those who were likely to be called before a royal commission, rights that they would have enjoyed, and which excluded the possible intervention of the courts if the special commission, in this instance, were carried out in circumstances in which a court may have formed the view that it was wrong in principle. There are certain principles that ought to operate in relation to the conduct of commissions of inquiry. We already know in relation to royal commissions that they can have their findings canvassed if there is a belief that the commission has made an error. Courts can have their findings reviewed by higher courts. There is no reflection upon a judge or others who may be involved in inquiries if their judgments are canvassed. In relation to the Mount Erebus inquiry in New Zealand, there was such an appeal and the decisions of the royal commission in that instance were canvassed by the Privy Council, as I understand it. Of course, section 36 of the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act in New South Wales contains provisions designed to exclude the court from carrying out a review of the form that it might normally be able to carry out. It excludes appeal. It excludes the use of the writs of prohibition. We know that in relation to the conduct of the Special Commission in New South Wales in two instances recently there has been some comment about the way in which the inquiries have been conducted. It is no reflection upon the Commission itself that complaints have been made. The reflection is upon the legislation that took away the normal procedures that would have otherwise operated in relation to the conduct of a royal commission and took away the possibility of an approach to the court when there was a view that the procedures might not have been carried out properly.

We know in relation to the first report of the Special Commission in New South Wales that there was an editing of the report of the Special Commissioner by the Government, a very unusual procedure. We know that in relation to the second matter that was looked at in New South Wales by the Special Commissioner there was very considerable complaint about some aspects of the inquiry, including the inability of one of the parties who were involved to have information that would normally be available as to the nature of the findings that might be made so that other evidence could be put before the Commission before it reached a final view. Such matters could have been the subject of an appeal.

The Opposition is co-operating in the passage of the legislation that we are dealing with today, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1984, to ensure that the Special Commission is able to conduct its inquiry unhampered by any action on the part of this Government. The Opposition is facilitating the passage of that leislation. So it is important that we be aware of the limitations in the special commissions of inquiry legislation in New South Wales . If the view is to be formed that the inquiries that have been carried out to this point in time can go unquestioned because of the nature of the legislation that was introduced by the Government of New South Wales, to limit, in my view, the way in which the Commission's findings might be properly examined by the courts and in ways in which they would if the body were a royal commission, those matters ought to be the subject of comment in this Parliament.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill is designed to ensure that the Special Commissioner in New South Wales has access to certain tapes of conversations recorded by an authorisation that was given under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. Of course these tapes, unlike other tapes that we have been hearing about, are authorised. They are tapes that were taken legally. But there are limitations upon the extent to which others might be apprised of the contents of them. The purpose of this legislation is to ensure that the Special Commission in New South Wales, headed by the new Commissioner, Mr Justice Slattery, which has been established to examine certain circumstances surrounding the early release of prisoners in New South Wales, will be able to have that information available to it in the circumstances in which it is carrying out the inquiry. Undoubtedly, this evidence is considered by the inquiry to be important to it. No doubt there is no possible allegation in this instance that the tape recordings lack any authenticity. Presumably they have been taken under the aegis of this legislation by agencies of the Commonwealth and have not been taped illegally by police, as has been suggested was the case in relation to certain other tapes about which we hear so much.

Of course the matters that are being inquired into are of great moment and of great importance. I think it is important that the task that Mr Justice Slattery has been given be undertaken. I certainly hope that, in this instance, if Mr Justice Slattery finds that the special factors that I have mentioned involved in the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act in New South Wales in any way hamper him in the conduct of this inquiry, he will make known to the Government of New South Wales and more widely deficiencies in this legislation so that the inquiry can be properly facilitated.

In New South Wales there is concern amongst lawyers about the fact that special commissions of inquiry legislation was introduced and that the normal procedures by way of royal commissions have been put aside. I speak as one who has heard those views; who has for a time practised law in New South Wales; and who is concerned when the system of justice is brought into disrepute and when legislation can be characterised in the way in which this legislation has been characterised and is not giving rise to a fair and proper inquiry for those who have had to appear before a special commission of inquiry. I think that these matters ought to be noted by the Government and by the public at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I welcome the fact that the legislation is not being opposed, although having listened to the speeches by members of the Opposition I would have thought that they did not see very much merit in it. Obviously they used that mechanism to give forth some personal views about New South Wales. The issue clearly is that information which has already been furnished to Mr Justice Cross can be made available to Mr Justice Slattery. I do not know why we had to have such a wide-ranging debate on issues which have nothing to do with the Telcommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1984 which is before the House. Everybody agreed that that Bill should be introduced. But now another matter has been opened up. Obviously in the minds of some honourable members opposite there is something wrong with the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act of New South Wales. I do not see any merit in that accusation. The Act was set up to handle accusations which were made either in public or in private. The fact that there are casualties, whether political or otherwise, is, in fact, a tribute to the method of justice, of analysing evidence which is given subject to cross-examination rather than accusations being made with no opportunity to investigate the merit of them. Let me make it very clear. The judicial process still runs its course under the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act. People are entitled to have legal representation and to test the evidence against them. When the evidence against them crumbles and falls it follows, does it not, that it is in accordance with justice that the people making the accusations have to suffer the damage and not the people at whom they aimed those accusations? When we see people such as Mr Coombs and Mr Waterhouse coming out unscathed, surely we cannot complain about it?
—But you do not think that those commissions are infallible, do you?

—I want to make the point for the benefit of the honourable member, who did not mention it, that the commission merely makes a finding as to whether there is cause for further action. In other words, it is a prima facie finding. Why would the honourable member object to that? Honourable members opposite talk about natural justice. They should examine the justice in this case. What happened to the reputations of two people who came out from that inquiry unscathed and were then vilified in this Parliament? What happened to the reputation of Mr Justice Cross? Honourable members opposite do not want to listen. What happened to the reputation of Mr Justice Cross, a very honourable judge, as was shown by the debates which subsequently transpired here in regard to a finding that he made on the evidence?
—He was hamstrung by the Act.

—He was not hamstrung by the Act. What happened to the woman magistrate who had to suffer because of an accusation made by a person who subsequently had his counsel get up and say that he wanted to withdraw the allegation?
—Supported by the New South Wales Government.

—The right honourable member has been damaged for life because of the findings which have been made against him. He has been damaged because of what he had to admit in the witness box. It had nothing to do with the findings. He knows that that is the problem. I am very mindful of the fact that Mr Justice Cross has had to retire because of the strain put upon him. I think that a lot of that strain would relate to the debate which took place in this Parliament. I wonder what redress Mr Coombs and Mr Waterhouse have in libel and in other actions against accusations which have been made against them. What redress does Miss Schreiner have, from the point of view of being a magistrate who was vilified? What about the advertisements for the Liberal Party which were used in the recent election and which named a person who is at present facing trial? What do honourable members think about that from the point of view of justice?
—Do you suggest that that has anything to do with what we are talking about today?

—It does, because I am answering the honourable member for North Sydney. It is because I am answering him that he is trying to run away from it. I am referring specifically to the fact that the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act in New South Wales is functioning. I draw his mind to the fact that there have been other commissions of inquiry.
—That is a very bad piece of law.

—It is a law that enables people to test the validity of accusers. It is a law that allows people to lay an information when perhaps they feel they cannot give it to the police. The issue is very clear. The point is this: There was the Moffitt Royal Commission on Alleged Organised Crime in Registered Clubs in New South Wales. That would interest honourable members opposite in political terms, would it not? It would interest them substantially, because of the corruption that was obvious at that time, when there was no Labor Government in New South Wales.
—What is wrong with a royal commission? Why did Wran run away from the royal commission system?
—That is the point. Honourable members opposite should not try to stop it by continually interjecting. Let me talk to them without the interjections.
—Order! Interjections are out of order. The Minister is entitled to be heard in silence.
—That is right, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am answering interjections now, but the accusations were made by the honourable member for North Sydney.
—I was speaking about the Act which this Bill supports and so it is directly related. You know that, Lionel.

—I know that, and I know that the honourable member spoke about the corruption in New South Wales over a long period. I also know that he said that one could walk in and out of gaol-these are his own words-at any time. That is why we had the Nagle Royal Commission into New South Wales Prisons, which, of course, related to the period when the Liberal Government was in office. Why do honourable members opposite not get their facts right? I will accept the view that there can always be corruption but the question here is how to pin it down. The problem about corruption, if one wants to look at it objectively, is that unfortunately it can also get into the police forces. That is the problem. The problem then for the average citizen is that he has to ask: 'How can I legitimately complain if I have no source to go to other than that'? That is the value of the legal profession. The legal approach is to say: 'Let us test the accusation'. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) is only smarting over the fact that he made a stupid political accusation against people --
—I am not smarting at all.

—His career is destroyed. In the terms of the judical process under this Act the right honourable member had every chance to go ahead with those accusations yet he withdrew them. But he came into the Parliament afterwards and repeated them. I make the point that honourable members opposite should not make the accusation in this Parliament that there are problems in New South Wales only because of recent events. We could take them back in time to a period which would cover the whole spectrum when the Liberal Party was in power. Substantial accusations were made at that time. The Moffitt Royal Commission had a lot to do with them. People who had previously been in high office were also affected. So it is ridiculous to suggest now that all of a sudden we must look at this Act and at what is wrong with it. The point that honourable members opposite ought to value about the Act--
—There was Farquhar, Kevin Humphreys--

—Yes, the right honourable member would name them all again even though one of them is facing trial now. He was found wanting. That is the reason his career here is finished. There is no need for him to talk about credibility, because of what happened. I am only making the point, in the plea--
—You never had a career.

—Maybe so, but that does not matter. I will go out clean. There are few doubts about that. The point at the moment is this: The New South Wales Act, which it has been suggested is wrong because it would not allow anybody justice, has been proved to be of value in clearing people charged with crime. I think we will find that other people are guilty of misconduct from the point of view of making accusations for which there is no validity, affecting, as I say, the question of justice.
—Absolute rubbish! You know there was validity.

—It hurts the right honourable member a lot. He cannot stop because of the accusations. For example, I am talking about the woman magistrate called Schreiner. Why is the right honourable member trying to interject against that? I am talking about Coombs and Waterhouse. That must hurt the right honourable member a lot.
—You know the allegations are true, don't you? You read my evidence to the Special Commission.

—I do not know that at all. There was no truth. That is why the right honourable member withdrew it. I want to make this point about this Act: Other people will want to make accusations and that Act gives them the chance to do so.
—No, it does not.

—Yes, it does. It gives them an opportunity to test the position . When the Commissioner makes a finding, it will not be a finding of guilty or not guilty; it will be a finding on whether there is a prima facie case to answer. That is the point. Then at least we will get some parallel with justice at present.
—What about natural justice?

—There is natural justice in that. The point I am making is that every person has the right to be legally represented. That has all the elements of justice. If it is so wrong, why are honourable members opposite not opposing this Bill now? This Bill will allow evidence to be put before the Commission. Honourable members opposite are hoist by their own petard because they approved of the Bill in the first instance. The Bill will allow evidence that has already been given to Mr Justice Cross to be made available to Mr Justice Slattery, and honourable members opposite approve of that. If that is so, why have honourable members opposite raised, in a long political diatribe, what they think is wrong with New South Wales, saying that one can walk in and out of gaols and that there is corruption? I can explain to them the corruption that applied under previous Liberal administrations. All they do is interject when that is said. If that Act is not what they want, why would they allow this evidence to be made available? They should oppose the Bill. That is the logical thing to do. They should not try to bluff their way through by abuse and ridiculous accusations.
—What do you think you are doing?

—Firstly, I have to answer the accusations that honourable members opposite have made about what is wrong with the Act. They said that the Leader of the National Party never got a fair deal under the Act. They said also that there were problems with the administration of gaols in New South Wales, as though that had occurred only recently, and they omitted to mention the Nagle Commission. They forgot to mention that the accusations which had been made about the woman magistrate Schreiner had to be withdrawn. None of those things were given credit. The point is that the magistrate was accused of something--
—The substance of the allegations could be understood--
—Why is it--
—So that the public would not be aware of why these allegations were being made.
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting.

—The fanaticism of interjection! A woman magistrate in New South Wales was impugned and, as a result of this inquiry, the person who made that accusation arranged for the Queen's Counsel representing him to stand up and withdraw. That is the position.
—He was denied the opportunity to be represented, and you know that. He was given a watching brief.

—The right honourable member is fearful that what happened to him will be found out. I challenge honourable members opposite: If this Act is so bad, so unfair, and so contrary to natural justice, why in the name of logic or sense do they support this piece of legislation? I think we have heard enough of these accusations from the Opposition. By all means let them suggest that they do not want any more inquiries by this Commission as far as members of the Opposition are concerned. Honourable members opposite are so interested in natural justice that they have agreed to a Senate committee taking unto itself such powers that no justice will be given to the people accused before it! On the same principle of looking at tapes, those opposite are going to empower some senators to do whatever they want to do. What rights will the people called before that Senate committee have? What chance of justice have they got? A double standard is being adopted here today in that those opposite are saying: ' We support the Bill but we oppose the forum to which the evidence is going'. How ridiculous can they get? It is also ridiculous for them to suggest that there has not been any justice before that Commission when in fact there has. It is also ridiculous for those opposite to set up a Senate committee before which people will be dragged on very much the same issue without any right to have legal counsel or without any right of cross-examination. Those opposite do not deserve any credibility because of the speeches they made. The only sensible part of their speeches today was when they said that they supported the Bill. We ought to leave it at that.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the House is resuming the second reading debate on the Health Insurance Amendment Bill by which the Government seeks to introduce amendments to section 17 of the Health Insurance Act in the hope of resolving the present doctors' dispute. The Opposition believes that these amendments do not go far enough and will not resolve the dispute. Accordingly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government should take immediate steps to resolve the dispute between the Minister for Health and the doctors by accepting the Health Legislation Amendment Bill of which the honourable member for Mackellar gave notice on 27 March 1984'.
Part V of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia defines the powers of the Parliament. Section 51 proclaims:

The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to: . . . The provision of . . . medical and dental services (but not so as to authorize any form of civil conscription), . . .

The important qualification, that prohibiting civil conscription, was included in the amemdments to the Constitution proposed in 1946 by the then Labor Government at the suggestion of the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr R.G. Menzies. The amendments were approved by the people in a referendum. It is most unfortunate that attempts by the present Labor Government of Australia to circumvent that binding covenant of our Constitution are threatening the peace, order and good government of this Commonwealth.

As a direct result of the actions of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Government, doctors are on strike for the first time in Australia's history. We face the extraordinary situation where doctors have been so provoked by threats to their private independent professional practice that they have decided to withdraw their services from public hospitals except in cases of emergency. Given the sense of dedication and remoteness from political action of the vast majority of the profession, why have its members decided to act in this fashion?

It is worth examining the history of the present dispute. In September last year the Government introduced legislation into the Federal Parliament to establish a new system of health insurance called Medicare. The scheme was similar to one first proposed in the late 1960s and introduced by the Whitlam Labor Government during its term of office between 1972 and 1975. It was then called Medibank. Medibank was progressively dismantled by the Fraser Government during its term of office, the main changes occurring between 1976 and 1981. The Labor Party has claimed a mandate to reintroduce a similar scheme following its election victory in March 1983. The scheme involves nationalisation of over 50 per cent of the private health insurance industry. It offers free surgery consultations and free hospital beds in public hospitals, although these offers have been made without the prior agreement of the medical profession whose co- operation is essential to make them a reality.

The offer of free surgery consultations depends on doctors applying the same procedures as have previously been available, but not compulsory, for pensioners and the disadvantaged-that is, the doctor direct billing the Government for 85 per cent of the Government approved schedule fee and accepting that amount in full settlement of the account without billing the patient. While many doctors have been prepared to do this for low income groups, they have not in general been prepared, since the introduction of Medicare, to do it for others. It means accepting a reduction in gross income of at least 15 per cent. Doctors, understandably, see no merit in discounting their gross income to this extent, with consequent higher percentage reductions in net income to patients who could afford medical insurance.

In order to put pressure on doctors to direct bill, the Government made all private medical insurance, as opposed to hospital insurance, illegal, reserving a public monopoly for Medicare, thus making it impossible for patients to insure for the gap between fee and claim. The Government also distributed propaganda to the public suggesting that they ask for free treatment and tried to persuade State governments to permit advertising by doctors who agreed to direct bill. We cannot yet judge the success of these efforts to move private medical practitioners over to the Government payroll, but we know that many doctors who had previously direct billed for pensioners and the disadvantaged have reverted to billing the patient and accepting the discounted fee collected by the patient from Medicare.

By and large, members of the profession accepted these measures as legitimate legislative aims for a socialist government but reserved their right to choose their own method of billing. If the Medicare measures had been left there, the Government would not have got itself into its present predicament. But the Government went further. Part of the Medicare package of legislation was the now notorious section 17 of the Health Insurance Act, which provides that Medicare benefits are not payable to a patient treated as the private patient of a visiting medical officer in a public hospital unless the doctor concerned has signed a contract of service in a form approved by the Federal Minister for Health. As some 80 per cent of the nation's hospital beds are in public hospitals, and an even higher proportion of the surgical beds, a high proportion of private specialist practice in Australia is performed in public hospitals. Up until now, the professional relationship between the doctor and the patient has been for the most part preserved, despite the use of public facilities. The public hospitals have negotiated contracts for the use of these facilities with the doctors in each case, and it is these contracts that the Federal Minister now seeks to control. Any such attempt by the Minister to dictate the conditions of service of doctors in State public hospitals for the purposes of the Medicare scheme runs the risk of contravening the civil conscription prohibition of the Constitution. The denial of the Medicare benefit to the patient, thus putting pressure on the doctor, can be seen as a device to try to circumvent the Constitution. The High Court of Australia may well have to decide whether this device succeeds.

However, section 17 is even more provocative than that. It gives the Federal Minister powers to determine the acceptability of a contract without any provision for arbitration or appeal. The concerns of the profession were made known quite clearly to the Minister last September, but he and the Government refused to accept an amendment put forward by the Opposition. From that moment, the die for the current dispute was cast.

At the time of its introduction and since, the Minister has claimed that the purpose of section 17 was to curb the unnecessarily high earnings of diagnostic specialists using public facilities to treat private patients. It may be that some such specialists are earning what might be regarded as excessive sums from their contracts. The Opposition does not dispute that. If so, the hospitals concerned, acting under State legislation, have it within their power to seek to have the contracts renegotiated. As the Bill was being debated in September last year, I specifically asked the Minister whether the provisions of section 17 applied only to certain diagnostic specialists. He replied:
They apply to all medical officers using public hospital facilities for private practice.

The Minister repeated this assertion in Question Time last Tuesday. So section 17 applies to all medical officers using public hospital facilities. For the moment, the Minister has applied its provisions to certain diagnostic specialists.

Other specialists, such as the surgeons, became suspicious of the Minister's intentions, particularly when he began to change his public explanations of the reasons for section 17. When it was pointed out to him that if diagnosticians were earning too much from the use of public facilities then adjustments could be made by hospitals to charges for facilities, he produced the new argument that he was trying to protect patients from excessive charges, defined by him as charges in excess of the Government schedule fee. Unfortunately for his credibility, it has emerged that diagnostic specialists, almost to a man and to a woman, have not been charging more than the schedule fee. We have had the most extraordinary situation in the States where, when the doctors resisted the contracts under section 17, this Minister asked State Labor colleagues to introduce price control legislation.

I do not know whether honourable members heard the Minister for Health in South Australia, Dr Cornwall, being interviewed on radio one morning last week. Dr Cornwall had the unhappy duty of bringing in price control to force diagnostic specialists in South Australia to charge the schedule fee or less. He said that they all were already charging the schedule fee or less, and that he was perfectly happy with the contracts that they had signed, and that this Federal Minister was coming in and insisting that they sign another piece of paper, and that therefore he, Dr Cornwall, had to take stern action through State regulations to introduce price control to make these diagnostic specialists do something that they were quite happily doing already.

The same thing happened in Victoria. State Health Minister Roper had had discussions with the Australian Medical Assocation in Melbourne. It was quite happy about diagnosticians charging the schedule fee and, in fact, all were charging the schedule fee or less. But the Federal Minister came in and said that the doctors had to sign a piece of paper. So Mr Roper brought in price control regulations to force the diagnostic specialists in Victoria to charge the fees that they were already charging under their existing contracts. In New South Wales the same thing would have happened, the same farce would have occurred, with Mr Mulock had there not been a State election on; but that farce has been reintroduced, immediately after the election, and Mr Mulock in New South Wales has brought in the same kind of unnecessary price control regulations. In New South Wales, too, the diagnostic specialists have been charging the schedule fee or less and, in the case of the radiologists certainly , paying about 60 per cent of their fees as facility charges to the public hospitals.

Why, then, introduce draconian measures at the Federal level and back them up with State price control measures to force doctors to do something that they are already doing voluntarily? I think that the answer can be found in an address given by the Federal Minister to the Doctors' Reform Society in August last year . I should interpose that the word 'reform' in the title of this particular society has about the same level of meaning as the word 'democratic' in the title of the German Democratic Republic. This small society, representing about one per cent of doctors, is always ready to support this Minister in his more reprehensible actions. At this meeting with this Society, referring to the contracts of visiting medical officers, he said:
It was agreed at the July Health Ministers' conference-
that was July 1983-
that attention to these problems should be initially directed to the area of diagnostic services, with the intention to move more broadly in due course.

Thus it is clear that the Minister had already decided, even before introducing the legislation in September, to include other specialties in due course. The surgeons were well justified in their concern. They realised that what was at stake was Federal Government control of the profession on a scale not previously contemplated.

We can understand the Minister's increasingly truculent stance. His core objective is different from the unbelievable one he has used to justify the legislation. But he has also caught himself on a hook. He has contracted to provide to the Australian public services for which he has made no prior arrangements with those being asked to deliver those services. He has prevented himself, under section 17, from paying benefits to patients unless the doctors providing the services have signed a piece of paper. Yet the conditions he has attached to that signature make it impossible for any self-respecting doctor to sign it. Who would be so crazy as to sign a contract that could be altered unilaterally by the other party without legal process, arbitration or appeal? At one stage the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intervened and asked the Australian Medical Association to accept an inquiry into the section 17 issue but the Prime Minister, like the Minister, still insisted that the contracts be signed before the results of the inquiry were available. Again, who could possibly accept that ?

If the Minister is successful in his aims, Medicare will result in all doctors in their surgeries being totally dependent on the Government for their gross income, and all visiting medical officers in the public hospitals will have their contracts directly controlled by the Federal Minister. No wonder the profession is angry and alarmed. So too should patients be angry and alarmed. What is at stake is the future of private medical practice in this country. I have no doubt about the Minister's long term intentions. He wants to move to a British system, but realises that the public would not accept such a proposition if it were advanced openly. He seeks to move by stealth. Indeed, he disclosed his approach and the reasons for it in a speech to the Australian Hospitals Association in Adelaide in 1982 when he was still in opposition. At that meeting he said:
The Party-
meaning the Australian Labor Party-

has put aside any primary emphasis on salaried or capitation systems in pragmatic recognition of the prevailing culture and attitudes in this society and in its effort to secure widespread community support for its program. Private fee-for-service medicine is deeply entrenched in Australian society, strongly defended by the medical profession, and favourably evaluated by the population at large. That is a fact of life and whatever changes we desire in that system will have to take place gradually and incrementally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The present Minister for Health said that to a meeting of the AHA in Adelaide in 1982 when he was the Opposition spokesman on health. In other words, he was saying: 'We do not think we can get away with the abolition of fee-for- service private practice in one hit, so we will do it salami fashion, slice by slice'.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the quality of patient care depends to an enormous extent on the individual motivations, be they professional satisfaction, monetary reward or a mixture of both, of independent private health practitioners, each striving to keep up to date with the state of knowledge and each trying to meet community needs. They are flexible and sensitive intermediaries between the world of knowledge and the world of practice, and they pass the essential signals in both directions. I have immensely more faith in the capacity of hundreds of thousands of independent brains to make the myriad complicated adjustments necessary for this task than I have in the capacity of just a few chosen brains, however brilliant, to decide how all will adjust. In other words, I believe in having hundreds of thousands of independent private medical practitioners making these decisions about patient needs rather than a group of administrators. I fear that the Minister and his advisers are busily constructing a dinosaur. It will be a tragedy for this country if we let them do it. We simply must not let them do it .

Let us examine the amendments that are before the House tonight. These amendments, very clearly, do not get to the heart of the argument. First of all, there is the so-called Haines amendment. This really ought to be called the Baume amendment because it is the amendment that was moved in the Senate last September by my colleague Senator Peter Baume. It was supported then by Senator Haines and one other Australian Democrat, but three Democrats voted with the Government and the amendment was defeated because at that stage, of course, the Government rejected it. All it provides is for parliamentary scrutiny of the guidelines issued under section 17. There is no guarantee in such a procedure against civil conscription, no guarantee that the provisions of section 51 of the Constitution prohibiting civil conscription will be adhered to.

The Minister claimed in his second reading speech that the forces of the market -place would constrain his use of these guidelines. But doctors do not know how a Senate will vote on guidelines. We had the example of the Democrats last September pledging in a joint statement with Senator Harradine and me to oppose certain aspects of Medicare. When it came to a vote in the Senate they switched and voted with the Government and let the measure through. Also, doctors do not know the composition of future Senates. There is no safeguard in a parliamentary scrutiny of the Minister's guidelines under this section. Also-this is more important at the moment-the doctors have no reason whatsoever to trust this Minister or this Government.

Let us consider this Minister's treatment of this highly skilled professional group. Most of them have no interest in politics. Only a few are engaged in political activities all the time. Most of them wish to get on with their private professional work of treating their patients. These people train for long periods and for the most part, with very few exceptions, provide a very satisfactory service to the people of Australia. An opinion poll taken last year showed that they had the support of 60 per cent of the Australian population, placing them in very high regard above any other single profession. These are the people of whom the Prime Minister of this country said: 'They are the builders labourers of the professions'. The Prime Minister compared them with builders labourers. The Minister said of them and of this dispute:
In principle, this dispute is really no different to the Hawke Government's stand in the BLF pay claim.

I cannot think of anything more wounding that a Prime Minister or a Minister for Health could say in the middle of a serious dispute with an honoured profession, a profession facing up to its first strike action in the history of this country , than to compare it with the Builders Labourers Federation which has a reputation in this country as being the worst union in terms of industrial disputes, lawlessness and gangsterism. It is absolutely notorious. Yet all the members of the profession have been branded by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health, in whom they should have confidence, as being like the builders labourers. How on earth could that profession have any confidence in this Minister and his guidelines?

The second amendment moved by the Government at this stage allows the Minister to exempt any doctor from the guidelines if State government rules achieve what the Federal Minister wants. Again, there is no safeguard in that. The Minister, in his second reading speech yesterday, gave his game away yet again. He simply does not understand the nature of the problem he is dealing with. He said:
. . . we cannot and will not be deterred from the principle of section 17 . . .

What is this sacred principle of section 17? Honourable members should remember that it gives power to control all doctors' contracts, not just diagnostic specialists' contracts. Is that the principle that is so sacred, the power over all contracts? I thought diagnostic fees were the problem. But it is power over all contracts. Is that the sacred principle? We now know that in July last year the Minister decided with the State Ministers that he would move on to other specialities in due course. How would this affect surgeons for example? The guidelines he quoted in his speech include:
(a) All accounts to be raised by the hospital on behalf of the doctor.
(b) All charges to be at or below schedule fee.

What would the consequences of this be for a surgeon? A surgeon is threatened by section 17. What about the doctor-patient relationship? Who employs the doctor? Is it the patient or is it the Minister? The Minister thinks he is the employer. In support of his argument he foolishly quoted an editorial from the Sydney Morning Herald and unwittingly revealed his view of himself in relation to the doctors. I quote from the same editorial from which the Minister quoted:
Dr Blewett's power under Section 17 is certainly no more and probably a great deal less than that of any other employer.
