I stress the word 'employer'. Does he not realise that that is a lunatic thing to say to the independent specialists? Does not he realise that he is flaunting before the doctors his disregard for section 51 of the Constitution? They regard the patient as their employer. The patients regard themselves as the employers of the doctors. Now that the Minister has, under Medicare, made illegal all forms of private medical insurance and pays 85 per cent of the schedule fee out of taxpayers' funds he has elevated himself to the role of employer of doctors. That is what section 17 is about. That is why these amendments are a waste of time.

Guideline (b) restricts the doctor to the schedule fee or less. If this is applied to our surgeons a surgeon of exceptional skill, at the peak of his powers, will not be able to charge more for his services than a surgeon just out of training. That is what the Australian Labor Party wants, but it is not what Australians want. That is a recipe for mediocrity and the surgeons know it. We know it is part of the accord to bring all incomes from professional people under control. It is not incomes that the Government is controlling, it is prices. Costs are to be subtracted from those fees, whatever the profession. This Government, as part of the accord, wishes to bring into control the price of all those services of the professions and small businesses. In this case if the Government controls the surgeons' fees and contracts it is a recipe for mediocrity. If it happens patients will be the losers. The quality of health care will fall.

What must be done to get out of this appalling mess? Quite simply we must get rid of the civil conscription provisions of section 17 that were put into the legislation last September. They were never necessary to achieve the Minister's stated objectives of reducing the costs of diagnostic services. Indeed, they are in no way essential to the running of Medicare. The costs of the diagnostic services are probably about 3.5 per cent of the nation's health bill. Presumably , if these costs are too high, we are talking about a proportion of 3.5 per cent of the nation's health bill. Medicare would go on with section 17 provisions removed. The Minister must accept the Opposition's private member's Bill, expunge those clauses, go back to the doctors and seek their co-operation in solving his diagnostic problem if that is his real concern.

Whilst section 17 is inessential for Medicare, its continuance in its present form is the canker that will destroy Medicare and this Minister. While it is there he will not have the confidence of doctors. Without their co-operation he will have no Medicare. Therefore I say to this Minister: Withdraw these unnecessary and offensive provisions. Withdraw them or resign and let somebody else do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is determined to succeed in providing for the Australian people an efficient health care system of the highest quality . This it is doing through Medicare. Certain doctors are determined to destroy Medicare. The Australian people are determined to have Medicare. They understand it and they want it. But certain doctors have deliberately devised tactics to confuse and mislead the public and the rest of their profession and to hinder the Government's operation of Medicare. They will not win. The Australian people will win. They understand very clearly what benefits there are for them under Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: Certain doctors, in their long battle to destroy Medicare, have now settled on industrial action. The Health Insurance Amendment Bill is a positive step by the Government to seek a resolution of the dispute before this current industrial action, which is causing inconvenience to patients, escalates to a point where it could endanger patients. This legislation provides the immediate safeguard the profession has sought. It amends section 17 of the Medicare legislation, that section which the doctors claimed gave the Minister unfettered power to regulate them.

It was a long battle before this stage was reached. In fact, this is the doctors' last stand. It is a pretty unreasonable stand and a lot of people agree on that. Some of my colleagues will quote from editorials from some of the most conservative newspapers in this country which point out how unreasonable the stand of the doctors is. The doctors have been able to put their very considerable resources into this battle. I would like to quote from a letter from the Australian Association of Surgeons written to its members on 8 March.
Many members responded to our earlier requests for a donation of $250 per quarter over 12 months and the time has now fallen due for the next quarterly instalment.

That money is to be used in a propaganda campaign. It might be necessary to point out to some honourable members opposite that a single person, aged 18 years or more on the dole, gets $295 a month. Yet the Australian Association of Surgeons can ask its members for $250 a quarter just for a propaganda campaign. The doctors have certainly had all the money that they have needed for their campaign. But, after all, they are not interested in money. Money is not the object of the exercise. It does not mean much to them at all, or so they say.

In this long struggle what have the doctors' tactics been? In their initial attempt to undermine Medicare they refused to bulk bill. These doctors know that if the cost to the taxpayer is to be kept to a minimum the co-operation of the doctors to bulk bill is important. If honourable members opposite, who seem to be supporting that tiny group of doctors conducting this campaign, do not believe that doctors would stoop to misleading in their tactics, let me read to them from a journal called Medical Practice, Australia's medical news magazine incorporating the AMA Gazette. I must point out that the Australian Medical Association says it does not endorse everything in this journal. But an article in this journal on practice management entitled 'Bulk Billing: How to Present Your Policy' gave doctors some tips on how to explain to the patients just why they would not bulk bill. The article states:
If patients argue that the rebate fee is the 'right' fee they are likely to say : 'Your doctor is overcharging'.
The doctor is advised to tell his staff to respond:
'No. This is the fee charged by private doctors. If you want the rebate ( discounted) fee you will have to go to a Government doctor, a Medicare doctor.'
I ask honourable members to listen to this. Staff might say to the patient as the article states:

. . . we are very happy to tell you that doctor has decided to retain his private practice and is not conforming with the Government's Medicare payment plan. This means he can continue to give you his best quality service. You are not coming to a government doctor.

What a hide. Fancy disparaging the care that doctors always give their patients by saying that if one goes to a government doctor one will not get the best quality care. Honourable members should listen to this. The doctors have been advised in the article to put this in their policy:
Our health care policy is to remain as private practitioners and therefore we do not conform with the Medicare payment plan.
I guarantee that plenty of people have seen that on doctors' surgery walls. The article continues:
'I hope you are happy that I am endeavouring to retain my status as a private practitioner, Mrs Brown . . . You didn't really want me to become just a Government doctor did you Mrs Brown?'

What is 'just a government doctor'? Every doctor in this country can now have his fees paid through Medicare and every person who needs medical care in Australia can get the best quality medical care. I happen to be one of those people who believes that every doctor in this country gives of his best to his patients. Certainly those doctors in private practice who bulk bill are still the best possible doctors and are still retaining their private practice. I am also one of the people who believes that not one of the doctors would have succumbed to the advice given to them in the magazine.

The point is that Medicare has survived and will survive that particular tactic . Most doctors are bulk billing. So that tactic failed. I point out though that it is often put to me by certain top surgeons that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is arrogant. After having read out the sorts of terms in which doctors are advised to speak to their patients, I think they have a bit of a hide to talk about arrogance. After that tactic had failed, the next step was to pick out an area which attempted to put a ceiling on fees. This is an area in the Medicare legislation. That is a very expensive area that relates to diagnostic services, such as pathology, radiology, radiotherapy and nuclear medicine. This is a very high cost area of Medicare with a significant technical content. These services are provided by the use of public equipment and public facilities. These very costly facilities are taxpayer funded, so it is only right that there should be a wider degree of public accountability.

The basic aims of the Federal Government in introducing the contracts between the doctors in this particular area and the hospital is to limit the amounts of money these specialists can claim for private patients by preventing specialists from charging above the schedule fee for their services and by placing a ceiling of $62,500 on specialists' income above which the hospital takes a percentage which is paid into a hospital fund. Although these working conditions are unacceptable to the AMA they are in fact pretty reasonable if not too generous. At the moment when private specialists visit hospitals they examine a certain amount of cases and charge for each individual case. The doctor is required to pay the hospital 20 per cent of his schedule fee for the use of hospital facilities. For example, if the schedule fee is $50 the hospital receives $10. The doctor can charge the patient more than the schedule fee. However, the hospital is entitled to none of the money charged in excess of the schedule fee. The proposed hospital contracts will prevent doctors charging patients fees in excess of the schedule fee and thus try to keep down rising health costs.

The second proposal of the contracts is to place a ceiling on the income of private and salaried specialists in any one hospital at $62,500. However, the income of private specialists is not limited to this amount. They can go over it . If they exceed this amount the specialists are required to pay 25 per cent of any further income into the hospital fund. If they earn over $87,000 they are required to pay 40 per cent. However, this condition is no great kick in the teeth for the money paid into hospital funds is used really to further the doctors' profession and their professional career. Furthermore, the limits of $ 62,500 and $87,000 restrict only how much a private specialist may earn in any one hospital. So it is possible for a private specialist to be earning this much in two or three hospitals. The Australian Association of Surgeons protested against the Government's moves. It really homed in on this one. It thought that this was something it could get the Government on. It encouraged its members to refuse to do non-urgent operations on Thursday, 1 March for 24 hours. The AMA was not the initiator of the decision but supported the surgeons' actions.

It is very hard now to work out what the doctors want. It is not just the money . I can understand doctors wanting to make a fortune; I can understand a plumber wanting to make a fortune; I can understand a school teacher wanting to make a fortune; but what I cannot understand is why, in their efforts to make that fortune, they would want to sabotage a health insurance system that is benefiting every Australian. So what do the doctors want? I will tell honourable members what they want. They want only one thing and that is to destroy Medicare . Any attempts to understand what they really want come up against some pretty extraordinary attitudes amongst the profession. They really seem to think that we want to hurt the work they do. They really seem to think that Medicare was designed to destroy health standards in Australia.

As the Minister for Health said in his second reading speech yesterday, it would not be in the interests of any government, let alone a Labor Government, to introduce guidelines that prompted an exodus of specialists from the public hospital system. We depend on these people for the excellence of care that is currently provided in our public hospitals. Rights of private practice are an important element in attracting high quality medical staff to the public hospitals. This Government believes that, while some of those private practice rights are in need of reform, it would be counterproductive in the extreme to abolish them. In fact, if a government were foolish enough to impose unreasonable guidelines under section 17 these specialists would have an immediate recourse to withdraw their already established private practices outside public hospitals. They obviously do not need the direct protection of a law necessary for a salaried employee. Nevertheless, the Government has tried every possible way to come up with reasonable terms to meet the doctors' objections whilst sticking to the principles of the section 17 arrangements.

I will go through some of the stages chronologically in this long battle by the doctors: On 11 January 1984 the Minister met with representatives of the AMA to discuss their objections. On 24 January the Minister announced he would set up the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals under the chairmanship of Professor David Penington. On 9 February the AMA's attention then turned to the Minister's unfettered powers under section 17 to alter their conditions. In negotiations with the AMA it was agreed that terms of reference for the Penington inquiry would include consultative procedures prior to variation of the guidelines and appeal or review procedures in relation to these arrangements. The Minister also gave the AMA a guarantee that the guidelines would not be altered or extended until the report of the inquiry had been extended. So the AMA then objected to the new national list of facility charges for prescribed diagnostic items. Again, the Government agreed to refer the question of the national list of facility charges to the inquiry and to allow the existing facility charges to remain in force until the inquiry reported.

On 16 February the AMA did agree to participate in the inquiry and that was the only concession it made. However, following the 16 February meeting the Federal President of the AMA, Dr Thompson, publicly stated that the Government's concessions and the inquiry had provided a real basis for a resolution of the dispute. Some people just do not take into account the determination of certain doctors. On 22 February the Government's proposals were rejected by a meeting of the AMA and specialist groups. Then the guidelines that were introduced on 29 February were revised to ensure that the only significant requirements for the agreements between the hospital and the doctor were that charges raised be at or below the schedule fee. This is not a government fee. It is a fee set annually by an independent arbitrator after hearing argument from the Government, the AMA and other interested parties.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we suspended the sitting for dinner at 6.30 I was detailing the long struggle between a certain group in the medical profession and the Government on the Medicare legislation. Rather than sum up what I have been saying I will quote from an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 February 1984. It is not often I will quote that paper to sum up my arguments but this, I think, is very accurate. At the end of the editorial entitled 'Doctors, cash and mystique', the Herald stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The provision of diagnostic services is notorious for over-servicing. The Federal Government would be derelict in its duty to the public if it did not seek to control over-servicing and the exploitation of public hospital facilities for private gain. The Government has been most conciliatory, indeed, compromising in its dealings with the AMA. It should now stand firm and let the doctors do their worst. And the long-suffering public should be under no illusion as to the respective identities of the good guys and the bad guys.

Having identified us with the good guys, and even girls, I will continue by saying that I had reached the stage in chronologically going through some of the steps in the battle where the guidelines introduced on 29 February were revised to ensure that the only significant requirement for the agreements between the hospital and the doctor was that charges raised be at or below the schedule fee. I repeat a very important point: This is not a government fee. It is a fee set annually by an independent arbitrator after hearing argument from government, the Australian Medical Association and other interested parties.

At a meeting on 2 March the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) offered, first, to give an undertaking in writing that during the period of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals there would be no change of any sort in the guidelines as gazetted on 29 February or in the details of their application; and, second, in respect of the recommendations of the Penington Committee relating to appeal and review procedures, that the Government would advise the Penington Committee that the it had no objection to recommendations providing for such procedures and would accept the recommendations of the inquiry on that matter.

In return, the Government sought an assurance that the AMA would recommend to the members of its profession that they sign written agreements in accordance with current guidelines and, secondly, that there be no discrimination against Medicare-only patients in recognised hospitals. The Federal AMA agreed that this was reasonable but the compromise offered by the Prime Minister was rejected at a meeting of the AMA. Several attempts to arrange a meeting of the Federal and State health Ministers with the Federal and State branches of the AMA and the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists have failed because the medical profession has refused to attend.

We have reached the stage tonight where, because Senator Haines of the Australian Democrats has put forward a constructive proposal which would give immediate substance to the Prime Minister's undertaking of 2 March to institute appeal provisions into section 17 of the Health Insurance Act, we are putting forward this Bill. The Government has adopted Senator Haines's proposal in this Bill. Therefore, there can now be no argument that the Minister's powers under section 17 of the Act will be considerably fettered and restricted both formally through legislation as well as in practical reality.

The two practical objectives of this Bill are to empower the Senate to disallow guidelines on doctors' contracts if it believes the guidelines are unreasonable and enable the Government to pay Medicare benefits for services even when doctors refuse to sign disputed contracts. In addition, the Government has agreed in principle to regular arbitrated review of the schedule fee after negotiations with the AMA. As the Minister pointed out in his second reading speech, the speed with which the Government moved to secure an arbitrated interim fee increase once the wage pause was ended should also establish the genuine interest of the Government in this matter.

I am sure that the majority of the medical profession will accept this public act of good faith by the Government and cease the current industrial action in the best interests of their patients' welfare. As a matter of fact, I am astounded that the Opposition is not accepting this. Certain doctors have tried to destroy Medicare but the only casualty of the doctors' action will be the doctors' reputations. Certain top, expensive, yacht-sailing, born-to-be-better- than-the-rest-of-us specialist doctors will fall from the pedestal on which our respect previously placed them. The person who will go on to a pedestal in the opinion of the Australian people will be the current Minister for Health.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Parliament has quite a number of recently arrived members and many honourable members who have been here for only a handful of years who would not recall the early 1970s when the now Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) as Minister for Social Security set about introducing Medibank. The opposition to Medibank and the determination of the medical profession to oppose it is much the same today as it was then. In the early 1970s the doctors said: 'We will make a fortune out of Medibank, but despite that we are opposed to it'. That was the view of 99 per cent of the profession. They believed very strongly and rigidly that the socialisation, the nationalisation, of health would mean the destruction of what is probably the world's best health system. That is what we are witnessing now-another step down the road.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot blame any doctor in this country for not trusting the Australian Labor Party in government in its approach to health.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look what they did at the last election.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Melbourne to cease interjecting.

—Mr Speaker, it is obvious we need a couple of psychiatrists in this Parliament to treat some of the left wing members of the Australian Labor Party who are going berserk at the very suggestion that doctors may be motivated by something other than money. Doctors came out of the original Medibank a lot richer than they had been in pre-Medibank days. Doctors then could say, 'We told you so'. It was the government system. The Labor Government implanted into this country a cancerous system in terms of medical care it took from the United Kingdom. Now the Labor Government is modelling its health system on the Canadian system.
—You promised to retain it in 1975. You promised to retain Medibank.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne will cease interjecting.
—Opposition members are quite upset. They cannot deal with rational argument.
—Order! I ask the honourable member not to invite interjection.

—I see that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is in the chamber. I will give three or four examples of why the people of Australia, particularly the doctors, should not trust the intention of the Government in anything it tries to implement in relation to health care. That is why the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the shadow Minister for Health, who is at the table proposed this afternoon that we abandon the proposed new section and go back to the drawing board. It makes a lot of sense because without the co-operation of the medical profession our health system will not work as it should.

SPEECH.PARA: The employees of the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia are an example of why nobody should trust the intentions of the present Government. On 13 August last year the Minister for Health signed a letter himself telling Senator Martin that :
The Health Insurance Commission will be giving preference in employment to former health fund staff.
On the second page of the letter he continued:
The Government is taking special steps to deal with this period-
The letter continues. I will not use up my time any further on the letter. The other day the Medical Benefits Fund in Queensland was forced to dismiss 37 workers. A newspaper article about it states:
Another 37 Medical Benefits Fund workers were retrenched yesterday, taking the total number of sackings in the State to 83.
A spokesman for the Health Minister, Dr Blewett, said that there was no guarantee that any of the workers would receive jobs with Medicare.

Heaven forbid! Every time the Government wants to back off on something it is a case of 'a spokesman says'. A few days ago I took on what the Government was doing in relation to Medicare and I have in my possession another letter from the Minister for Health which was addressed to all the pensioners in Australia telling them:
. . . DO NOT follow the instructions to complete an enrolment application.

A letter from another socialist, Mr Wilcox, the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission, was sent to all the pensioner organisations telling them to tell their members not to join up, that the Government would arrange it automatically. We find that in the last few weeks the system has broken down. The system has not been working. I made public comment on it and what did I get? Another spokesman for Medicare made a statement. Nobody will ever identify himself. They are all spokesmen; they do not have the courage of their convictions. The Minister signs the letters and it is a spokesman who does the dirty work. It is like telling someone to go into the death chamber in San Quentin and that nothing will happen to him. That is what the Government has in mind for the doctors. A couple of days ago the shadow Minister for Health alluded to the speech which the Minister for Health gave last year or in 1982 to the Doctors Reform Society stating that the Government is out to destroy, to nationalise and to socialise the whole system. That is the Government's ultimate aim.

What have we seen so far? All the happy lefties are sitting in a row, like green bottles, clapping. They are attacking members of the medical profession saying that their only motive is that of monetary consideration, referring to them as fat yachties falling down from pedestals, from the masts of their yachts , et cetera. You do not understand. You believe that our society is best built by ripping down people from the top, that we should level out the whole of society and everyone will share the proceeds. What you do not understand is that if we have a society in which people can aim to better their standards and to better their ways it is a system which allows people to improve themselves and to progress up the ladder. What do you want to do? Do you want to turn everybody into a public servant? You want to turn every doctor into a public servant and that is your ultimate goal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I invite the honourable member to address the Chair instead of Government members.
—Mr Speaker, I appreciate your impartiality in this matter. I know that as a former doctor you are shaking your head in total agreement with what I am saying.
—That is most unfair.

—I also wish to make the point that people have no reason to trust the Labor Party on this matter. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), said with an appealing voice: 'Of course we cannot afford to offend the doctors. Of course we do not wish them to leave the hospitals. We are dependent upon them. We will not risk losing them'. Half of the speech that the Minister for Health made yesterday refers to the fact that the Government will do nothing to endanger the goodwill of members of the medical profession because we want them in the public hospitals. But the facts are that the constraints and controls that the Minister has introduced under Medicare upon the private hospital system also ensures that the longevity of the private sector in the hospital field is also without guarantee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has categorised hospitals into three groups to determine how much financial contribution the Federal Government will make and how much money the health funds are allowed to pay hospitals. It is a form of control on hospitals. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Beddall) and a Labor member of the Queensland State Parliament, Mr Goss, made headlines on 20 March in Brisbane in a widely read newspaper called the Southern Star. They claimed that the health services in the Sunnybank Private Hospital in the southern suburbs of Brisbane are being threatened by lack of support from the State Health Minister; it was all his fault that the categorisation system was introduced! A few days later I received a letter from the Minister for Health. He signed the letter so I suppose at the time he meant what was said. It states:
I refer to your personal representations on behalf of the Sunnybank Private Hospital concerning the categorisation of that hospital under Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that we are dealing with the Health Insurance Amendment Bill, which is narrow in its ambit, but debate has been widened by the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar. The honourable member is straying from the subject of the Bill and the amendment. I ask him to pay some regard to that.

—Mr Speaker, I am trying to outline why doctors have every justification for failing to accept the word of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I am giving examples in writing. I am trying to outline where this Government has let down people, the medical profession or others in the field of health care. That is what I am endeavouring to do.
—I was hoping I would bring the honourable member back to that point.
—I will stick to that subject. The letter, which is on this subject, continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Acting on the formal request by the hospital that I review the initial category determined for it, I have examined the hospital's submission that it should be reclassified from Category 2 to Category 1. As a result of my examination,-
this is Dr Blewett-
I have decided to confirm the initial category determined for the hospital.
The hospital has been advised by my Department of my decision, and that a statement of reasons will be forwarded as soon as possible.

So the letter goes on. We have Labor politicians running around the electorate saying that the State is responsible for the categorisation of hospitals which has almost forced the closure of some private hospitals in Queensland. Yet the letter I have quoted is a clear example of the fact that it is something that was invented by the Minister for Health. It was introduced with Medicare and it is something which has stripped the private sector once again.

I have another letter stating why people have no reason to trust Labor and why doctors should be and are particularly concerned. My office received the letter vocadexed from a constituent in my electorate. The letter talks about the writer 's daughter. Before the days of Medicare when she went to her general practitioner she paid him $18.60 per visit and always recovered the lot from a private health fund. Now she can recover only $9.90 from Medicare-she adds that this amount is sometimes increased to $10.20-and therefore she will be out of pocket.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the schedule fee? The doctor is ripping her off.
—The honourable member should just quieten down. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: On discussing this with our doctor, he informed me that Item 5 which is a normal consultation, applies from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. daily Monday to Friday and 8 A.M. to 1 P.M. Saturday. In other words, a G.P. is expected to work for 65 hours per week at ordinary common fee or charges.
My constituent states:
This is absolutely outrageous, as what unionist, or average person works even better than 40 hours for standard pay.
She goes on to make a case. The only mistake the person made is when she said:
. . . I would like to know if Dr Blewett would work for 65 hours per week for ordinary pay.

I can assure that constituent that the Minister for Health would probably work for about 100 hours a week for a set salary. That is probably one of the problems that he has brought on his own shoulders as a result of his intransigence. To return to the Bill, I believe that the medical profession has every reason to be wary and concerned about the long term intentions of the Minister for Health and nearly every Labor Party politician because they are out to destroy the profession, to socialise and nationalise it and to strip it of its individualism. The tragedy is that half the Labor Party members do not understand that there is a relationship between the doctor and the patient which has been created as a result of a system which, even with its warts and weaknesses in the past, has been allowed to exist in this country for so long. It is absolutely ironic that it was the Curtin Labor Government that in 1946 proposed an alteration to the Constitution to try to protect the medical profession and the dentistry profession from nationalisation.

The Minister is an academic doctor-he is not a doctor of medicine-who sat in his enclave in Adelaide for all these years dreaming up how to evolve the perfect health system. He talks in the House about the two million people he claims were previously not covered. I will willingly concede that the one thing wrong with the previous health system which existed in this country was that there was too much of a cut-off point in terms of income and that there was not graded assistance from those who had their health benefits completely paid. The Minister knows what I am talking about. If we had introduced the graded system there would not have been any problem with the health system which previously existed.

But what the Government has done is to tip out the lot. It has tipped out the baby with the water. It has completely changed and transformed the system and has set about to destroy the private sector and the health funds. Without returning to an old hobby horse, it was proved year in, year out that Medibank Private, which was a government instrumentality, was the most cost inefficient health fund in Australia. It was virtually bankrupt in four of the six States. Yet what has been done? We have handed the whole health care system to an organisation that was devoid of success, that did not have the track record, because the Minister is paranoid about the private sector. He will not allow the private sector to have any part in providing an agency service for Medicare. There are people who have to walk for miles to get a health refund.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member ought to return to the Bill and the amendment.

—I was just about to say that the doctors feel very acutely for their patients. They do not want to have happen to them what the Government has done to the people of Australia in relation to Medicare. In conclusion, I do not believe that there is one member on this side of the chamber who would condone stoppages. Honourable members on this side of the House have always been consistent in their attitude to strikes. The Australian Labor Party, on the other hand, is selective. If the stoppage involves members of a professional group, they are looked upon as evil men. If they are non-professionals, their stoppages are justified. The Government believes there is further justification if it can tear down the capitalists and destroy the system.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the House do not condone stoppages. But we understand and, as far as I am concerned, the doctors have every justification for not having trust. The track record of the Labor Party Government is such that they would be putting their heads into a noose and letting the trapdoor drop. That is exactly how I see it. The Government is disinclined to accept the very sensible request from the Opposition that it go back to the drawing board and try to work out a scheme and a system with which the doctors will comply. One fact of life is that we cannot make a health system work properly without the co-operation of those who dispense the health care, and that is the medical profession, not the academic doctor who sits in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When it is all boiled down, this whole issue is about the accountability of the medical profession to the taxpayer and the consumer. The strike action of the Australian Medical Association is a high handed, spoilt brat response to the Australian Government, the Australian taxpayer and the Australian consumer of medical services. The Jamison Report on the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals clearly supports the Government's action and the people of Australia clearly support the Health Insurance Amendment Bill. Judging by the phone calls that I constantly get in my office, the community is absolutely incensed by the greed and elitism of the specialists and the medical profession in general.

SPEECH.PARA: But the Australian Association of Surgeons, in a letter from its Federal President, Peter Jones, and Federal Secretary, Michael Aroney, to all its members, has a different view. A letter dated 8 March and headed 'Private and Confidential'-we might all ask why it is headed 'Private and Confidential' if these surgeons are acting so nobly in the public interest on such an issue- states:

It would appear that health has become the province of the far left of the Federal Government and this is a trade-off so that Mr Hawke may manage the economy without interference from the socialist left.

As one of the socialist left I do not have many occasions when I can quote from probably the most conservative newspaper in Australia, Rupert Murdoch's Adelaide newspaper, the News. But I can clearly quote from today's editorial. Today's editorial which is headed 'Militant medical madness' states:
. . . on any reasonable assessment of the dispute, it is obvious that the Federal Government has bent over backwards to accommodate the doctors.It has provided for an independent inquiry.
It has even been prepared to give authority over public hospital contract guidelines to a Senate in which it does not have a majority.
For doctors then to take to the streets of Adelaide and other cities and to threaten a national strike is irresponsible and plain wrong.
The Government is almost frantically waving an olive branch. The AMA is brandishing a cudgel.
The well-paid doctors should immediately do what they will have to do eventually anyway, sit down, stop making threats, and start talking commonsense.

This whole issue is about accountability. It is about the refusal and the inability of members of the medical profession to regulate their own profession in line with what should be their responsibility to society, the taxpayer and the consumer. After thousands of years members of the medical profession, be they witch doctors or our finest surgeons, should now realise that they are not a glorified secret society of infallible gods and godesses.

Before I go any further, let me state clearly, unequivocally and emphatically that not all doctors support this rogue action of the elitist AMA. Not all doctors are as insensitive and greedy as the majority attitude represented by the AMA. I have tremendous respect for the skill and the worth of doctors and, in so many cases, the social responsibility that they exhibit. But I ask those doctors who are incensed about the action of the AMA to stand up now and make their voices heard before it is too late.

The AMA is giving all doctors a bad name, just as the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) has brought disgrace on his parliamentary colleagues for his puerile and arrogant attack on unemployed people. While I do have respect in many ways for the medical profession, I must now point out what is really going on. I say again that this whole issue is about the total accountability and responsibility of the medical profession. This issue is not just about how much a doctor should be able to charge in a public hospital. This aspect is just a symptom of the decadent irresponsiblity and greed. It is clear from this rogue action of the AMA that the AMA and the majority of its members are quite emphatically stating that the public does not have any right to interfere in any way with their profession and with their business.

It is clear that the AMA believes doctors should not be scrutinised in any way, whether it be in the fees they charge or in their professional skills. The medical profession believes, and by its actions and its inaction it clearly shows, that the public in its eyes has no rights. Just to show honourable members what I mean, in 1981 one of my constituents was advised not to have any more children and she subsequently underwent a very simple procedure by surgical standards, a tubal ligation. Normally, the woman would have been unconscious for a few hours at most and in hospital at most for two nights. But because the surgeon perforated the bowel of my constituent with the veness needle used in that procedure, a further emergency operation was needed to save her life. What should have been a simple, no risk operation left my constituent unconscious for 28 hours instead of two, in hospital for 10 days instead of two days, and unnecessarily scarred physically, psychologically and financially.

What happens in such a case? This is the accountability that is part of the issue. Does my constituent have any redress as a consumer, because a patient is a consumer of the medical profession? She does have these rights but they are effectively denied to her and just about any other person by the closed shop of the medical profession. While the public quite correctly respects and values the doctors' skills as healers and lifesavers, the public also quite correctly has the right to expect that doctors will professionally accept their fallibility and responsibility for their actions and skills.

If a doctor, either by fallible accident or crass incompetence, causes unnecessary injury to a patient, the patient has the right, in law, to expect rectification of the problem without cost and to be able to claim compensation for the damage. But we all know that if the job is botched we do not have a hope in hell of fair and responsible compensation for our pain and any long term consequences. The truth is that any doctor who testified against another would be ostracised by his or her peers in a way that would make the greatest mythological union heavy look just like Father Christmas. Let us not kid ourselves. A doctor who is prepared to stand up for the rights of the patient or for the consumer in this way would be destroyed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member to be somewhat more relevant to the Bill.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am trying to stress that the whole issue is about accountability. I believe that my constituent has suffered at the hands of the medical profession because of this lack of accountability. In response to that she was sent to a solicitor and the solicitor sent her to a doctor. She was told that she should consider herself lucky, she should be grateful.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. You have just asked the honourable member to be relevant and he has just continued on without--
—Don't try to cover up.
—I am not trying to cover up anything. I am trying to get at least a little bipartisanship and a non-partisan approach into this chamber.
—Well, let him finish what he is saying.
—Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will remain silent .

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The Speaker, who was in the chair before you, allowed a considerable degree of relevance to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), who did not at any stage mention anything in the Bill whatsoever. I presumed therefore that there was a degree of freedom about debate on the health insurance measure.
—I was not here to hear that, I am sorry. But I still ask the honourable member to try to restrict himself to somewhere near the Bill.

—My constituent is in the situation whereby she is forced to pay thousands of dollars. We are talking about the fees of the medical profession and what its members expect for that money and what consumers can expect for the money that they have to pay either as individual consumers or taxpayers. Where people are expected to pay over and above the schedule fee this case is particularly relevant. That person has paid out thousands and thousands of dollars to a doctor who did not charge the schedule fee. So that person is suffering regardless. I think that in this instance when the medical profession has decided to take such rogue action in this regard it should be listening to the sorts of comments that it faces and which are not allowed to be brought up in the courts because of the profession's closed-shop attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: The doctor concerned privately admitted his mistake to her. Other doctors have privately admitted it. As I said before, the reference which the solicitors got was that she should be grateful that she was not killed. The inference was that she should be grateful that the doctor saw what had happened before he withdrew his instruments. I think that is a disgrace. I think it is a sham, like most of the other things that are going on in the AMA at the moment. I wonder whether anyone in the medical profession is prepared to stand up to the AMA on behalf of my constituent or in regard to the fees doctors are charging now as private practitioners in public hospitals. Every year thousands of people-men, women and children-find themselves up against the cold, impenetrable wall of silence, a wall of intimidation, irresponsibility and downright injustice. This woman was told that she was more in need of a good psychiatrist than a good lawyer by this witness doctor of hers. If she had had a good doctor in the first place she would not have needed either a good psychiatrist or a good lawyer. But now she needs both.

If doctors are prepared to admit that they can make mistakes and that any medical misadventure is more than just an act of God, if honourable members will pardon the pun, they might find that they would be more genuinely respected by the community and not seen as gold miners and elitist quacks. Perhaps some of them would find their consciences easy to live with as well if they would accept their responsibility to their patients more openly and humanely.

The Australian public also has other rights. Apart from their rights as consumers and individuals they have their rights as taxpayers as well. Just as we expect our soldiers, who have been debated in this House today, who are trained and equipped by public money to behave responsibly, so we expect our doctors, who are trained by public money, to behave responsibly. The private doctors who are striking because the Government is insisting that they charge a schedule fee in public hospitals when they use public facilities were also publicly trained and equipped in our public hospitals. Two-thirds of our so- called private admissions by these doctors are to public hospitals. The taxpayer is paying massive hidden subsidies to these private practitioners who demand that they should charge what they like, when they like, at taxpayers' expense.

It costs the Australian taxpayer at least $100,000 to put a doctor through a basic medical degree in an Australian university. In any one year the Australian taxpayer is investing about $200m in educating doctors. In any five-year group, by the time a medical student has gone in one end and come out the other with a degree, the Australian taxpayer will have invested $1,000m. One thousand million dollars of taxpayers' money is invested in educating doctors. I think that is particularly relevant. If the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) did not think that the other point was relevant, that point is. Hard work, sweat and blood of millions of Australian workers goes on the education of doctors alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—The former Minister for Health laughs. Workers' investment in their health and in their families' health is important. No one denies that doctors work very hard and that literally they can achieve miracles. But they should also be reminded who paid for them to learn their skills and on top of that, who buys the equipment and technology used in our hospitals, who builds our hospitals and who supports the paramedical services. No one denies a doctor's right to earn a decent living commensurate with his skills. That should not be denied to any worker. But when radiologists claim that their charges are high because there is a shortage of radiologists, they do not say that it is they who literally have most of the control of the number of radiologists in this country . It is a farce and a con job all the way down the line.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note at this stage the attitude of members of the Opposition, those who cackle on the other side. Clearly they support the AMA in this rogue action. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) writes letters to them, begging for money. Clearly the Liberal Party wants its share of the loot as well. The Australian public has been outraged. It is insulted by the overservicing, the outrageous charges, medifraud, and the high-handed arrogance and social irresponsibility of so many members of the medical business. It is about time that the medical profession took stock of itself. The AMA is not a divine union. Its members do make mistakes which cause untold financial and physical hardship to some of its consumers. These consumers need protection and fair claim to compensation. It is well overdue; it is hundreds and it is thousands of years overdue.

The South Australian Government is taking steps to protect South Australian patients by bringing in extensive changes to its Medical Practitioners Act. Other enlightened States, such as Victoria, are considering similar steps. On 13 , 14 and 15 April the Victorian Parliament's Social Development Committee will conduct a phone-in to hear from people who have complaints about medical care and the medical profession.

This Federal Government is committed to the principle that all Australians have a right to good medical care at a reasonable expense. This Bill clearly has the support of everybody except the Liberal-National Party Opposition and a few members of the AMA. Australia is sick of the spoilt prima donnas of the medical profession. If the medical profession and the Liberal Party want further evidence of this I again turn to the editorial in today's Adelaide News, that conservative newspaper, headed 'Militant Medical Madness'. It states:
. . . on any reasonable assessment of the dispute, it is obvious that the Federal Government has bent over backwards to accommodate the doctors.
It has provided for an independent inquiry. It has even been prepared to give authority over public hospital contract guidelines to a Senate in which it does not have a majority.
For doctors then to take to the streets of Adelaide and other cities and to threaten a national strike is irresponsible and plain wrong.
The Government is almost frantically waving an olive branch. The AMA is brandishing a cudgel.
The well-paid doctors should immediately do what they will have to do eventually anyway, sit down, stop making threats and start talking commonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that most of the arguments seem to have been canvassed on both sides. I intend to be fairly brief. This debate is over the control of diagnostic testing. I refer honourable members to the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. One of the recommendations of that inquiry was an urgent review by each of the employment authorities, that is, the hospitals in most cases, of the standards of the salaries set for diagnostic specialists. I ask the Minister for Health ( Dr Blewett): Why, if that is the recommendation of the Jamison inquiry, does he not accept that the independent authorities and the doctors can work out their own problems? If diagnosticians are exceeding what is a fair go in these hospitals, why not let the hospital authority sort it out? Why does the Minister , big brother, have to step in and say: 'I will control all--
—On behalf of the taxpayer.
—The taxpayers be damned, this is a matter--
—Exactly how you think!
—What do you mean by that?

—If those opposite do not mind, I would rather the Minister answer these questions than the mad lefty group over there. In steps the Minister for Health and says: 'I will control them all, despite the recommendations of the Jamison inquiry'. If there are those who are exceeding a fair go, and the medical profession is only too happy to agree that a minority of doctors might be ripping off the system, why cannot the authorities and the doctors sort it out? I would be interested to hear why not. But no, the Minister steps in and says: 'I will fix all this. I will be the decider. There will be no right of appeal'. I put to the House: Would anybody in his right mind put his future into the hands of one man, particularly the Minister for Health who is hell bent on introducing socialised medicine into this country? We are not talking about strike action. We are talking about support for the stance of the doctors and that support is forthcoming from this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us move on to another matter. The Minister has agreed that the original proposals in his Bill are now to be amended. That is what we are talking about tonight. He is saying that he will accept parliamentary scrutiny. That is not a proposal which I greatly favour, and I can understand doctors being very concerned about what might happen when they put their future into the hands of a political institution where power swings from one side to the other and where there is a possibility, very faint I hope, that the Senate might come under the control of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you trust yourself?
—I certainly do not trust you in control of the Senate, and the doctors do not trust you either.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for McPherson to ignore the interjections and to direct all his comments through the Chair.

—Right, Mr Deputy Speaker. I ask the Minister why, having gone that far , he will not say: 'I have made that concession. We obviously have a big problem which is affecting the health care of thousands of patients throughout this country. I will put it on the back-burner and we will wait for the outcome of this inquiry and go back to the negotiating table and start again'.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal of the shadow Minister for Health, of course, is to delete section 17. It seems to me to be an eminently sensible proposal, having made the concessions that the Minister has made, to delete section 17 and to go ahead, if he must, with this mad scheme of his so that at least he can get back to negotiating again with the doctors.
The Minister for Health was very keen in various places, particularly in his second reading speech, to quote the Sydney Morning Herald. Other honourable members have also quoted this sentence:
Dr Blewett's power . . . is certainly no more and probably a great deal less than that of any other employer.

In talking about a group of independent doctors, independent businessmen or anyone who is independent and who takes pride in being independent, why would the Sydney Morning Herald or anyone take up a red flag, wave it in their faces and start talking about an employer? If we are talking about arriving at some reasonable conclusion, why talk about being the doctors' employer, because that is the basis of the whole argument? They do not see themselves as employees of the Government and they are not going to be employees of the Government. The relationship is between the patient and the doctor. It seems to me that of all the foolish things that have been quoted, to talk about the Government being the employer of the doctors is the most foolish of all.

That leads to a slightly broader issue, that is, the question of socialised medicine in this country. It is no wonder that there is resistance to socialised medicine. If we look at what has happened in Britain in the last 10 or 15 years we can see the results of it. The big growth industry in Britain now is a return to private enterprise medicine, private hospitals and private practices. That is where it is happening. They have been down this track and it has failed. Why would any sensible people embrace the same dead end road of socialised medicine, of forcing doctors to become public servants, trying to force them into bulk billing and negating any gap insurance and forcing private health funds into sacking thousands of employees if it were not for some great socialist ideology that blinkers them to every other common sense approach?

I fully support the amendment put forward by the shadow Minister for Health. The Minister for Health has made concessions in putting forward a proposal for parliamentary scrutiny. All the other issues aside, including the socialised medicine he seems to be determined on, I ask him to look sensibly at the amendment put forward by the shadow Minister for Health. Let reason prevail. It is a most difficult area, which everyone acknowledges. There are rights and wrongs on both sides. For God's sake, let us get back to some sort of negotiation and accept the amendment that has been put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the Health Insurance Amendment Bill knowing that it deals with a matter which has been given wide coverage in the community. Section 17 of the Medicare legislation has caused agitation among some members of the medical fraternity. I say 'some members of the medical fraternity' because it is patently clear that the majority of doctors have accepted Medicare and are working in the interests of the Australian public. But a small number of bloody-minded doctors have embarked on an industrial campaign which has earned the condemnation of the whole Australian community. These doctors have been encouraged in their futile action by their organisation, the Australian Medical Association. This group originally set out to try to convince the Australian public that this Government was destroying the mythical doctor- patient relationship. This facade was quickly stripped away and the real issue surfaced, the issue of money. These doctors believe that the Government has no right to control the incomes of doctors which are earned in public hospitals. If the doctors were engaged in business like other small business people and were competing in the private area, they might have a legitimate complaint. But they are not competing in that area. The Sydney Morning Herald in its editorial put the position quite clearly when it said:

SPEECH.PARA: If doctors were simply small businessmen earning a living in a free market, any attempt by governments to limit their incomes would be intolerable. But the medical market is far from free. Doctors sell a service which is almost wholly subsidised by the taxpayer and health-fund contributor. Moreover, public hospitals serve as government-financed workshops for doctors with rights to treat private patients.

Doctors have nothing to complain about in terms of governments attempting to control the cost of health care in Australia. They have complained that they are being treated differently and that no other worker in Australia is treated in the same way. They are right. They get away with things that no other worker can get away with.

Let us look at the comparison between how the doctors are treated and how other workers are treated. Workers' incomes and their conditions in Australia are controlled by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The workers place their case, through their union, to the Commission, and the employers, the governments and other interested people have the opportunity to put their case. The Commission considers its position and gives its answer. The workers are expected to accept the umpire's decision. If the workers try to buck the system, penalties are applied. Let us look at how the Australian Medical Association and the doctors are treated. They also have an independent tribunal. Their union, the AMA, puts its case as to the level of the schedule fees, which is what determines doctors' incomes. Other interested groups, such as the Government and various other bodies, put their case. The tribunal considers all of that evidence. It weighs it up and makes a decision. But that is where the similarity ends, because the AMA invariably refuses to accept the umpire's decision. It sets its own levels. It ignores the tribunal's decision. It circularises its members and encourages them to charge more than the schedule fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're fighting for survival; you don't understand it.

—Just to confirm the very fact, the honourable member for Moreton in attempting to justify the doctors' position gave a very good example, where a local doctor in his area is charging $18 when the schedule fee is $12, that is, $6 above the schedule fee. He is charging Australian citizens more than they should be paying. When an independent tribunal has set the fees and recognised what should be charged, the doctors ignore that and set their own levels. There are no penalties applicable in respect of the millions of dollars that the medical profession rips off the community by overcharging above the schedule fee . They have shown themselves to be selfish and greedy by their selfish and greedy attitude to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: These doctors have chosen to oppose Medicare. They have selected various issues . At present they are concentrating on section 17. In other areas where they have raised objections and where the Government has set those aside, they have said: 'That is not enough; we have found another area to which we object'. The AMA would have the public believe that it is only reacting like this because it is the socialist actions of this Government to which it is objecting. Perhaps we should look at the AMA's track record in this area. At the end of the last century, the friendly societies in Australia employed around 40 per cent of doctors. They continued to do so until after the Second World War. As late as the early 1950s, contract practice was still thriving. In July 1950, the Minister for Health, Sir Earl Page-Opposition members should recognise that person-estimated that major friendly societies covered 600,000 families for medical benefits. This figure excluded those in hospital funds. The Federal President of the Friendly Societies of Australia estimated that that meant that about two million individuals were covered by the friendly societies for primary medical care provided by doctors who were being paid a fee. But during 1950 the BMA, that is the British Medical Association which was later to become the AMA, unilaterally terminated those agreements. In 1944 the BMA opposed the introduction of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. That scheme was intended to provide free medicines to Australians. The BMA was successful in 1944. In 1947 a further attempt was made to introduce the scheme. The BMA-or the AMA, as it is now known-opposed it again. Even though the Government had passed the Act, the AMA, as it now is, ensured that its doctors did not allow it to operate properly . In 1947 the BMA again rejected the Government's proposal for a national health scheme, even though the then Government had made many concessions to the BMA in an attempt to introduce the scheme. That sounds pretty similar to what is happening today.

During the 1960s there was great concern among people in the Australian community over the cost of health. At about that time there were two important official inquiries. There was the Nimmo committee, which reported in 1969, and a Senate select committee, which reported in 1970. In March 1970, the Minister of the then Gorton Government announced a scheme which was to link Commonwealth funds and benefits. But the AMA established its own common fee and ignored that. An editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald at that time stated:

The public may be excused for thinking that the Federal Government's medical benefits scheme was aimed at helping them to meet the high cost of sickness. The medical profession clearly sees it in another light. To them it is a doctors' benefit scheme. After a long public debate on the inadequacies of the present health insurance scheme, Mr Gorton's Government was returned to Canberra last year on a promise that the scheme would be vastly improved. The Government has played its part by pouring out an extra $32.5m in subsidies which will find their way to the doctors. The public has played its role uncomplainingly by agreeing to pay higher insurance rates, but the doctors are not prepared to play their part.

It sounds like today. Gorton attacked the AMA. He said that he was appalled at the great increases that it was proposing, and he warned that his Government would fight the AMA with every means at its disposal. He did not believe that any profession should be able to fix its fees at any level which appealed to it when it was supported by public moneys. We all know how the AMA fought alongside the troglodytes of the Opposition benches against the Whitlam Government's Medibank. Is it any wonder that the community no longer holds the medical profession in high esteem when it has such a poor record of concern in the national health treatment area?

Let there be no mistake. This Government was given a mandate to introduce a national health scheme. We are charged with ensuring that the $2,000m which is paid to the medical practitioners is wisely and properly spent. The Parliament has been concerned about overservicing, medifraud and tax evasion. Even today, there is plenty of evidence to show that that is still happening. In one of the hospitals in Victoria we find that a radiologist was paid $155,000 in one year, to June 1983. Over-award payments were made to medical practitioners there. Payments were made out of the trustees' accounts for such things as doctors' wives' accommodation overseas, for Christmas presents and for office parties. Who were the trustees? The doctors themselves were the trustees. Is it any wonder that there is great concern on the part of the Government over the expenditure of moneys in health?

As I have said, this Government has the responsibility of administering the $2, 000m which is being paid to doctors. We shall ensure that it is paid and spent wisely and properly. Doctors cannot expect to be a privileged part of the community. They cannot expect to receive millions of dollars from the taxpayers to use the facilities which are paid for by the taxpayers to be able to rip off and to earn exorbitant sums, without expecting that the Government will place some controls over that income. They cannot have it both ways. They cannot act out of self-interest, to the detriment of their patients, yet retain the high esteem. They cannot expect that the medical mystique can be used as a weapon without being blunted, and when they resort to union tactics of solidarity they cannot complain when doctors, good and bad, are all roped in together.

The amendments that we have put forward in this Bill are yet another concession we have made to the AMA. We have referred most of the doctors' strong objections to the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. This Government has said that it will observe the decisions which are made in relation to those issues but, looking at the track record of the AMA, I expect that it will probably not be prepared to accept the decisions. We have introduced a compromise to section 17 and the doctors have already said that it is not good enough. They do not want any controls at all. They want to continue in the way in which they have been operating, ripping off the public, causing great expense in the health costs of all Australians, and earning exorbitant salaries and wages. This Government will not let them do so. The previous Government and those sitting on the Opposition benches showed that they were incapable of doing that because the doctors were their friends, their supporters , their mates. As has been said, Andrew likes to get some of the money that the doctors have been taking from the public to run his election campaign. As we have said, we will not allow that to happen.

This Government has compromised as far as it is going to do. It is time now that the few intransigent doctors who are out there complaining sat down and decided that in any industrial action there is always compromise, not just from one side but from both sides. This Government has compromised its position. It has put up issues for review, it has agreed to go along with proposals. It has compromised on these amendments and the doctors are still saying that they are not prepared to compromise. I know from the reaction of the Press and the media and from constituents in my area that the Australian community is saying to those doctors: 'We have had enough of you and your attitude. You will now have to compromise and accept that this Government has a mandate which the community gave it and which it is implementing. You will have to co-operate with it in allowing this system to work'. As I said, right through the history of Australia the doctors have shown that they will work only in areas in which they receive extremely good benefits. That has come to an end. They will work in this system because this system will benefit the Australian community, not the doctors.

All I can say is that we oppose the amendments put forward by the Opposition. All the amendments do is kow tow again to the Opposition's supporters, showing that honourable members opposite have not the strength of conviction to defend their position. They have aligned themselves with a group of people who are castigated right across the community and they deserve, along with those doctors , to be criticised by the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Health Insurance Amendment Bill tonight because the Government has simply failed to live up to one of the most fundamental precepts on which it was elected to office by the Australian people last March. We were told during the election campaign that honourable members opposite wanted the Australian people to have a government of consensus, a government which would bring all Australians together. We are seeing at this time a classic example of the basic failure of a philosophical principle which was perhaps presented in good faith but which is now being seen by the Australian medical profession for what it is. It is no consensus; it is nothing more or less than a direct attempt to change the fundamental base of the medical profession in Australia to suit the doctrinal views of the Minister for Health ( Dr Blewett), who is at the table, and the left wing of the Australian Labor Party which is so well represented in this House tonight. That is the situation we are facing.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has already pointed out the facts very aptly and has proposed to the House appropriate amendments to this Bill to allow us once and for all to get back to a sound system of relationships between, on the one hand, doctors and their patients; and, on the other hand, doctors, the rest of the medical profession, the hospitals in which they provide their services and, above all, the Government. But it is a sad fact that the amendments which have been suggested do not go down that road at all. They have been demonstrated to be unacceptable to the left wing of the Labor Party, which prefers to take the view that all doctors should be employed by the state, and they have proved, for good reason, to be unacceptable to a large number in the medical profession.

Let us look at the realities of the situation. A few months ago the Minister told us in this House that the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals had been established to try to overcome this problem. We know that this inquiry will report back to the Government in July. Any government with any sanity, and any Minister with the very semblance of good will towards the people within the area over which he had ministerial responsibility, would surely now put aside section 17 and wait for the report. If the Minister does not do that, one of two solutions can be chosen: Firstly, he is assuming that the report will underwrite everything he has said in this House today and everything that was said by the Government a few months back. Alternatively the Penington report, with the support of the medical profession, will come up with reasonable alternatives to this very pressing and vexatious problem. But, 'Oh no, we can't go down that road' says the Minister, because he wants to be seen in public to be a little Napoleon. All I can say is that he has found his Waterloo. He has found in the medical profession one of the most independent groups in the Australian community, a group of medical people who have given to this country, as my honourable colleague said earlier, one of the highest standards of medical health of any similar country in the Western world.

Today we are asked to force those people who have given their services so well in the past to have their future effectively dictated to by a Federal government . I think it is not unreasonable to ask the following simple question: If any honourable members opposite were doctors of good will and good repute- regrettably, some of them lack the latter-what would they do if they found themselves in a situation in which they could well say: 'Why should we trust? What have this Government and this Minister done in the last 12 months in which they have been in office to give the medical profession reason to trust that if we put our futures in their hands we will not be let down?'

The simple reality of the situation is that doctors and the medical profession as a whole have every reason to distrust this Government and, in particular, this Minister. On many occasions in the past-in speeches to the Doctors Reform Society, in the odd slippage of the tongue in this House and elsewhere-he has made it quite clear that his fundamental objective is slowly but surely to change the very base of the medical profession's relationship with its patients and that profession's capacity to act independently in Australia. He wants nothing less than an extension in this country of the very worst aspects of the British national health system.

Any honourable member who has been to the United Kingdom and seen the problems and the lowering of medical standards that have been brought on that country by the decisions taken 20-odd years ago, and the attempts that have been made over the decades to try to turn back that well worn clock, would appreciate the fact that this Parliament and all its members have a bounden responsibility to think twice before taking this country down a course of action over which we will probably ultimately lose all control and which will certainly, as my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar has so well pointed out, guarantee the Australian people a lowering of their health standards.

The point has been made that we are condoning strikes. I emphasise this point: The Opposition does not condone strikes. But this Government and this Minister have done their best, at least over the last two months and even before that, to attack the integrity of the medical profession. This Government sought conflict; it did not seek co-operation or consensus. The Minister came into this House some months ago with his Medicare legislation. The honourable member for Mackellar and I, and many others, spoke on numerous occasions on amendments to that legislation pointing out to this House and to the honourable members in it on that night that what has now taken place is exactly what we believed would happen.

The Government on that occasion, without getting the support of the Australian Medical Association, without discussing the matter with the medical profession, simply had the arrogance of its position to assume that, because it was the Federal Government of the day, it could ride roughshod over the interests, the integrity, the expectations and the future of a significant number of people in this country who also have rights. Yet the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Health, who is seated at the table, have told us on numerous occasions that what we effectively are seeing is nothing more than an extension by members of the medical profession of their intention to apply the same nonsense we have seen by the Builders Labourers Federation. I remind honourable members that the BLF set out to break the accord. The AMA has not set out to break the accord. All that the AMA has set out to do is assert its right to expect the Government to enter into sensible negotiations with it. So many honourable members opposite simply adore the trade unions of the far Left and their presence in this chamber relates entirely to the support of those trade unions. The Government tries to relate the AMA to the BLF and then it wonders why doctors in this country rise up in fury at the suggestion that there is any relationship at all. This simply demonstrates yet again-I say this to the Minister-the perfidy of his position and the two-faced attitude being adopted by this Government. If this Government wants to be a government of concern and a government of consensus it has to talk to everybody; not just to those who vote Labor; not just to those who fit this Government's own little socialist compact; but to all sections of the community. That is the essence of what consensus is all about.

We were told by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Saunderson) about how terrible it was that a doctor-a radiologist in Victoria-had earned a substantial sum. I suggest to honourable members opposite that if there is a problem-I am not prepared to state in this House that all contracts which have been entered into between doctors and their respective hospitals are necessarily perfect or that they are necessarily always in the national interest or even in the interest of the particular hospital-surely we can ask: What has the Victorian Labor Government been doing about it? What has the Victorian Labor Minister of Health, Mr Roper, been doing about it? That Government has the power and the authority given to it by this Party when we were in government to be in a position to negotiate with doctors, collectively as well as individually, to assert the standards of the contracts which should be applied in State hospitals throughout Victoria. That situation applies in every State of the Commonwealth. If there have been problems in these contracts-the Minister has not demonstrated in this House a clear case that that has been the position; he has simply asserted what a terrible thing it is that some doctors earn more than other doctors-I simply remind him that when he was talking about specialist professions in particular, when he was talking about people such as surgeons, he is assuming that he is dealing with someone who may be able to practice his profession for 30 or 40 or so years. The simple fact of the matter is that many surgeons lose their capacity to act as surgeons. When that happens their income has effectively stopped.
