If this Government is going to try to apply a standard which draws no distinction between a doctor who graduated this year and a man who has been a top surgeon in Australia for, say, the last 15 years or 20 years, if the Government is not prepared to accept that most patients like to get the best doctor available and they are not necessarily all that interested in getting some nationalised doctor services because that happens to be the doctor on register on the day, all I can say to honourable members opposite is: 'God help you if you get sick in a car accident in January next year'.

There is a distinction in terms of the equality of service based on the experience which a doctor may have. If the doctor gets a substantial income, as was suggested by the honourable member for Deakin, it just might be because-I give the honourable member opposite the credit of that-more people want to use his services than somebody else's. But of course in this socialist society of mediocrity which honourable members opposite so strongly support in the left wing of the Australian Labor Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you stop insulting the medical profession?

—The honourable member should keep quiet, she does not know what she is talking about. The simple fact of the matter is that this Government wants to bring down the standards of the medical profession and it wants to bring down the standards of medical attention to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the situation stands clearly demonstrated tonight. We have also been told by the Minister that he has some fear that these doctors will not maintain the average fee charged under the medical benefits schedule. I wish to quote some figures. I doubt that these figures are incorrect as they happen to be from the AMA. The Minister may well have his own set of figures. It is all right; if the Minister has a different set of figures I would welcome his introducing them into this debate. To date the Minister has failed to do so. These figures represent basic total health care costs up to 1980. They demonstrate that in the two major areas which are the subject of this amendment- pathology and radiology-95.57 per cent of pathologists were applying fees charged as a percentage of the schedule level. In other words, they were effectively below the top of the schedule level.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is for 1980?

—These are the figures for 1980. But the comment has been made that there is no evidence. As I said earlier, if the Minister has evidence to demonstrate this, let him bring it into this chamber. I am unaware of it and I do not think he has the information either.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the other question of radiologists, in the same period, 1980-as I have said before there is no evidence that this has changed to date-98.88 per cent of the fees charged by radiologists in public hospitals across Australia were within the respective dimensions which the Minister believes should be the basis of this whole argument. I simply suggest to him: Assuming that those figures are correct-I have no reason to doubt that they are-are we not going down a tremendously long and very difficult route to try to make the entire profession fit into the strictures of this new governmental control because it is feared that some doctors may not be, as the Minister would put it, earning the sort of income that he regards as appropriate or precisely appropriate in terms of the left wing of the Labor Party? We are talking about less than 2 per cent of pathologists and less than 5 per cent of radiologists.

The Minister told us in his second reading speech that the whole essence of section 17 was that he had to use it as a means of controlling the system; a system which he apparently believes does not get adequate control from State authorities. Tonight I clearly have been prepared to concede that some hospitals may not have had programs and contracts which were necessarily always in the national interest. But having said that, the Minister has not been able to demonstrate in this debate that we have to find a solution to the problem by going down such an absolutely draconian road. He has merely suggested that what we have seen from the AMA is what we see too often in Australia, an example of industrial power being applied, and that there is also a public opinion to be applied.

I would venture to suggest that when the Australian people understand the basis of the AMA's complaint, when the people appreciate the realities of the situation in which the doctors of this country are slowly but inexorably going to be forced into ultimately a nationalised health system, where rights of the individual to have any control over his relationship with his doctor either directly or through a hospital are going to be at risk, then I assure honourable members of one thing: There will be a very definite public opinion and it will not be in favour of the Government or of this program which the Government is trying to force upon us at this time.

Let us get down to some of the basics of the matter. The Government says it was elected with a platform to reintroduce an extended system of what was then called Medibank and what the Government has now called Medicare. The Government told the Australian people: 'Don't fear, it is not going to cost you any more than the present system of assistance plus insurance'. What did the Government do? The first thing it did was nationalise 80 per cent of the insurance industry insofar as medical insurance is concerned; it forced thousands of people out of their jobs, and it is a government that is so concerned about unemployment! We know all about that. This is a demonstration of the Government's concern. In addition, the Government has now gone to the other extreme of trying to force a change in the relationship between doctors and their patients and trying to force a significant level of doctors into a nationalised system by virtue of the fact that they have no control over the terms of their contracts. Section 17 in its original form said exactly that, that we, the Federal Government of the day, we, the Hawke Labor Government of the day, will determine whether in fact a contract is to be struck.

There is not one industrial organisation in this country, not even the same industrial organisation which I said earlier so many honourable members are beholden to, which would be prepared to give to this Parliament the power to determine whether or not their contracts and relationships were acceptable. But in this amendment tonight that is exactly what the Government is asking the AMA and the doctors of Australia to accept. The simple reality is that this is a party House. The Senate is a party House and honourable members opposite do not know and we do not know what the determination, the makeup of the Senate will be after the next Federal election. So why should the doctors be prepared to commit themselves on the basis of a major risk that in fact the Parliament, either today or at some future date will in fact be able to apply an independent determination as to whether those contracts are effectively or should be effectively applied. They know that this is a party House and they know that while the socialist Labor Party controls this chamber and while the Government is in a position to get its legislation through the Senate there is no way they have any basis of trust in this Government which already in 12 months has done so much to destroy in the minds of the medical profession the belief that some of them may once have had that the Government was serious when it said to the Australian people that it would govern on the basis of consensus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Medicare legislation and the Health Insurance Amendment Bill are the culmination of many years of work within and outside the Australian Labor Party. Developed from the experience of many experts in government in the Public Service, in medical practice and in education and health institutions we have a scheme administered without fault by the present Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). The developers of the scheme looked at the experiences under health schemes in other countries. Major contributors to the development of health policies have included medical practitioners on this side of the House. They are: Dr Klugman, the honourable member for Prospect, former shadow Minister for Health and a former medical practitioner; Dr Doug Everingham , the honourable member for Capricornia, a former Minister for Health, a former medical practitioner and a great pioneer in Australian health care; and Dr Don Grimes, Senator for Tasmania and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, a former medical practitioner from Launceston, Minister for Social Security and Minister representing the Minister for Health in the Senate. All of these people are medical practitioners who contribute on our side to our health policy.

SPEECH.PARA: There is Dr Rosemary Crowley, a senator from South Australia, a former medical practitioner who chaired the Community Health Sub-Committee of the Government which will lead to a community health program, an essential partner to Medicare; Dr Rick Charlesworth, the honourable member for Perth, a former medical practitioner, an expert on sports medicine and an expert on preventative health through fitness; and Dr Harry Jenkins, the honourable member for Scullin, a former medical practitioner, a former shadow Minister for Health in the Victorian Parliament and now the Speaker of this House. Dr Blewett is the Minister for Health and administers the Medicare scheme and our health policies without fault in this place. We have had the benefit and he has had the benefit of the advice of six medical practitioners.

At the moment the Opposition has one medical practitioner, Dr Peter Baume, now Senator Peter Baume, a distinguished medical practitioner. I was pleased to be told by Senator Baume that in the electorate of Eden-Monaro practising private medicine is one of the great people in the Australian medical profession and one of the most respected former instructors of trainee doctors, Dr Bill Corliss. Dr Bill Corliss and I believe all his colleagues in Sussex Inlet bulk bill for all patients and probably like many doctors he has made arrangements with the local hospitals so that Medicare patients can have their doctor of choice in the local hospitals.

It might well be asked of this Government: Why is the Government interested in containing the costs in hospitals about which we are concerned? Hospitals have become extremely costly institutions. Hospital costs escalated in the late 1960s and early 1970s when justifiable arbitration decisions were made which gave equal pay for women, which gave correct awards for tertiary graduates such as dieticians, physiotherapists and occupational therapists. So hospitals since that time have been undergoing justifiable economic challenges. At the same time in the late 1960s and early 1970s doctors were squeezing all they could out of the public via the health funds. The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Saunderson ) has drawn our attention to that fact. He has quoted the former Prime Minister, Sir John Gorton. Sir John Gorton said that he did not believe that any profession should be able to fix its fees at any level which appeals to it when it is supported by public money. Where are the John Gortons today?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the Liberal Party.

—There are none in the Liberal Party. Where are the people who believe that none of the professions should fix fees at any levels when it is supported by public money? What is so irksome about this attitude of the minority in the medical profession is that their attitude compares so unfavourably with so many of their paramedical colleagues and so many of their own medical colleagues not only in the Doctors Reform Society but also thousands of doctors throughout Australia who do not agree with the policy of the Australian Medical Association . What is so irksome is that their attitude compares so unfavourably with their sister professions such as the optometrists who mostly prefer to bulk bill for everyone and charge the schedule fee. Optometrists ask me and many other Government members to ensure that they be allowed into the Medicare scheme so that they can bulk bill for patients. Chemists have been bulk billing for 35 years and cannot charge more than their schedule fee. Optometrists' schedule fees are fixed by an independent tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: Doctors' fees are also set by an independent tribunal. What more do they want? Chemists' fees are fixed by an independent tribunal, so are the doctors' fees. Yet that is not good enough for a few doctors. Why will doctors not accept arbitration like the rest of us? With infinite patience and good will my friend the Minister for Health has accepted the proposal-it resembled our own proposals -of Senator Haines, the Australian Democrats health spokesman. Senator Haines has challenged doctors by saying: 'What does it mean to you, either principle or money? If it means principle you will vote for this Bill'.

Parliament now has the final say on the guidelines through this Bill. Like Senator Haines, I trust the Parliament. Like her this Government trusts the Parliament. But do those few fleecers of the public purse, that minority of specialists, trust the Parliament? I doubt it. No one likes losing income. The bigger you are the harder it is to take. People earning from $150,000 up to possibly $300,000 a year are less than happy with any loss of income. A glance at the circulars that doctors receive indicates how high incomes can go. The ordinary GP and the specialist with a social conscience must wince at the insurance ads which seek business from doctors for loss of income. The ads in these doctors magazines show tables for doctors seeking insurance for loss of incomes not for tens of thousands of dollars but hundreds of thousands of dollars. These few people not only try to undermine health care in Australia they also seek to undermine the economic accord of the Government.

The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) wants to amend this Bill. What he really wants to do is revert to the system not of hospital and medical benefits for consumers but of a doctors' benefit scheme, just as his Government had-eight of them. This Government is about a fair medical and hospital benefits scheme for all, including the two million people who had no cover at all. We are determined to do that at minimum cost to the Australian taxpayer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe we really should try to get this debate back to what the whole issue is all about. This debate is nothing to do with money.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear the tones of derision from the left corner of the Government benches. The fact of the matter is that this is nothing to do with money. We have heard left wing speaker after left wing speaker on the Government side denigrating the medical profession. They have denigrated the medical profession only in one sense. We have had the medical profession described by speaker after speaker on the Government side as money grubbing and ruthless exploiters of the poor constituents of this country. That has simply nothing to do with the argument. Firstly, it is false and secondly, it has nothing to do with the legislation or with this dispute which is taking place at the present time.

SPEECH.PARA: We just heard the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) give a recitation about the number of medical doctors in his Party and draw from that some sort of conclusion that because there are a large number of medical practitioners in the Government, the Government health scheme is better than anybody else's. Just the other night, I saw the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, in an address to the members of his constituency, stand up in front of the television camera and say that nine out of 10 Australians are better off under Medicare; they pay less for their medical treatment than they had before. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that some time ago. He has now altered his position. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is a trifle more accurate; he says it is something like seven out of ten. But the honourable member for Eden-Monaro has not progressed; he has not looked at the figures. He keeps trying to hoodwink the members of his electorate . He, let it be said, a pharmacist, should know better. He keeps trying to hoodwink the members of his electorate and others who might be listening that nine out of 10 Australians are better off. He knows it is wrong. The Government knows it is wrong, but no, the lie is repeated and repeated. It is repeated just like the lie from member after member of the left wing of the Government in saying that the doctors of Australia are ripping off the public, that they are nothing but greedy extortionists. That is nonsense. Government members know that it is nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right when you say that the doctors are ripping off the public.

—I am very glad to have the honourable member for Kalgoorlie joining in the cacophony of complaints from the Government side about the doctors of Australia. The fact of the matter is that the standard of Australian medical practice is amongst the highest in the world. It is the envy of countries right throughout the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I will return to the matter that I raised to start with. Nothing in this dispute has anything to do with money. The fact of the matter is that the medical specialists who work in public hospitals do not charge more than the schedule fee. The Minister for Health, who is sitting at the table, has been advised by the State Labor Ministers for health in Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales that the vast majority of medical specialists practising in public hospitals do not charge more than the schedule fee. If the Minister disputes that statement let him come out and say so for the first time. I would like to see the figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said medical specialists.

—I said: 'Let me see the figures'. The Minister has not delineated those at this stage. The dispute is about section 17. What does section 17 do? In simple terms it gives the Government and this Minister total power to dictate the working conditions that medical specialists, in particular cases, have to undertake before they are allowed to work in public hospitals. That is what it does. We all know that those left wing members of the Government, if they were speaking for their unions, would not have a bar of any employer putting those sorts of conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us talk a little about employers. The Minister for Health has said that he employs the doctors. Who employs the doctors? The patients employ the doctors. What this Minister is trying to do is to bring government intervention-the bureaucrats-into the special relationship between the patient and his or her doctor. That is what is happening. That is what this section 17 is all about. No trade unionist would have a bar of it. What this Government is trying to do is to introduce through backdoor, cheap, snide methods the first stage of the nationalisation of the medical fraternity in this country. Why does the Government not come out in the open and admit that? No, the Government is going to adopt the Fabian approach and do it gradually.

The Minister himself revealed the entire plan when he was talking to the Doctors Reform Society last year. He said: 'We are going this far to start with; we will move to the other practitioners later on'. That is what is happening. This Government is convinced of and dedicated to the belief that the only way to move in regard to medical practice in this country is to nationalise it. This is the first step along that track. What we have is not a dispute about money; what we have is a situation whereby the Government is seeking to take that first step in the nationalisation of the medical profession. It is unnecessary at this stage. The Minister talks about how conciliatory he has been; how he is inclined to consensus and conciliation. What a load of rubbish. Here we have the first doctors' strike in the history of this country solely as a result of this man's intransigence. Here we have the first doctors' strike in the history of this country and the Minister is trying to say that he is conciliatory.

The Government has set up the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals which is looking at every aspect of these matters. Goodness knows why the Government will not put off any action until the Penington Committee has reported. What could be fairer, what could be more realistic, having set up a committee to look at the problems concerning the dispute? Why pour petrol on the flames by acting in advance of the report of that Committee? What is wrong? Where is the fault in logic, having set up the Committee to look at the causes of the dispute and to suggest possible outcomes and possible solutions, which opposes the proposition that the Government should take no action to exacerbate the problem until the Penington Committee has reported?

The facts of the matter are simply these. The vast majority of medical specialists working in public hospitals do not charge more than the schedule fee but they are very, very suspicious, and with due cause, about the bona fides of this Government. They will refuse to give any government carte blanche over the pay and conditions under which they will work in public hospitals. Government members would do the same if they were in a similar situation. If they were honest with themselves and the people of Australia they would take exactly the same attitude as the doctors. Government members are not courageous enough or honest enough to say that.

If any trade unionist were confronted with a situation such as that proposed by honourable members opposite this Government would defend him to the hilt. But no , they try to portray the medical practitioners of this country as rapacious, as exploiters, as blood suckers. Those are the sorts of terms they use about medical practitioners. They will continue to do that until they become ill. When they become ill suddenly the medical profession and their particular doctor will become an absolute hero. They will listen to that doctor very, very carefully. If that doctor says 'you need such and such a treatment' they will listen to that very carefully because suddenly they will recognise, understand and appreciate the skills, dedication and qualifications that the medical practitioners of Australia bring to the treatment of their patients. To the great credit of the medical practitioners of Australia they will treat Government members. The medical practitioners will provide them with a high quality service despite the things that they have said about them.
I have to say a word of congratulation to the Minister for Health. He is the only Minister for Health in the history of this country who has succeeded in bringing the medical profession together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first one to stand up to them.

—He is not the first one to stand up to them. He has succeeded in bringing them together and what has he also succeeded in doing? He has succeeded in putting at risk high quality medical care for the people of Australia. What the Government is all about, and let there be no mistake about this, is that if it persists with the actions that it has taken it will create second class medicine in Australia. If socialised medicine is such a great thing, let us look at medical practice in those totalitarian authoritarian countries which mean so much to so many members of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. Let us look at medical practice in, say, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Why is it that so many people there seek to upgrade their medical skills not in the USSR but outside the USSR? Why is it that the cutting edge, if I can use that term, of medical technology and medical practice is not under socialised authoritarian regimes or is not under socialised authoritarian medicine? It is in medical practice which recognises the rights of medical practitioners to charge for their services, to upgrade their skills and the rights of medical practitioners to have a relationship with their patients free of intervention by bureaucrats or governments of this nature.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 17 provides that the Minister can do anything to members of the profession in relation to their continued practice in public hospitals with no right of review whatsoever. Where is the fairness in that? I ask Government members who are great humanitarians and great civil rights protectors: Where is the fairness in no right of review? They cannot answer that simple question. The fact is that there is no need at this stage for this provision. If the Minister had any semblance of common sense, if he had any semblance of honesty, he would recognise that the amendment moved by the Opposition provides a very simple commonsense solution to the problem confronting the Government and the medical profession at this stage.

The Government has the Penington Committee. It has a timetable for that Committee to report. That Committee is examining the problems confronting the Government and the medical profession in relation to these matters. What could be more simple, more common sense, than to set aside any action which could be termed as provocative on either side until the Penington Committee has reported? It is a simple, straightforward, commonsense, fair and reasonable attitude to take. But no. We will not have that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut it out.

—'Cut it out', says the honourable member; we cannot do that. That is too simple; that is too straightforward; that is too fair. What we want to do is to continue this confrontation with the medical profession. What we want to do is to allow a situation in which the left wing anti-medical bigots on the Government side can abuse the medical profession. We do not want to clarify the situation. What we want is confrontation not consensus. What we want to do is to bring about a situation which can lead only to continuing uneasiness and continuing distrust not just for the moment but for years ahead between the medical profession as a whole and this socialist Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one more appeal to the Minister. Have a look at the commonsense solution which is being offered by the Opposition in this case. It does not preclude the Government's options in the future. It has set up the Penington Committee; it can put its case to that Committee. The doctors and the medical profession can put their case to the Penington Committee and the Government can look at the Committee's report. Why not set aside confrontationist action before that Penington Committee reports? It is the simple, straightforward, fair and reasonable thing to do but, of course, that is just too straightforward, too fair and too honest. The Government will not do it, but it should.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we have heard a tremendous amount of hot air on what is a very important subject. An important piece of legislation has been brought before this Parliament; it was introduced by this Government. It is interesting that honourable members opposite, for the first time in their lives I would have thought, are supporting an industrial strike, an industrial dispute . We do not usually see this. We usually see the exact opposite. But honourable members opposite, including the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) who has just spoken, probably for the first time in their lives are supporting industrial action. I do not suppose it is surprising that that industrial action is being taken by one of the most privileged sections of the community. This Government has never said, nor has it suggested in any way, that all doctors are rip-off merchants or blood suckers which I think was the phrase the honourable member used. I think it is equally true to say that some doctors do rip off the system.

SPEECH.PARA: I have in front of me a document entitled 'Medicare statement of Benefit' that the honourable member would recognise. That document shows that one of the fees asked for by a doctor of an 84-year-old lady was 41.7 per cent over the schedule fee. The only reason he would have asked for that amount was because the lady lived in a fairly well-to-do suburb. But that is beside the point when a doctor is asking nearly 50 per cent more than the schedule fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was probably trying to redistribute income.

—The worst thing about it, if the honourable member for O'Connor thinks about it, is that one can recognise the point of overcharging the schedule fee if the Commonwealth picked it up. I can understand that. I would not agree with it, but I can understand the mentality of someone saying that the Government will pay for it, anyway. But the doctors know that that does not occur and that it is the patient who picks up the difference. So if the doctor overcharges by $20, it comes directly out of the patient's pocket. The patient pays everything over the schedule fee. The doctors rip off their own patients. One example shown in the document is for 41.7 per cent charged over the schedule fee. I assert tonight that that is not a rare occurrence.
—How do we know it is fair dinkum?

—The honourable member can have a look at it afterwards. We have seen the problems involved in this dispute and it is an industrial dispute-that is all it is-put on by the doctors. It is all about the introduction of Medicare and their rights, or what they see as their rights.
—To king hit it.

—To king hit Medicare, as the honourable member for Stirling says, and to charge what they want. This Government believes that in public hospitals, which are paid for by the taxpayers of this country, there should be a schedule fee to which they should adhere. We always forget one aspect of doctors and how they became doctors. The vast majority-75 per cent of doctors, if we use the ratio of State schools to private schools-would have gone through the education system. They then go to a university that is paid for by the taxpayer. They then go to the public hospitals, where they spend several years. Some spend more than a decade learning various specialty skills or surgery. They spend years and years there under taxpayers' money. Yet they turn around and say: 'We want to charge what we want to charge, even though we have used taxpayers' money to be trained for all these years, and now we are using taxpayers' facilities'. Fair crack of the whip. Doctors cannot have it both ways.

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare, and what the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has said, purely sets forward a health insurance scheme. In the public hospital area we are asking doctors to abide by the schedule fee which is determined in the scheme put forward in the legislation and which is being reviewed by the present Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. When that report comes down, as the Minister said in the House this week, the Government will abide by those decisions. If my memory serves me correctly, he said it in his second reading speech. The doctors will not wear that and, as the Minister interjected during the remarks of the previous speaker, will the Opposition guarantee that the doctors will abide by any decision? They have shown no softening in attitude. They have shown no degree of being able to come to any sort of arrangement whatsoever.

Let us not also forget why Medicare is before us. It is a universal health scheme for the benefit of the vast majority of the Australian people. With regard to the forerunners to the scheme-to my memory there were five Fraser Government schemes and there may have been more-they ran one after the other. Each one was to be the last one. All of them were a disaster. All of them supposedly would save the taxpayer money. All of them supposedly would be easier . All of them cost the taxpayer money and all of them sent the health bill through the roof. The whole health portfolio was in a total shambles when this Government came into office. Medicare is a universal health scheme that will benefit the vast majority of people in Australia.

Let us not also forget the fact that while it benefits people who cannot, or could not, afford health insurance, it also benefits many public hospitals which were virtually going under because of the thousands of dollars in bad debts of people who just could not pay under the old system introduced by the previous Government, of which the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) has been a part over the previous seven years. My time has almost expired. This Government has never attempted to tar all doctors with the same brush. That is not the case . The Minister has never said that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Prime Minister and the BLF statement?

—The Minister has put the Government's case succinctly on a number of occasions. He put it once again in his second reading speech last night. The people of Australia have overwhelmingly voted for Medicare and they will do so again. If there were a referendum on it next week, I know exactly what would happen and who would lose out, and it would not be Medicare, the people of Australia, or this Government. For all those reasons, for all the reasons that the Minister has put forward, the people whom it will benefit most are the vast majority, that is, the middle and lower income earners. For some who cannot afford to take out any private insurance and have not been able to do so for many years this Bill is one of the most important pieces of legislation that this Government will bring forward. That is why this Government is strongly defending it. I appeal to doctors to think again, because this Government is not asking too much of them now or over the coming months. The Penington inquiry still has to bring forward its recommendations. I support the motion for the second reading of the amending legislation moved by the Minister and I hope that everyone in this House will do likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot of talk tonight for and against the rights of doctors but I will commence by talking about the poor old taxpayer . He is the Australian who has been promised all sorts of things by this Government. I have a copy of the Australian Labor Party policy speech which was put to the people prior to the election. I guess it could be argued that that was what they voted for. The speech contains statements such as this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor government will return to the basic principle of the right of all Australians to health services according to their medical needs.

Tonight we heard the speech of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). It is well known to us all that he also has a family interest in a pharmacy. That, of course, is another industry which, as he mentioned, has managed to come to live with being a servant of the Government. Of course, we know how it has come to live with being a servant of the Government. If we go to his shop it takes five minutes to find the dispensary. We have to fight our way through the beach balls, lollies and all the other things that he is obliged to sell to make a living.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor is ranging much further and much wider than any of the previous speakers in the debate. While I and other occupants of the chair have allowed the debate to be far-ranging, I think the honourable member for O'Connor would be helpful to the debate if he got back fairly closely to the question before the Chair.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The issue before the Chair is the nationalisation of health schemes. Pharmacies are very much a matter of health and, as such, I am suggesting, Sir--

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor is attempting to defy the Chair. I have suggested to him that he should refer closely to the matter before the Chair. If he is not prepared to accept the advice of the Chair , he should resume his seat.

—Sir, I will not take the choice of resuming my seat. It is a pity, nevertheless, that that example could not be extended a little further. Maybe it is a pity that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro did not respond to my interjections on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the Australian people are currently having a Claytons of a medical service. They have the Medicare service that you have when you are not having a Medicare service. Approximately $150m has now been collected under the one per cent levy on taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—I would estimate that after two months the figure is $150m. I looked at the Budget figures this morning. Clearly, that is an estimate, but even if it were a little less it is a lot of money. What are the people getting for it? They are getting precious little because this very debate is about the fact that the Government has failed to deliver a service. The service it has failed to deliver is in our public hospitals. That service, the medical service, is deteriorating daily.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a brand new scheme. There was absolutely no need whatsoever to introduce it until matters of this nature were resolved. The scheme was not already in existence. This situation did not blow up in a minute. It was clearly known to the Government. The Government went down the track of taxation before delivery. Why could it not have gone down the other track, given the taxpayer a go and let the taxpayer pay his money when it was confident that it could deliver the service? That is a reasonable proposition. I think that those people who voted to support this service as put up in the policy of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) expected that the Government would deliver the goods prior to taxation. That is a reasonable proposition. If the Minister wants to get to his feet after me and say that it is not a proposition and that the Government has the right to start taxing people before it can deliver let him do so. I put it to him again: There was no problem in the Government's being able to negotiate these arrangements prior to introducing the levy on taxation. Whatever time it took that would have been a fair and reasonable deal for the taxpayer.

Let me touch on another matter. When the section 17 issue is resolved it will not be resolved in my electorate. My electorate contains dozens of very small, decentralised government hospitals under the Western Australian public hospitals arrangement. They are excellent little hospitals. They are not viable in terms of staffing by public doctors. The only way that they can be retained and be of great convenience to people is to be serviced by private doctors. When this row is over my people-the people who are paying these taxes-will still be private patients and will have to carry private medical cover.

That was as clear as the nose on everyone's face to the Minister prior to his introducing this wonderful scheme yet he did nothing to resolve it. In fact, he allowed a situation to remain whereby there is no requirement for bulk billing. I am pleased about that, but while that situation remains and there is no forced bulk billing clearly the doctors in my electorate will opt to treat their patients as private patients. In terms of the local public hospital system those people must maintain their private health cover after having paid the levy. Let us remember that these people, whether they are government employees or not--

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose fault is that?

—It is clearly the fault of the Government for not resolving the problem. If the Government cannot fix the problem, it should just take the taxes off. That is all I am asking the Government to do. It should not tax without being able to deliver the service. I am not arguing for the doctors.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us also remember that the people who find themselves in this situation, many of whom are employees of the Government, have also had government calculated cost of living allowances added to their salaries. There is no profit in that. That is just a calculation made.

Recently I talked to a postmaster in the north-west who gets over $2,000 to compensate him each year for the high cost of living and the other difficulties he faces in that area. There is no profit to him in that but he has now lost one per cent of that allowance because the Medicare levy takes one per cent of that allowance which is granted for other purposes. But that was not the case when he paid for his private health insurance. That was universal across the State. He received it at the same price as did people living in the middle of the metropolitan area. So now he has to continue to pay a level of private health cover. He has to pay one per cent on a cost of living allowance carefully calculated only to compensate him for the costs of living in that area and all because the Government was so anxious to bring this scheme into force without having the responsibility and the decency to measure the cost to certain people and correct those matters first.

I object strongly on behalf of my constituents. I have a funny feeling that on the other side of this House are honourable members who have constituents with exactly the same problems. But they will subvert them to the rule of the Australian Labor Party which is: 'One in, all in'. As I mentioned to another member the other night, they are not prepared to face up to the problems of their individual electorates. They would much rather have the collectivist arrangement which operates in their own Caucus whenever they can find it and it is just too bad. I am happy to speak on behalf of the constituents of these honourable members. I am prepared to say that there are grave problems throughout Australia for certain individuals in regard to this program. The blame for all of them rests with the Government because it failed to resolve the problems before it introduced the tax.
As I have a couple of minutes left I will address myself very briefly--

TALK.START.PARA: —To the Bill?

—This is all about the Bill. I have complained about these problems because that is what they are. They have been talked about and I am now responding to statements which have been made. I presume that the honourable members who made those statements were talking about the Bill because nobody questioned them. I draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that constantly the gross remuneration of certain doctors is thrown up in this place. The doctor who is in the room at the moment would be able to tell us that that is not the situation. Gross figures highly distort the truth. The fact is that doctors employ people. Those who have the greatest salaries employ the most people. I am not saying this for any other purpose than to make it quite clear to honourable members that that fact must be recognised. If we ask a doctor to take any cut in his gross remuneration he is not able to go to his receptionist or his nurse and say: 'We have just gone on to bulk billing, love. You used to get $250 a week. You will now get $220'. We know that is not the way it works. The only person in the system who can take the cut, of course, is the doctor.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we heard reference to the income insurance schemes of doctors. When a doctor who is the sole source of income in a practice goes out of production he still has the responsibility-I think that honourable members would agree with me -to create employment for those who support him. Clearly, when he insures his income he insures his gross income for the purpose of being able to continue to pay rent and wages. That is misleading too. I say that to the honourable member for Eden-Monaro because normally he is a person for whom we can have the highest regard when it comes to telling the truth and explaining things as they are. He should rethink his statement in that regard. It is clear that if we are to talk about remuneration to doctors we should be fair enough to explain what they keep . I am not suggesting for a moment that it is not necessarily a substantial amount of money. But it is not in the figures which have been bandied around here tonight. We should at least be as honest as that.

I have just about run out of time in considering a couple of matters. But let me get down to the final word. The final word is this: There is a lot of talk in Australia about what is now the political position of people and, in particular, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We talk about the right, the left, the centre and all those terms. If anybody wants to know where the Prime Minister stands in the political spectrum, let us remember that within the first 12 months of his Government-the Bill we are talking about now is an example of this-he has set out to nationalise medicine. If that is not socialism, I will go he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-First of all, I thank honourable members on the government benches for their eloquent defence of the measure. I am afraid that I cannot say the same about honourable members on the opposition benches. I will deal with them in two ways. First of all, I will deal with most of the back bench speakers before addressing the remarks of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I do so because nearly everything said by the back benchers had nothing to do with the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1984 whatsoever, so it can be dealt with very quickly. However one theme ran through three of the speeches. Let me note that the only relevant remark about the Bill made by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) was that doctors made a fortune out of Medibank. I do not know whether that is true, but the whole intention of section 17 is to make sure that doctors do not make a fortune out of Medicare. That was a very relevant remark. There were problems about Medibank and cost control. This is one of the cost control elements of Medicare. Of course, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) said that this issue has nothing to do with money. I shall prove in a moment that it has nothing to do with anything else but money. That is the only issue left. It is not even money now; it is a concern about money in the future. That is the kind of fear that has been spread through the profession. But it is about money, and we will come back to look at that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take up a point made by our friend the honourable member for O'Connor ( Mr Tuckey) about money. He attempted to suggest that the figures we were using were gross figures. Let me give a few net figures. In 1982-83, seven radiologists took out of the Victorian public hospital system a little over $1m net; that is, after all their costs had been paid, all their equipment paid for and all their salaries paid. That did not allow for what they made in their private practices or for any work in private hospitals. There may not have been very much of that, I am prepared to agree, but they took $1m net earnings out of the public hospital system. The $155,000 mentioned this morning in the case of the radiologist in Victoria was a net earning. That is what he took out of the public hospital system after facilities had been paid for and other costs had been paid. Let us not blind ourselves to the fact that this is about money; and increasingly, after all the actions that the Government has taken, it is about practically nothing else but money.

Now let me look at a couple of other specific remarks made by some of the back bench speakers. First of all, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) quoted one of the recommendations of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, saying that this issue should be left to independent authorities; that is, the hospitals and the doctors. He ignored every other recommendation from the Jamison Committee, which was all about the problems of private practice. Let me answer him on just the point he made. This Government is having a tough enough job insisting that doctors observe the schedule fee in public hopsitals. The honourable member for McPherson said: 'The hospital can do it'. This is the whole point of this operation. Both the hospitals and the State governments find it extremely difficult to make reasonable demands on the medical profession. It is utterly absurd to think that a public hospital can stand up against the weight of this profession on these issues when, as I say, the Commonwealth Government is having a big enough battle to insist on reasonable constraints on private practice behaviour in public hospitals. That is quite clearly the answer to that issue.

Let me now look at our friend the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) . There is nothing much to be said about his speech, although I will have another point to make about it in a moment. It was mostly rhetoric. He accused us of breaking the accord by doing what we are doing. There is no hope of the accord working in this country unless all ordinary workers in this country believe that every section of the population is being treated fairly. Unless we can convince people of the fact that all groups of the population, particularly those with the broadest shoulders, the biggest incomes, are also being treated fairly there is no hope of the accord holding. The experience of every overseas country shows that unless we can assure the population that all are being fairly treated the accord cannot work. That is one of the reasons why we are determined to insist on these reasonable contraints on private practice in public hospitals , or else we will never convince the ordinary workers, the people on $10,000 to $20,000 a year, that these people-and none of them are touched before they get to $62,500 a year-are being fairly treated. Unless we can convince people that we are being fair there is no chance that the one hope of economic recovery in this country-that is, the maintenance of the accord-will work. To accuse us of breaking the accord when we are trying to do this seems to me absurd. We are in fact trying to do the opposite.

Finally, the honourable member for Warringah, who is not with us, again in a very eloquent speech, asked: 'Why do you not be reasonable? Why do you not put off what is now the only guideline, this insistence that radiologists and pathologists charge the schedule fee, until after Penington reports?'. I am perfectly prepared to put that guideline off if from the Australian Medical Association we can get an agreement that it will accept the recommendations of that Committee. If the AMA is prepared to say, as the Government would be prepared to say, that it will accept the recommendations of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals, of course we would be prepared to make that compromise. But to make it without that kind of assurance is just to say that we will have another battle in six months time; that is, instead of fighting it out now we will have it again in six months time and prolong it. I am perfectly prepared to make that pledge that if the AMA is prepared to accept the recommendations of the Penington Committee the Government is prepared to accept them and we would put off this proposal.

Let me finally turn to the gravamen, the chief source of the argument, the only source of the argument, that came from the Opposition side. First of all, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has moved an amendment. The amendment is the ambit claim of the AMA. What the honourable member for Mackellar has said in this amendment is the extreme demand of the AMA, what it is demanding after all its other objections have been satisfied and after every other point it made was satisfied. We now have the Liberal Opposition presenting in this House the ambit claim of the AMA. I am perfectly happy to see the honourable member for Mackellar as a stooge of the AMA. I am disappointed that that should occur, but I am perfectly happy to see the Opposition sink along with the AMA in the suicidal folly on which it has now embarked.

Let me take the specific points made by the honourable member for Mackellar. First of all, he said that our proposals in section 17 are somehow contrary to or getting round the Constitution; that is, the section 51(xxiiiA) placitum on civil conscription. We believe we are perfectly within the Constitution in what we have done. If the AMA does not believe that, it has an appropriate course of proper and legitimate action; that is, to take the Government to the High Court of Australia and challenge that. That would be a preferable and responsible piece of behaviour rather than this industrial militancy it has planned. If the AMA believes, with the honourable member for Mackellar, that there is an argument that this is outside the Constitution-we do not believe it is-the AMA is perfectly entitled legitimately, to take that appeal to the High Court. It is one of the rights it has in this society and it is wealthy enough to do so. That would be a proper way of dealing with this issue.

Let me turn to the point made that section 17 is somehow a first step towards nationalisation. First of all, that is rubbish. But in fact we get a lot of support for that rubbish from honourable members who have spoken tonight. Let me just quote from a very interesting document on contractual arrangements. I quote from the 203rd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts:

Another approach would be to permit medical practitioners to participate in the Medical Benefits Scheme and to have their fees subsidised both by Government and fund contributions only if they were registered medical practitioners for the purposes of the Health Insurance Act. Practitioners could apply for registration under the Act, which could be granted subject to conditions . . . . If eligibility-
that is, eligibility for payments-
depended upon registration as a participating practitioner, more effective administrative control may be able to be exercised without resort to the criminal law.
This could take the form of a contractual relationship between the Commonwealth and individual doctors-
rather than the present arrangement which is based on the relationship between patient and doctor. To continue:

In legal terms, this approach would have the advantage that breach of contract is much easier to prove than fraud, and would emphasise that the medical benefits arrangements impose certain obligations on doctors to abide by the rules.

In many ways, the proposals made there, by a committee of which the honourable member for Bradfield was the chairman, are much more wide-ranging-as he said, they affect all medical practitioners-than anything presented in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute nonsense. You are talking about a different matter. Fraudulent. What you have put up is nonsense.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Burke will cease trying to assist the Minister.
—We have not yet finished the kinds of double statements that are made here. I quote now from another report of the Public Accounts Committee, the 212th report. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes that the Government's Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1983 provides that Medicare benefits are not payable in respect of prescribed professional services rendered to patients of, or at, recognised State and Territory hospitals unless the doctors have made an agreement (in a form approved by the Commonwealth Minister for Health) with the recognised hospital and unless the doctors were acting in accordance with the approved agreement. In addition, any benefits incorrectly paid will be recoverable . . .
This type of contractual arrangement was one of the possible legislative reforms discussed by the Committee in Chapter 8 of the Progress Report-
that is the report to which I have already referred-
The Committee believes this type of contractual arrangement, and its extension to other areas of medical practice, may greatly assist prosecutions for medical fraud.

Not only was the Committee approving of it in relation to public hospitals; it wanted it extended. When I read the names of the signatories to that report, I find the name of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). Does he read the reports to which he puts his name, or was what he has said in the House tonight an absolute contradiction of the support that he gave here for the types of proposals? No doubt Opposition members can clarify the position for me. But I make both those points-the point from the honourable member for Bradfield and the point from the honourable member for McPherson-to say that to see these kinds of arrangements as nationalisation is absolutely absurd. I do not believe that when the honourable member for Bradfield was making these proposals he was making proposals about nationalisation. I do not believe that the honourable member for McPherson, when he signed his name to that report, was making proposals for nationalisation. There is no intention--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your proposals are different.

—My proposals are not different. I may just say to the honourable member for Mackellar that the honourable member for McPherson was referring directly to section 17 of the legislation. There is no intention of nationalising in these proposals, just as, as I say, there was no intention of nationalising, I believe-the honourable member for Bradfield may explain otherwise-in the proposals of the honourable member for Bradfield or in the proposals of the honourable member for McPherson. What we were doing, as they were doing, was simply saying that private practice rights in public hospitals must meet certain guidelines in the interests of the community. Indeed, we are concerned with preserving private fee-for-service practice. We are not removing that from the hospitals in any of these guidelines, but we are saying that if doctors are to have these private fee-for-service rights in public hospitals they must observe certain conditions and certain responsibilities towards the taxpayers who fund the hospitals, the equipment and the staff.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is nothing in those guidelines which is aimed at nationalisation of the medical profession. Indeed, the guidelines were brought in because we wanted to protect, in the long run, private practice rights-unlike the Medibank arrangement where both with pathology and radiology the specialists simply became public services in public hospitals. We rejected that proposal and we said that they would remain private services; that there could be private practice rights in them but that they would have to observe certain conditions in the public interest.

I did not recognise the caricature presented by the honourable member for Mackellar of my colleagues Mr Roper, Dr Cornwall and Mr Mulock. I just want to say that they have supported these proposals throughout; at least Dr Cornwall and Mr Roper helped to create them and supported them because they realised the need for the Commonwealth's support, with its insurance power, to help solve some of the problems in the area.

Before I come to the final point in the argument, let me say that I thought that the honourable member for Mackellar, who is constantly condemning me and honourable members on this side of the House for our attacks on doctors, was himself guilty of a most gross attack on all salaried doctors in Australia. The implication of his remarks-the notion that if doctors are in some way constrained or controlled it leads to mediocrity-is a reflection on all salaried doctors. The honourable member is saying that if people accept salaries instead of these private fee-for-service arrangements--

TALK.START.PARA: —There must be a choice one way or the other.

—And we allow that choice. But the honourable member is saying that somehow or other this is a mediocre service. So I think that one should be very careful in these general reflections on members of the medical profession, as made by the honourable member.
—That is a total misrepresentation of my position.

—It is a reflection on them to talk about mediocrity if we have salaried type services. Finally, let me just look at what on earth doctors are striking about. There is only one guideline in place, and that is the guideline that radiologists and pathologists should not charge more for their services than the schedule fee, a fee set by arbitration and not by the Government. That is the only guideline that we are asking these medical practitioners to observe. All the other constraints have been put aside by the Government, in an effort to negotiate, and they have been referred to the Penington Committee. So that issue is removed from any decision until Penington reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there is the question that we might change the guidelines before Penington reports. We have given a guarantee that there will be no change in the guidelines until Penington reports. Of course, there is a further guarantee of that now because this Bill makes provision so that both Houses of Parliament are able to review any guidelines and reject them. This Government does not have a majority in the upper House and therefore it would have to convince the members of the upper House of the reasonableness of any proposal before that could go through. That kind of fettered power is removed entirely, so the doctors do not have that claim to make. Again, we are not requiring doctors in nearly all of the States to sign any documents or letters, which was another of their worries. We have taken other methods through this measure to ensure that that requirement will not be imposed on them. Again, some of the doctors have now said: 'If you impose the schedule fee, you might not change it for five years; you might have no arbitration for five years and that will affect our income'. We have made the guarantee to deal with that fear. In principle, the Government accepts that there will be regular schedule fee arbitrated reviews, and those regular reviews of the arbitrated fee we guarantee. So that problem, that fear, is removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not addressed the scope of section 17.

—Finally, let me deal with the two points which the honourable member has just raised, including the scope. Of course, the scope is general; but it cannot be changed without the approval of both Houses of Parliament. As we have also pointed out, none of it will be effected until Penington has reported, because Penington has been asked to look at all these issues. The Government has said that any arbitration proposal, any appeals proposal and any consultation proposal recommended by Penington will be accepted in advance by this Government . After all that has been done, I believe that there is not a single excuse for the kind of industrial action that threatens the people of this country.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.
