DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mount Barker and Katanning, Western Australia-Nuclear Power Reactor Accident- Domestic Air Fares-Mr Charles Perkins-Asian Immigration-Sydney Airport

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week I have as my guests in Canberra two high school students from my electorate of O'Connor. They are Evan Porter, who is aged 16 years, who comes from a small town called Narrikup and who is a student at the Mount Barker Senior High School; and Jenny Crauch, who is aged 17 years, who comes from Borden and who is a student at the Katanning Senior High School. At times Jenny is also a resident at St Andrews Hostel in Katanning. These young people are in the House tonight. They have been my guests at Parliament House all week. They are having a view of how we, the leaders of their society, conduct the affairs of the nation. I am sure that they have been quite interested. Nevertheless, they are here with me and I am sure that all honourable members would welcome them to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.
—This is the speech you gave last year.

—Last year I had two different people. This is not the same speech. The speech is prepared by the young people themselves. Narrikup is a small siding centre. Mount Barker is a regional centre, the centre for the Plantagenet Shire and a very large service centre to the Great Southern. Mount Barker is very close to the residence of another well known member of Parliament, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond). Existing industry in the Mount Barker area includes wine production. I am pleased that Plantagenet wines are available in the parliamentary dining rooms. Many years ago Mount Barker was a major centre for the apple industry. It is pleasing to note that as that demand reduced, the wine industry was there to create employment and keep the region prosperous. Nevertheless, the region is principally one of mixed farming. It has a great tourist potential because two of the higher mountain ranges of Western Australia, the Porongurups and the Stirlings, are within the Plantagenet Shire. Many Western Australians enjoy the opportunity to go through those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The Principal of Mount Barker High School is Mr Stevens. That school has about 350 students and is one of the few high schools that have an agricultural wing attached. As I have said, Jenny Crauch comes from Katanning High School which is a larger high school, with approximately 600 students. The Principal at that school is Mr Johnston. Being a larger high school it has an associated government school hostel, St Andrews. About 110 pupils reside there during the school year. It is interesting that Jenny has brought to our attention the fact that the name Katanning is derived from the Aboriginal word 'Kartinup', meaning a meeting place. Although many of the old people used to say that, as the railway line runs right down the main street, the word 'Katanning' came from the noise of the trains. But it is really derived from an Aboriginal word.

Katanning is about 300 kilometres from Perth and has a shire population of about 5,000 people. It was originally established by Frederick Henry Piesse. Katanning is an interesting place. It has always had a progressive attitude. It was the first country town in Western Australia to have electric light, because of the efforts of Mr Piesse. The town relies heavily on an abattoir industry. It is interesting to note that 300 Malays from the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island are living in the town. They have integrated perfectly in that town. In 1981 I had the privilege of being present when Tunku Abdul Rahman opened a mosque in Katanning. It is a wonderful example of integration in our community, one of which all Australians can be proud, most particularly the residents of Katanning.

I thank these young people for showing the interest to come to Canberra to see how things go on. I will bring other children. I hope at that time, Mr Speaker, I have your indulgence and that of the House to bring to your attention the presence of these young people and to present the speeches that they write.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is five years since the accident at the nuclear power reactor at Three Mile Island. As a matter of fact yesterday, 28 March 1984 , was the anniversary of that accident five years ago. Everyone remembers the shock of that accident and the fact that it could happen; that the technology of nuclear reactors was not foolproof. Everyone remembers the fears for the local residents and then the months of new revelations as management was forced to admit more and more details of the accident. Before Three Mile Island there were hypothetical calculations of what happens to a superhot uranium fuel core when it loses cooling water. That was what occurred early on 28 March 1979 when a series of mechanical and human errors caused steam to escape through a pressure relief valve, draining coolant and causing temperatures in the core to soar to 4 .5 times above normal.

SPEECH.PARA: At first it was thought that the plant was not severely damaged and would be back in operation within a couple of weeks. In reality, the damage was enormous. It took 15 months before two engineers entered the containment building for the first time. In the months and years after that there came more problems, more doubts about the ability to solve the problems, fewer reassurances for the community and fewer solutions to the problems.

What I want to talk about and emphasise tonight is the unimagined and still unresolved financial problems associated with that nuclear disaster. In dollars, it has actually cost seven times more to deal with the aftermath than it did to build the unit 2 reactor which went into commercial service just three months before the accident. I want to talk about the enormity of the cost, as it was a pretty enormous cost. Who pays for it? That is one of the unsolved problems. Do the insurers pay? Does the company pay? Do the electricity consumers pay? Does the Government pay?

Utilities and the nuclear industry are widely split on who should pay for the Three Mile Island clean-up. The owner of the damaged nuclear plant, General Public Utilities Corporation, says that the problem is a national one. It hired a former member of Congress to try to work out a solution. One proposal would, in effect, force electric utility customers in the United States of America to pay the multimillion dollar cost of cleaning up after the Three Mile Island accident. However, some people think that the federal Government should pay for the clean-up. Adding to the pressures in 1981 for quick action was the possibility that the GPU could go bankrupt and there would be an exhaustion of the insurance money to clean up the radioactive mess that remained at Three Mile Island. Some experts insist that the longer the clean-up is delayed the greater the chance of another health and safety problem at the site. By 1982 clean-up operations at the plant had crept along at a snail's pace as GPU waited to see where the clean-up money was coming from.

Before the accident GPU was in a sound financial position and its shares were high on the stock market. At the time of the accident it carried the maximum amount of property insurance available, $300m. About two-thirds of this money had already been spent by 1981. The company originally estimated that the clean- up would cost about $400m, meaning that the company would have to come up with yet another $100m above its insurance payment. By 1982 the clean-up was taking longer than expected and, because of inflation, it was estimated to cost at least $1 billion.

Decontamination does not come cheaply. Four hundred and nine million dollars have already been spent. Now, in 1984, five years after the accident, or ' incident' as it is called in the nuclear industry, at least two years of decontamination work lies ahead at an additional cost of $591m. While we are naturally wary of possible future incidents in the nuclear power industry, let the 'industry' itself and those who support it beware of the insurmountable, never-ending financial problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few days the Government, and particularly the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) and the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley), who is the honourable member for Swan and who is from Western Australia, have been trying to tell the Western Australians that they have not been forgotten by this innovation in tourist travel, the Air Pass. In fact the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism has said that this imaginative new initiative will knock all Australians on their ears. The Minister for Aviation, in answer to a dorothy dix question from the equally ill-informed honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) from Western Australia, used as an example, might I say his only example, the benefits that will be derived by Western Australians. In his answer to this question he was criticising our very capable shadow Minister for Tourism, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) when he said-this is the Minister for Aviation on Wednesday-that Western Australians could get to the eastern States using the $500 fare. Might I say he did not indicate how Western Australians could get back, but we certainly could get to the eastern States. I can understand the pressures that Ministers are under when answering questions. The Minister for Aviation is a very busy person, he sort of shadow boxes around and gets his duds up all the time and gives his old nose a bit of a wipe, but his concentration must have lapsed a little bit. If anyone from the west wants to get to the eastern States he can get a return fare for $381, a flexi-fare to Sydney and back, let alone having to use the $500 fare.

SPEECH.PARA: The main point I wish to raise is: The Minister cites examples of two different situations that may occur regarding the $500, 6,000-kilometre fare or the $800, l0,000-kilometre fare. He states:
For example, under the $500 fare they could-
that is, Western Australians-
fly Perth-Darwin-Alice Springs-Perth at a saving of $272 on the price.

Unfortunately I have news for him. I do not know whether he is aware of it already, but a number of my constituents have sought that fare to do exactly that. In fact, one of my constituents and his three friends were going to charter a light aircraft to do exactly that, cancelled the light aircraft and decided they would avail themselves of the new fare. Unfortunately that is not available to Western Australians. The trip happens to be 160 kilometres over 6, 000 kilometres. If a Western Australian wants to use the Kangaroo Air Pass it will cost him $800, will it not? I advise the Minister for Aviation that that fare is not available. It is l60 kilometres over.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he has misled the House.

—I would not suggest that he has misled the House. I do not imply that. I think it is just a lack of homework. The Minister has lambasted our shadow Minister for Tourism who made certain statements in the West Australian. The Minister for Aviation answered in the West Australian, criticising our excellent honourable member for Higgins. I am afraid the Minister will find that the honourable member for Higgins is right. If the Minister for Aviation and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism really want to knock us on our ears, why do they not work towards developing a truly competitive domestic airline system? They should rethink cross country charter flights; rethink giving Qantas Airways Ltd the right to carry passengers across Australia; and rethink perhaps the third line operator from Western Australia, Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd and then perhaps air travel to and from Western Australia might be more appealing.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to touch briefly on two areas which concern racism in our society. Before I commence, I would like to place on record my congratulations to Charles Perkins on his appointment today as head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I do that as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. I regret what occurred in this place today when the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Barker, (Mr Porter), saw fit to attack Charles Perkins in an unfair way. I think it is disappointing. I have already had a couple of members of the Opposition suggest to me that they regret what occurred. They thought it would have been a proper thing for the shadow Minister to congratulate Charles Perkins on his appointment. I regret the failure by the Opposition to acknowledge the appointment of an Aboriginal for the first time in this country to such a high position. I would like to congratulate Charles on his appointment.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a motion on the Notice Paper in my name which deals with racism. I would like to bring to the attention of the House a poster that appeared in my electorate. I think it will concern all honourable members of this House. It reads:
Stop the Asian invasion. Say no to mass Asian immigration. Say no to cheap Asian imports. Say no to Asian-American corporations. Support the National Action, Box . . .

It is interesting that honourable members of the Opposition laugh at that, but I happen to represent somewhere between 14,000 and 16,000 Asian people. I am proud to do so. I resent those people who print this sort of literature going around the electorate of Melbourne pasting it up, inciting racial hatred to a degree which I think is equal to what occurred in Europe prior to the Second World War. We have a situation in this country where people are presenting racist type arguments to our community. On the one hand we have people like Ruxton of the Returned Services League. I have spoken about him in this place before. He expresses extreme racial hatred every time he or people like Jennifer McCallum from the People Against Communism speak to any rally in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fought for Australia.

—Fought for Australia? He is no lone ranger there in fighting for Australia, but it gives him no right to attack people in the racist way he does, continually at rallies and on the radio. It astounds me how responsible people in charge of our media allow an individual of that calibre to make such statements. Sir William Keyes, in an article in the Canberra Times, condemns Ruxton for his racist statements and dissociates the RSL from him. I am pleased to see that occur.

SPEECH.PARA: In the middle of this we have the very slick-he is sometimes too smooth for his own good-comments made by the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs , the honourable member for Denison, (Mr Hodgman), in this place. It is interesting to see that the shadow Minister continually refers to the need to go back to our traditional areas of migration. In a recent speech he criticised the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, (Mr West), on the question of the intakes from Asia. We heard him talk about how he was a member of this organisation and how he was a member of that organisation, but underlying it all is criticism. One can only take it as that. I am sure the Asian communities-in fact, I know the Asian communities and, in fact, a wide number of ethnic communities-are concerned at the attitude. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) can sit there and laugh and sit there and glow with a full head of steam, but the facts are that he made statements such as: 'We will make immigration an election issue'.

We should look at the extreme position that has been put by these people. Incidentally in the very near future we will be able to name the printer of this document and the people who paid for it. We will expose those people and the people supporting this National Action group. What I am trying to say to the House is: If one looks at the views expressed by Ruxton and at the very slick racial attack that has been undertaken by a committee of this House on the Aboriginal Development Commission under the guise of some form of investigation into an Aboriginal body-the honourable member for Denison can screw up his nose- and if one puts it all together, one sees that it creates a very dangerous situation. That is all I am trying to say. There is Ruxton; inquiries built up about nothing into the Aboriginal Development Commission; criticisms of Charles Perkins; criticisms about Asian intakes; and criticisms about people from Central America coming into this country. This all feeds the ratbag elements which exist in our society and which promote this sort of material.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—I am indeed delighted to see my colleague, the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley), in the House because I told him earlier that I was going to say something about the subject of Sydney Airport in the Grievance Debate. He had been aware of that and was unable, I am sorry to say, to be in the House. I would have liked to have seen him then and to have heard from him. Now that he is here, perhaps I can ask him one or two questions directly. He has occupied this high position for more than 12 months.
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I call the Minister for Aviation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite certain what the honourable gentleman wished to ask me, but yes, I have been a Minister for 12 months.
—Order! The debate is interrupted. Unless the Minister makes a certain request the House will adjourn.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that the debate be extended.
—The debate may be extended until 11.10 p.m.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker--

—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney completely misunderstands. The provision of the Standing Orders is to allow an extension to allow the Minister to reply. I call the Minister for Aviation.

—Perhaps I might actually get some time to address some of the points that have been made by the honourable member for North Sydney. I am not sure of the question he was going to ask me. He may have been wishing to confirm the fact that I have been a Minister for 12 months. I can confirm that for him. He did get that far in his speech. Yes, indeed, I have been the Minister for Aviation for 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: I will address first the points made by my colleague the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond), who was a little ungenerous in some of the things he had to say about the air fares introduced by the airlines offering new opportunities for Australian domestic tourists and, I think, opportunities that are in their extent unprecedented. The honourable member mentioned as the basis for his criticism-I take this criticism on board and, indeed, take it to heart-the fact that, if the traveller wishes to reach only one point, for example, Sydney from Perth, the fare is indeed higher than that offered under the flexi-fare system.

The honourable member might have gone on to ask under whom the flexi-fares were introduced. The flexi-fares which are a 45 per cent discount-a very good discount indeed-were of course introduced after pressures on the part of this Government on the airlines to start to address that requirement. Indeed, the flexi-fares have worked far better between Western Australia and the eastern States than they have done between any combination of points elsewhere. That is because Western Australians have in their travel patterns established a pattern of frequently wishing to go to only one point in the eastern States and then start their travels by other means of transport or visit one point for business purposes.

The flexi-fare works at its best on point to point travel. That is its major impact on fares over the longer distance. Of course, those distances are very great. Therefore, Western Australians have shown a markedly greater tendency to make use of that discount than any group of people elsewhere. I am quite delighted to take on board that criticism by the honourable member; but I do not think the point was worth making in the first place.

The honourable member also raised a grievance of several of his colleagues. I shall certainly happily look into that grievance. The honourable member did not go on to talk about the other opportunity that I talked about in regard to the $ 800 fares which raise very considerable opportunities for savings. The example I cited at the time was the very substantial tourist opportunity to save an amount of $676. Honourable members have to remember that in the Western Australian context tourism goes both ways. I have found as a Western Australian over the years that our opportunities-it is a point we often complain about-to visit the eastern States have been heavily curtailed because of air fares and South East Asian destinations have proved more popular. The point about this new fare is that it will offer Western Australians an opportunity to see the eastern States at a reasonable price. This is an opportunity which, to this point of time, has been largely denied them, at least beyond one or two points under the flexi-fare . From that point of view to the Western Australian tourist the fare is very good. Again from the point of view of the person who wants to come into Western Australia, there are many combinations under the $800 fare, in particular, and some combinations under the $500 fare which will offer an opportunity for Western Australians to come to Perth. Western Australians know that the most normal mode of touring in the south west of Western Australia is not by air but by hire car or bus.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you go to Albany?

—There is almost no aviation infrastructure in the south west of Western Australia which, if the honourable member, were any sort of shadow tourist Minister, he would know something about. We are trying to improve that in our relationship with the Albany Town Council but we are not there yet.
—How can you go to Bunbury?

—The honourable member raises an interesting point. I will take that point on board and make some inquiries with the airlines on it. That was not the only example I gave of that fare possibility. The other examples I gave offered some considerable savings. The opportunity for eastern staters to get into Perth in a way in which they have not been able to do to this point, in addition to a substantial tour perhaps of the Northern Territory and South Australia at the same time, as will be possible under the $800 fare, will send them into an area where I think considerable opportunities for tourism abound. They abound in fact in most of the areas in the electorate of the honourable member for Forrest, both the wine areas and the towns in the south of Western Australia. They also abound in the electorate of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey).

SPEECH.PARA: I have toured those areas frequently myself. I have never toured those areas in an aircraft, I have toured them by car, as has the honourable gentleman. When I was Special Minister of State I was not able to do the things for him that I ought to have been able to do in extending his mileage. He does not fly to Bunbury after he comes into Perth; he drives to Bunbury like everybody else. Of course, if there were an aircraft available for him to fly between Perth and Bunbury on anything like a regular basis the honourable member might have a very different attitude.

I suggest that the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) pay us a visit and have a good look around at the south west because he will enjoy it immensely . He can be guaranteed a very good time. In his very valuable tour of that area he will not find a great deal of aviation infrastructure. He may, indeed, be able to suggest to us some ways in which we might improve the aviation services in the south west so we can do something about them.

Neither I nor the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has ever suggested, firstly, that we have a directional power in relation to air fares. We do not. Secondly, we have never suggested that what has been presented is the be-all and end-all and that other opportunities ought not to be sought. We were invited by the honourable member for Forrest to address the possibility of ending the two airlines agreement. We will address that possibility. However, we will address it on the time frame selected for us by the honourable gentleman 's colleagues when they passed it through this Parliament. I am not sure but I think the honourable gentleman may have been an honourable exception in voting on that because a number of Western Australian Liberals were. Certainly, neither the honourable member for Higgins nor the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) were exceptions. They are both devotees of the regulatory arrangements that were introduced--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not devotees.

—The honourable member was devotee enough to vote for them. I am not going to be wholly critical of those arrangements. I think certain features of the arrangements and the changes introduced at the time were good, including the Independent Air Fares Committee. I think it ought to have more powers as a consumer protection body than it has. Nevertheless, that was a step in the right direction. It was a step, nonetheless, which deprived myself and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism of any opportunity for any directional activity in relation to the operation of air fares to Western Australia. I invite the honourable gentleman to do what I shall be doing when we set up our review of the two airlines agreement and make submissions to the people who will be conducting that review when it gets into place in a reasonable time, to fit into the timetable set by his colleagues in the last Parliament. I ask him to raise the possibilities of Qantas Airways Ltd--
—Order! It being 11.10 p.m., the House stands adjourned until 10 a.m. tomorrow.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 5 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: In each financial year since the inception of the (a) export market development grants schemes for (i) goods, services, et cetera, and (ii) tourist services and (b) export expansion grants scheme, which organisations or persons received grants, and for what value (a) in the electoral division of Wakefield and (b) for horticultural and relating industries throughout Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Export Development Grants Board determines grants under the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 and the Export Expansion Grants Act 1978. The export expansion grants scheme was allowed to lapse on 30 June 1983.
Details of recipients and the amounts of the grants provided are included in the Board's annual reports. The 1982-83 Report was tabled in the House on 29 November 1983.
The Board neither records nor has the facilities to record grants received by organisations or persons in a particular electoral division or a particular industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March 1984 (Hansard, page 413) Mr Hand asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, a question without notice concerning nuclear waste in Australia and I undertook to provide further information on the quantities of waste currently being stored.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
The quantities of the various types of radioactive wastes stored at the Research Establishment of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission at Lucas Heights are as follows:

(a) 510 m3 of low level solid wastes consisting mainly of slightly contaminated trash and dried sludge resulting from the treatment of liquid waste. This material is stored in buildings and most of it is or will be compacted into 200 litre plastic lined steel drums

(b) 136.7 m3 of more highly radioactive solid waste from reactor operation, radiopharmaceutical production and experimental work, stored in concrete lined pits excavated in sandstone and water-proofed with a bituminous membrane
(c) 2.87 m3 of liquid wastes, mainly from radiopharmaceutical production, contained in a special facility which includes shielded tanks.

Small amounts of radioactive waste are held in storage by other Commonwealth and State authorites; it is estimated that the total volumes held are in the order of 10 m3 and 20 m3 respectively. This waste has low to medium levels of radioactivity and includes material accepted for disposal from hospitals, research institutions and industry; it consists of, for example, surplus radiation sources, contaminated laboratory equipment, radiovalves and luminising paint. These quantities do not include low level wastes arising from industrial processes such as uranium mining and milling and processing of mineral sands.

The low level wastes currently in storage are considered to be suitable for disposal by shallow ground burial when a suitable site is available. Higher level wastes, after conditioning including solidification of liquid waste, would be suitable for disposal to a national repository. The question of waste disposal has been under joint review by Commonwealth and State officials.

In addition, wastes contaminated with low amounts of radioactivity and toxic chemicals were buried on AAEC land adjacent to Lucas Heights between 1960 and 1968, and contaminated furnace waste from Singapore was buried near Kambalda in 1981.
